description:
I love going to Spice Kit for lunch! Spice Kit has a great central downtown SF location, so don't expect to find parking easily if you're driving into town.

I've only gotten the Five-Spice Vietnamese bowls or Korean bowls; both are solid options. The food is very flavorful and healthy-ish - you won't find your meal swimming in excess oil like some other restaurants. I usually add a bit of Sriracha from the nearby cabinet for some extra kick 
(You'll find the nearby cabinet to hold more Sriracha in one spot than you've ever seen before). I do find the portions a bit small, though the food is fairly priced for downtown SF prices.

The lunch line can get very long around 12/12:30ish, but it moves pretty quickly. Overall, Spice Kit is a great spot to swing by for affordable tasty food!
author: Ganeev S.

description:
Located in the heart of Fi-Di, came here on a Thurs around noon.  There is a line, but it moves fairly quickly.  It's kind of like Chipotle, but with good Asian flavors!  Pick the form: sandwich, Korean Bowl, Viet Bowl, or Salad.  Pick a protein: Pork, Chicken, Beef --  all Asian-ish marinated.  

I picked Korean Bowl with Chicken.  It was very tasty and juicy and a healthy, fresh portion of shredded zucchinis and bean sprouts.  The hubs got the sandwich.  He enjoyed it.  I thought the pickles in the sandwich felt a bit harsh (compared to what you get at other nearby Viet places).  I def enjoyed and preferred my Korean bowl.

We also got two pork bao cause I read good reviews for it.  The boas are kind of small, so 2 for $5 is reasonable.  I would have felt ripped off if I had gotten it at 1 for $3.75.  The meat is tasty & juicy in the bao and the seasoning was nice with two slices of pickles.  Chalk it up to: quality ingredients come at a price, I guess.

Overall, a very solid lunch option in Soma.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
This is a review for their breakfast.

If you love grits I  recommend the rice bowl. Its simple, savory, filling and delicious. It also pairs well with a steamed bun,
author: Kaylan W.

description:
Decided to come here last minute on a weekday night to avoid the commuter traffic going home. We wanted to let the traffic die down before heading back to the East Bay. This was the only place that was open in the area that wasn't fancy dining. I wanted their chicken wrap but they were out of wraps. So I decided to go with their 5 spiced chicken rice plate. My husband ordered their garlic chili tofu Korean bowl. We also ordered a vegetarian bun & peanut slaw. 

Everything was pretty good except for the peanut slaw. The peanut slaw was so wilted I couldn't eat more than a bite of it. The chicken was spiced ok. The tofu was pretty good as well as the vegetarian bun. Too bad they didn't have anymore wraps left. It looked pretty good on yelp!
author: Ruby V.

description:
One of my go-to frugal eats in downtown SF, Spice Kit makes grabbing lunch simple and cheap. Despite being one of my go-to places, the quality of the food isn't spectacular. 

Typically I order their Korean bowl with lemongrass pork. The dish itself is usually a bit too oily and the pork had hints of the lemongrass smell but could really benefit from being marinated longer. The rest of the dish is complemented with assorted toppings like kind of julienned cucumbers, sesame oil tossed bean sprouts and some lettuce. These toppings are good to help soak up the oiliness of the lemongrass pork. Additionally this dish will usually have their kimchi rice included which also acts as another way to soak up the oily pork but helps provide a sweet sour contrast to the dish. 

The main thing is the food is decent. The kimchi rice seems to be a little too soft, could really improve from using maybe a day old rice or even just popping it on a wok to crispen up. All in all, I tend to come back mostly because the prices hover around $10 range but would suggest other places if you don't like your food to be overly oily.
author: Ryan F.

description:
Pretty good spot for asian fusion banh mi, wraps, salads, Korean and Vietnamese bowls in FiDi. Quite surprised to see the poor ratings. Watch out for cleanliness I guess. Portion size seemed fine to me too...

The format is pretty simple, you choose a style and choose a protein/filling. They have Five Spice Kitchen, Free Range Beef, Roasted Pork & Organic Tofu. They seem to be a pretty popular spot for lunch as they only had the pork and tofu when we came on a Friday night around 7 PM. I'd love to come back to try the chicken.

They had sides/add ons like a sous vide egg, pate, steamed pork buns, lotus chips & ginger peanut slaw.

Vietnamese Bowl - Steamed rice, crispy garlic, peanuts, jalapeno, cucumber, pickled veggies. Had this with the pork, tasted pretty good and met my expectations. 

Ginger Peanut Slaw - Thinly shredded cabbage, herbs, with ginger dressing. A must get! Makes for a great side.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Dropped by here for lunch during work.

Theres a lot of options for an fusion from banh mi and wraps to Korean or Vietnamese bowls. 

The overall way to order is pretty simple and it kind of reminds me of chipotle, but here it is just a style and the type of protein and maybe some sides and add ons if you wanted. 

Ended up getting a beef Korean bowl. I thought the portions were a little small. It contained red leaf lettuce, seasoned rice, bean sprouts, kimchi and cucumbers. Everything tasted well, but nothing mind blowing. The beef was a little chewy and dry. The place overall isn't bad if you're looking for something quick for lunch.
author: Timothy D.

description: Great food! I get their MealPal specials and it's an awesome deal!
author: Jac R.

description: I had lunch takeout from MealPal here, when they were offering the Vietnamese pork with rice bowl. The Yelp pictures looked enticing online and I was really craving some SE Asian flavors. Unfortunately though, I've never had such rubbery and oddly game-y pork that was both dry and tasteless. I ended up abandoning the meat after a few bites, which felt like a shame because it was a decent portion. I finished up the rice and veggies with fish sauce, but the flavor was one-dimensional and made me wish I had drenched more sriracha over the whole thing. Overall, kind of disappointing and don't think I'll be coming by again.
author: Annie L.

description:
All you seem to get is HAIR in your food. Disgusting. I do not recommend this place. They also have horrible service too.

I brought my Vietnamese bowl back to my office to find hair in my rice. (1st pic) then I brought my food back and without even a slight apology the lady behind the counter (Analyn? Lady who rudely took my order as well) took it back and made another order. Walked back and didn't think it was necessary to write this but half way through my meal I find another tiny hair floating in my sauce container. (Second pic) this is really unacceptable and they should wear hair nets when working back there. Also they jump back from the register and gathering food without using any gloves. The Vietnamese bowl is ok you get what you pay for, and their Korean bowl needs lots of work. 

This used to be in my rotation when I didn't want to walk too far for lunch but hair in my food twice in two different trips? Unacceptable. Those who eat here without paying attention.. y'all could be just eating hair this whole time! I've totally lost my appetite and this is a waste of my lunch. I hope you guys fix your hair net rules and your attitudes. Beware, if you decide to come here make sure you thoroughly check your food.
author: Suzie J.

description: The four stars are for the organic tofu bowls, the pork buns and their awesome customer service. I find their meat to be too chewy.
author: Maya Z.

description:
We came here at 11am on Friday for an early lunch, and there was no line at all. The restaurant itself is small, but there are plenty of tables outside in the small plaza (also in the shade) to eat at.

I ordered a Korean Bowl (seasoned rice, red leaf lettuce, cucumbers, marinated bean sprouts, kimchi, and their signature ssãm sauce) with free-range Kalbi Beef for around $10. I asked for brown rice which is free of charge! The portions were good for lunch and all of the ingredients tasted fine, but the beef was just a little dry.

Spice Kit is not a bad place to try out for some quick Asian Fusion food, and I might try their Steamed Buns or Mango Lassi on their breakfast menu (not served all day) next time.
author: George L.

description:
Not a bad concept - basically an Asian Chipotle. Fast service, decent food. All good.

Quick little lunch place.
author: Jimmy S.

description:
Food: 4/5
Service: 5/5
Ambiance: 4/5
Overall: I'd be back

The extended review...

Food:

Beef bowl - yummy yummy.  The beef with the kimchi rice is very tasty.  I used to frequent this place in the area and I've never had a bad lunch here.

Service - very nice staff

Ambiance - it's more a grab and go place.  Though there is nice seating outside on a sunny day.
author: Spencer Q.

description: I've only eaten here once and I would definitely return!  It's got some solid vegan options, the food is fresh and the staff are knowledgeable, engaged and friendly.  The prices are reasonable and the food is tasty!
author: Jenn C.

description:
No. Just no. If Spice Kit was the only lunch spot available for days, I rather not eat. I used to come here a lot because their food was tasty, cheap and well portioned. 

But the other day I found a huge MOTH in my bowl. When I asked for extra protein, I didn't mean THIS. Dead, yes. Fully intact, oh yea. And it blended so well with my lettuce, I almost ate it (I think I just vomited in my mouth a little reliving this experience). 

I immediately went back and they didn't even offer an apology. They just gave me a new bowl and called it a day. If they seemed more sincere about my lunch fiasco, I wouldn't have been so upset. But they literally shrugged it off, and the cook even seemed annoyed that I brought it back. 

I could've made a scene, but I had a meeting to get back to and it wasn't as if I was hungry anymore anyway (I gave the replaced lunch bowl to a homeless man). So long Spice Kit, you lost yourself a customer. And you can bet when I told my coworkers about this mishap, that they're never coming back either (so it's more like 12 customers). See ya.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
Can't decide between Korean or Vietnamese food? Then come here. This place is awesome in that it's kind of split into Korean Fusion or Vietnamese Fusion so you can have your Korean marinated meat one day and your banh mi another. If that doesn't sell you then does the price point of under $10? I know, a rare gem in SF.

I ended up getting the korean chicken bowl and I found it filling. The bowl itself could have been 2 meals if I wasn't starving since they give you a hearty portion. The chicken was flavored well and tender. The only concern is that it was more saucy than I expected which isn't much to pick at. The kimchi rice was cooked well and had large portions of kimchi in it. Pair that with your veggies and it's a solid lunch. 

Lines get crazy during lunch so come by 11:45 at the latest to beat them! They do have other options like steamed buns, vietnamese iced coffee, and thai tea if that's something you're craving with your meal.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
Spice Kit is my go-to for lunch!

Spice Kit is simple and fresh. Essentially, you choose what type of meal you want (e.g. Rice bowl, banh mi sandwich) then you choose what type of protein you want.

I discovered (and frequent) Spice Kit as part of MealPal. If you do meal pal, it's a great value and you can skip the line. 

The best option here is the Korean beef rice bowl. The beef is amazing and all the flavors come together.

The chicken here is seasoned differently. A friend and I said the chicken almost seems like pork. It's quite good, but a little different. 

The salads here are also really good. They're quite big and the dressing is very tasty.

It's fast, fresh, delicious!

Like just about anywhere downtown, go a little before noon to avoid a line.
author: Jonathan N.

description:
One of the worst meals I've had in recent memory. Shared two dishes and the pork buns. Food was slimy, over-sauced and lacked flavor. Both the pork and chicken tasted slightly off. We purchased a side of white rice to try to make the whole thing more palatable. 

The pork buns were a joke. The buns were spongy and dry and the meat was inedible. I would rather eat 10 day-old spaghetti than dine at this establishment again.
author: J. P.

description:
Fried chicken Friday y'all! In case you were wondering, they also have fried chicken on Wednesday, too. 

So, I probably eat fried chicken in some cuisine or another like once a week. I freaking love it and can't get enough. Spice Kit does their fried chicken well. It's nicely breaded and seasoned pretty well. I usually get it over a salad. It's a nice go to for lunch that's quick, across the street, and has a line that moves pretty quickly.

Overall, I find their portions small (maybe I eat a lot? haha), Vietnamese coffee too sweet (and not authentic by any means) and wish their dressing had more complex flavor to it, but it's all good. The peanuts have a nice crunch.
author: Shereen A.

description:
As far as cheap meals in SF go, this one wasn't too shabby. I paid $8.95 for a Korean bowl with 5-spice chicken. Portions were actually pretty solid--I wonder if the restaurant has improved in that regard, as many reviewers before me seem to have been disappointed by their portion size. 

I found my chicken to be well-cooked and flavorful, and the kimchi rice was on point as well. The bowl also contained generous vegetable portions, and they all tasted fresh. Overall, for under $10, it's hard for me to complain about this meal. It was a quick, easy takeout option that hit the spot.
author: Leela S.

description: This is the place where I go if it rains hard in SF b/c it's close to work. It has a pretty good five-spice chicken salad that I always order. I always like restaurant with simple menu that doesn't complicate people like me who easily get anxiety with too many choices...
author: Isabelle L.

description:
This place's service is quite the best I've experienced from fast food restaurants. The food is authentic and made fresh (at least that's what it seems like lol). 

You can be in and out of there within 5 minutes. 

The thing I don't like about this place is the amount of spices they add in their spiced rice. I've been similar rice before but nowhere near as spiced as these are. 

On the other hand, their chicken is great. 

Very nice, recommended.
author: Manpreet S.

description:
OVERALL
Solid Asian fusion meal spot! Conveniently located in Financial District, which makes it an easy grab&go lunch. Food is tasty, flavorful, and while not 100% authentic, it still does the job. 

FOOD
Ordered a Vietnamese bowl with Tofu through MealPal. Tofu was flavorful, rice & veggies were great, and the citrus fish sauce was decent. 

SERVICE
If you go during lunch rush (12:00 - 1:00pm), the line gets pretty long, but moves quickly as the cashiers are pros at moving things along. 

SEATING
Few seating inside, but there's tables outside for a nice meal on a sunny day. 

If you want authentic, amazing Vietnamese food, go to San Jose. If you want a tasty, quick lunch that will fix your cravings, go to Spice Kit.
author: Danny C.

description:
Pick your base (bowl,salad, or sandwich), then protein. Asian ingredients made similar to Chipotle.

Had the Korean Bowl, kimchi rice was good, beef could have been better. Diced cubes of beef were well done. Maybe if it was slight seared could've added slight more texture. 

Overall good lunch for about $15 with tip
author: Robin L.

description:
So the food here isn't amazing...but portion sizes are generous, the food is flavorful, and prices are reasonable! Great option for lunch if you're looking for some quick food in the city. I went with the Korean Bowl with garlic tofu. The Korean Bowl comes with lettuce, cucumbers, bean sprouts, a good pile of kimchi rice, and the protein topping that you pick. I thought the veggies were good. The kimchi rice was really salty and the rice was a bit soggy, but at least it had flavor! The garlic tofu was also a bit on the salty side, but very tasty. I also ordered two of their pork belly buns. Wasn't very impressed. The bun was the best part. The texture was light and fluffy. But the meat was meh...wasn't as tender as I expected it to be. 

All in all, though, I think this place is decent. Just have a cup of water ready to clench your thirst. The food here has good flavor, minus the salt. And for the amount of food that you get, the prices are definitely reasonable.
author: Ashley Y.

description: I got the Vietnamese bowl w/ lemongrass pork, plus 2 pork belly buns. The pork was dry and accompanied by a tiny portion of soggy rice. I only poured less than half of the tiny fish sauce container and my meal turned into something that resembled oversalted congee. The pork belly buns are very small, underwhelmingly seasoned, and certainly not worth 2 for $5.
author: Josh L.

description:
Greasy as hell !!!
Everything is doused in copious amounts of oil, portions are small for the price they charge and the taste is average at best. 
The batter fried tofu is almost inedible, soggy, spongy and the batter layer is very thick.
author: Abhi K.

description: Another solid lunch option in the area. I've only had the chicken salad so far but would like to try the bowls, as well. The salad is a decent sized portion and blends all the flavors really nicely. The peanut dressing is served on the side so you can choose how much/little you want of it. Whenever I come here around 1:30-2 the place is fairly empty so you have your choice of seating, whether inside or at the tables outside. Service is super fast too so it's great if you're in a hurry.
author: Pooja C.

description: The breakfast sandwich was filling and light. The service was nice and quick. My favorite part in the sandwich was the way they made the eggs nice and fluffy. The Chinese sausage is more on the cooked side to me. I like the music they play (R&B/pop)
author: Angeline T.

description: Close to home and clean! Located in a plaza right outside the Orrick building. Just a block away to get a quick couple orders of Vietnamese or Korean bowl with some veggies/Kim Chee(yummy dipping sauce). Pick your own meat like the 5 spice chicken or kalbi beef. The steam pork belly bun is not bad either if you like something hearty. Likey!
author: Vee V.

description:
1st visit - got the rice and protein.  it wasn't bad for the price - less than $10.

2nd visit - They serve breakfast and are open at 6 a.m.  Do not expect all items to be readily available though.
I got the coleslaw, chicken banh mi with egg, and yogurt.  About $17 and some change.

Their banh mi is not as good as Dragoneats.  
You get like a mini burrito size; dragon is like a full size burrito/sandwich.
Kit's is $8.25 and Dragon's is $7.50.
Ingredients were good BUT THEY FORGOT MY EGG!  Watch out for the jalapenos.
Their bread is flaky and light but it falls apart especially if its soggy and cracked.  Dragon's is a little heavier and can get sloppy but not as bad.

Coleslaw is not too soggy.

Yogurt is infused with mango I think.  Its yellow not white.  It comes with a nut and cracker mixture.  Its different, not bad.
author: Chris S.

description:
Stopped in for an evening snack around 5:30pm on a Friday, which would be nearly prime dinner hours. This place was beyond dead... to the point that no one was at the front counter when I walked in and there was only one person in the back that had a flat-top grill pulled out from the wall and cleaning it. I had to ask if they were open regardless of the sign in front saying they're open til 8pm. Despite that, I decided to give them the benefit of the doubt and proceeded anyways.

I ordered 2 Steamed Pork Buns and a Peanut Slaw. The pork buns, a beloved favorite, we're underwhelming. It's important to note that they were tightly wrapped in foil as if they were going to run away ruining the integrity of the bun itself. Aside from the highly unusual way to seve them, the pork was tender and had decent flavor, but they were far from exciting. The slaw had too much ginger and not enough peanuts. Personally, I love ginger, but I also love balanced flavor. The ginger completely over-powered the entire dish.

Overall, the service was very friendly (which was a redeeming factor) but the food was average at best and seemed to be tailored for the non-Asian palate.
author: Zach H.

description:
Ameticanized asin bowls limited menu; designed for speed. 

Veggie bun: shiitake mushrooms sautéed in soy sauce glaze. Favorite; the least sweet of anything on the menu. Would order again. Little pricey at 3.50 after tax

Ginger peanut salad: smells like ginger when you open the container. Sweet mayo like sauce. Little too creamy for Asian taste I think

Viet bowl w tofu: white rice with shredded carrots and cucumber. Excellent job getting flavor into crispy tofu. Spicy. May work better w rice noodles vs white rice. Fish sauce and citrus dipping sauce. Slightly sweet. Highly recommend. Tofu is fantastic. Threw out the fish/citrus sauce.
author: Doug C.

description:
$13 for a really bad viet sando and just an okay pork bun. If you know what a viet sandwich should taste like then pass on Spice Kit - just don't do it!!!

I got the 5 spiced chicken banh mi and added on a fried egg + pate. The bread was soggy and crumbs were falling all over the place. I love pate, but the pate here is so bland. 

I was really disappointed with this meal.
author: Jennifer T.

description: My go to place for lunch. Loved the Vietnamese bowl with chicken. Tried the pork belly was ok. Only Jing I wish they had is soup. Feel the meal was quite cold and if here is a warm soup, that will be even better!
author: Anya C.

description:
I used to love Spice Kit.  I periodically work out of an office in the same building, so it was very convenient, particularly if I wanted to grab a quick dinner.  Great food, too.

Multiple evenings recently, though, I've arrived to find that most if not all of their menu options are sold out, despite allegedly being open, typically explained by "catering orders."  

My most recent visit was worst of all, though.  

With great trepidation, I went in and asked if they had pork buns (my favorite), and to my joy, they said yes.  I ordered a drink, and unfortunately found that there was no ice.  Not the end of the world, but annoying.  When I returned to the counter, I saw them handing over my pork buns to be bagged, which was surprising, because normally they're made to order, which takes a few minutes.  Apparently, they had a number of them premade and sitting in a pot.  

"Ruh roh..." Scooby-Doo would say, but I took them to my office anyway, where I opened them up to find their temperatures somewhere between tepid and cold.

I didn't have time to take them back to the store, but I should have, because putting aside the food safety issues from their temperature, the buns were awful and the pork tough, as though they had been sitting for far too long, which they clearly had been.

Maybe Spice Kit is still good at lunch - I can't report on that, but it really seems like they should not remain open for dinner.  They're clearly half-heartedly doing it by effectively shutting down the kitchen hours before the actual closing time, and it disappoints previous fans.  Either stay open for real or don't bother.
author: Greg H.

description: I used to frequent this place often for lunch however my last visit about 3 months ago was disappointing and I have never returned. Though the prices have remained the same the portions have gotten really small.  I would rather have them increase the price a bit and have kept the portions the same.  It's a shame that they have taken this course.  Please notify me if you have made changes.  I miss eating at your venue.
author: Kenji M.

description:
What the hell is this? The pork seems to be boiled, it had no lemongrass taste at all.

Definitely not coming back.
author: richard y.

description: Found this little gem in the heart of San Francisco for lunch. Went back there 2 consecutive days since it's so fast, convenient and tasty! Must try the Korean bowl with Kalbi beef and Vietnamese bowl with lemongrass pork. The best part is being able to eat in the nice outdoor area of 405 Howard St.
author: Ada M.

description:
Love this place! It's like the Asian version of chipotle, but more consistent in quality.  Stoked to find a location close to work!! 

My go to: Korean bowl with chicken, and a side of a pork bun, with Thai iced tea.
author: Ha N.

description:
Like putting world music on the radio or flipping to the FoodNetwork on the TV, SpiceKit is a welcomed break from the same ol' SoMA lunch options. 

The food is very flavorful, the portions are solid, the service is fast, and the prices are reasonable. That said, I think SpiceKit stands out for its differentness as much as for its awesomeness. 

The Korean Bowl comes with seasoned rice and bean sprouts and julienned cuke. On top of that I had the chicken, which was really flavorful. Good spice and no grease. 

Will likely flip it on once a season, but not likely to a regular spot.
author: Lanny B.

description:
Checked this place out during the mid-week lunch rush, around 12:30 pm. There was a long line, but it moved super-quickly, and the orders came out 5-10 minutes after ordering. They have some bench seating inside, but this isn't a place to bring a date - it's about grubbing efficiency. 

I got the 5-spice Chicken Korean Bowl ($7.75), which came with meat, kim chi fried rice, an unsettlingly-large pile of marinated sprout/beans, and some shredded cucumber salad. Topped with some sriracha it was a solid, if not overly filling, meal. 

The sprouts were pretty off-putting, and even though I ate them all, it's not an experience I'm looking to repeat anytime soon. Lettuce at the bottom of the bowl became heated up by the chicken and wilted into a floppy, rubbery mess. The rice and spiced chicken were on point, and the cucumber slaw was alright. With a vegetable facelift, this place would be way better! Looks like next time I should get a salad. :-P
author: Laura B.

description: I came here to pick up my Mealpass lunch, a Vietnamese pork bowl. The meat was quite tender and I'm glad they used fully compostable bowls and forks. My only complaint is that the portion was too small
author: Nancy W.

description: Really outstanding.  Reminds me of a favorite Viet item I used to get in Oakland, the chicken salad option.  Really great intermingling of flavors and textures.  Fresh veggies and nice quality of ingredients.  A great item for Mealpal.  Wrap is a little messy.  I would recommend bowl or bread options.
author: Marc S.

description: A nice Asian fusion place, my favorite thing to order is the five spice chicken wrap. In many ways it is pretty much a burrito but with an Asian twist. The lines do get quite long during lunch time, but it is nothing out the ordinary for any Resturant in financial district. I've seen the portion sizes for the bowls as well, and they are quite large. Definitely worth the price.
author: Alex S.

description:
I regularly go here for lunch. 

I usually get the Vietnamese Tofu and chicken bowls. Both are pretty good.
The tofu bao is good, but not great. (Checkout Chairmain Bao)

The ginger slaw is also very good.
author: Nakul J.

description:
A couple friends and I grabbed dinner here on a Wednesday night - the food was great, and the service was even better. This is Chipotle-style Asian food, meaning you choose the method (sandwich, wrap, Vietnamese bowl, Korean bowl), you choose the protein (chicken, pork, beef, tofu), and you choose additions (sous-vide egg and pate). Our favorites? The wrap, which is a Vietnamese spring roll style rice wrap only burrito-sized, and the Korean bowl. The beef was by far the best protein.

The great thing about coming in the evening is that they're not very busy so you get very personal service. Here's where I give my shout-out to Jack (working the register 4/15/15 in the evening), who was so nice to us! He...
- Was super cheerful and enthusiastic. Gave great recs.
- Let me bring my bike in.
- Gave us samples of the beef and tofu when we were wavering. 
- Comp'ed my meal because so many things I was asking for were out! (See my receipt: )
- Had us sit when we ordered and brought our food out to us when it was ready.
- Gave each of us a free box of ginger paste.
- Let us hang out and talk way past closing time. 

The downside to coming so late is that they end up being out of so many things. The breakfast items look fantastic but, obviously, they're only served in the morning. My friend got the last coconut juice (they buy 13 coconuts and make 8 cups a day, fresh!). They were out of lotus chips. 

MUST-HAVES: 1st choice on method: Korean Bowl. 2nd choice: Wrap. Beef is the best protein, tofu is pretty good too. Must get the steamed bun!

* Ginger paste - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/spice-kit-san-francisco?select=70fas0hASlmfmZHm4bFd9Q#70fas0hASlmfmZHm4bFd9Q
I like the mix of peanut and ginger, but it didn't have a lot of flavor otherwise. It's a little bit soggy. Interesting to try, but I wouldn't necessarily get this again.

* Steamed pork bun - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/spice-kit-san-francisco?select=70fas0hASlmfmZHm4bFd9Q#yy6PRdn4gn0xmdXRPvuZDQ
The bun is perfectly fluffy, soft, and moist. The pork is has chewy fatty parts and crisp lean parts, and it has a great sweet/savory seasoning.

* Pork in Vietnamese bowl + egg - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/spice-kit-san-francisco?select=70fas0hASlmfmZHm4bFd9Q#nGRg-5YFAq_8-dGvHDEn1Q
The pork is a bit hard/overcooked. These are bowls where you end up mixing all the ingredients together (especially with the added egg), and that just doesn't work as well when this has a watery fish sauce and large pieces of pepper and carrot. It's got all the ingredients that go great together in Vietnamese food, but I think as a big mix bowl it doesn't quite work.

* Kalbi Beef in Korean bowl + egg - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/spice-kit-san-francisco?select=70fas0hASlmfmZHm4bFd9Q#4KQAHnuS26tfjmO6-h0IGw
The beef is so good! Its so chewy and fatty, and the flavor is delicious. THIS works great as a mix bowl -- the sauce is thicker, I love love loved the bean sprouts, and the egg brings it all together. It's like a modern bibimbap bowl, 

* Tofu in Rice Wrap with Pate - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/spice-kit-san-francisco?select=70fas0hASlmfmZHm4bFd9Q#moOU6KyO5XQaBR2yrurerg
We were impressed with how well the rice wrap held together! This was great, the tofu had a sweet-spicy flavor, and the pate had good texture - grainy, and there was tons in the wrap.

My receipt: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/spice-kit-san-francisco?select=70fas0hASlmfmZHm4bFd9Q#dXaMEbKsOst6Ujo3gRk7Eg
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I really love the flavors they create here - no idea if it's "authentic Vietnamese" or not, but whatever, it's delicious, fresh, fast. I tried the vegetarian bun (delicious mushrooms, super soft and fresh outer bread), and the chili-garlic tofu banh mi (just bursting with flavor).
Best of all, they are open for late lunches - you know, those times when you couldn't get to lunch before 3:30pm, and a lot of SoMa lunch places close their doors.
Tiny indoor seating, but there's seating outside.
author: What's in a nam e.

description:
~$12 for lunch w/side order. ~$8.30 for just the wrap. no line, short wait. similar to asian box / chipotle.

- chicken wrap: liked the chewiness of the very large gigantic wrap. would've preferred white meat chicken to thigh meat, but loved all the textures -  bean sprouts and marinated spicy rice. 
- mushroom steamed bun: didn't really like this very much - didn't feel the bun tasted very chewy/fresh, and there just wasn't much filling

bang for buck is decent here, would probably come back for the wrap
author: Kristie C.

description:
Another entry in the long standing tradition of food catered for lunch meetings at work.  This time, we had Spice Kit and ordered a bunch of chicken and veggie banh mi sandwiches for delivery.

I'm no banh mi connoisseur, but the chicken banh mi was better than most that I've had.  The bread was fresh, the sandwich was big, the chicken tender, and the spicy mayo gave it a nice kick.

The delivered sandwich was good enough for me to consider going to Spice Kit and actually ordering an in-person lunch and trying the rest of their menu.  High praise, coming from a lazy lazy man!
author: Nadeem A.

description: Unclean food handling - went for lunch and got severe food poisoning - started feeling unwell a few hours later and haven't been able to eat for 3 days since that meal. Never again. Ordered the five spice chicken wrap.
author: Erin K.

description:
A few of us at work decided to go grab some lunch at a food truck. Our first option was way too busy, however, someone suggested we go to this joint. I'm always up for some Asian grub and when I heard it was the Korean style Chipotle, I was super excited!

When you enter the joint, you get that modern feel. Concrete floors, minimal walls, exposed ceilings. The place gave off that industrial feel. When it came to ordering, there were 4 steps:

1. Choose your style: Sandwich, Wrap, Salad, Korean Bowl or Vietnamese Bowl
2. Choose your filling: Five Spice Chicken for $7.75, Kalbi Beef for $8.75, Lemongrass Pork for $8.25, or Chili Garlic Tofu for $7.25. At this step, you could also add an egg or pate. 
3. Choose your sides: upcharge of various items
4. Choose your drinks: only if applicable

For lunch, I got the Kalbi beef Korean bowl with an extra side of chicken for an extra charge of $1.50, EXCEPT, when I got back to my desk, there was no chicken :( They forgot to add that into my bowl or gave me someone else's bowl. I was pretty livid but since it was about 4 blocks away, I wasn't gonna walk back just for $1.50. Based on what I did have, the bowl came with chunks of kalbi, julienne cucumbers, seasoned rice, kim chi, marinated bean sprouts and their signature sauce. The bowl was ok. I didn't care for the taste of the sprouts. It almost seemed like it sat out for a while.The kalbi had a nice flavor but was a bit dry. I liked the rice and the cucumbers brought a fresh flavor to the dish. 

Overall, the place was just ok. I'm sure I'll be back in the future but I wouldn't necessarily rate this at the top of my list. If I'm ever craving Korean style Chipotle again, I'll come by and make sure I have all proteins the next time!
author: Rockne H.

description:
Love me a place that has their entire operations in order:

Clean and convenient location. CHECK.
Delicious food. CHECK.
Affordable prices. CHECK CHECK.
Fast and friendly service. CHECK CHECK CHECK.

If you're coming here for an authentic asian dish, you're in the wrong area. Spice Kit serves some tasty food.

My go-to is the Korean bowl + chicken. The marinated chicken is super good and the rice is slathered in a red sauce that I can't get enough of. Plus, lots of veggies on the side. It makes the meal complete.

All this for less than $9 and less than 10 minutes to order + pick up food. Seriously unheard of at some neighboring lunch spots.

Love the outdoor community patio area on a nice (rare) SF day too.
author: T L.

description:
Menu says breakfast buns and is priced as such but was actually just 1 small bun.

This type of dishonesty on the menu really bothers me and it's overpriced anyway.
author: Nick G.

description: This is an Asian fusion place which you can stop by to grab really good food for lunch. I came here for meal pal and their portions are big that I leave pretty satisfied and full. I got the Vietnamese tofu bowl. It comes with carrots, rice, fried tofu, and fish sauce. It was delicious! I can't wait to try the buns or sandwiches next time.
author: Jackie N.

description:
*Breakfast review. 

I wanted to try to pork belly (applewood smoked bacon) buns for breakfast so I stopped by this place today. Not too sure if I'm entirely pleased with it. 

(+) Pork Belly Buns. Definitely worth a try and it's a good breakfast item if you're craving a savory breakfast. However, for $2.50, the buns are SMALL. I can finish the whole thing with 3 bites.  2 for $5? You can definitely get a better breakfast deal elsewhere for a good wrap or burrito that's more filling.

(/) Vietnamese Iced Coffee. It was meh. Pretty watered down. 

Overall, it was a pretty overpriced breakfast for 2 pork buns and an iced coffee. Maybe I'll come back one day to try the lunch menu!
author: Tram N.

description:
TYPICAL FIDI
(3 stars)

The "chipotle" concept but with "Asian" food. 

-FOOD, ok
-PRICES, ok
-SERVICE, quick
-AMBIANCE, typical FiDi lunch spot 

Bowls, sandwiches, salads, nor wraps caught my attention. Ordered sides because they sound and look more interesting. 

HEIFER STATS. 

STEAMED PORK BUN ($2.50/3) - grilled KuroButa pork belly, pickled cucumbers, scallion and hoisin sauce. It wasn't terrible. It was ok, had better and had worst. Presentation was a mess. Ordered to go and when I unwrapped the foil it looked like it was thrown together, literally. I had to re-situated it's presentation to take a decent picture of it. 

STEAMED VEGETABLE BUN ($2.50/3) - grilled mushrooms and other stuff. This tasted pretty good. Although a healthier option it seemed a bit greasy. 

LOTUS CHIPS ($1.95) - house-made, hand-sliced, lightly salted and crispy. They were tasty but HELLA oily. In my opinion, Portion size is really worth $0.50 if you really were in an Asian country eating "street food"!

Will I be back? I want to try the burrito size rice paper wraps or breakfast. 

Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description:
Hells yes! I was really hungry so unfortunately I forgot to take a pic of my chili garlic tofu wrap but hot damn! I'm pretty sure I could eat another one- not because they're not filling (which they totally are), but because they were that friggin good. Tofu and spices and kimchee and sprouts- it was both hearty and refreshing all at the same time. at $8 a pop this won't break the bank for lunch either. 

So yes, it's like Chipotle but for Asian food. Service is quick/ friendly, and efficient. I went around 1pm and from line to receiving my order it took about 8 minutes.

Our office just moved to the fidi and I see a lot of group trips in our future! I heart you Spice Kit
author: Alyssa J.

description: EVERYTHING on this menu is beyond belief. There is so much to try and the lunch portions are huge. I find myself eating everything that is served in a dish. If you go early is seems like you're in your Auntie's kitchen: prepping and cooking, chopping and stirring, frying and grilling and rice cookers galore. And on a hot day: The a-typical Southeast Asian cuisine comes alive.
author: Papa Dadoo B.

description:
Found this hard piece of plastic in my kalbi beef Korean bowl. 

Other than that it was good. Maybe I'll go back but kinda scared now.
author: Henry L.

description:
3.5 stars - pretty cool Chipotle concept but w/ Asian food. (1) choose your style (2) choose your filling (3) side. Ordered the five-spice chicken korean bowl which came out fairly quickly, esp if you're on a time crunch for lunch.

The five-spice chicken was soo delicious, very flavorful, juicy,& really tender. The beansprout, cucumber&lettuce were refreshing. However, the kimchi rice was pretty bland&tasteless, so I had to douse it in Sriracha to give it some flavor. Improvement for this meal could be on the flavor, which seems to be a pretty common thing from the reviews.

Overall, really like the Chipotle-Asian concept. I would come back here again to try out their other stuff like their wraps/Viet bowl. Def recommend getting the 5-Spice Chicken for your meat!
author: Trina N.

description:
3.5 Stars

Ssam Wrap with Short Ribs

Beef was plentiful, tender and seasoned decently 
Rice was cooked well and added good bulk to the meal but needed a touch more flavor

Get a fork, its hard to eat once it starts to burst at the seams

Wait time to get your food is absurd +20mins after ordering during peak lunch hours so prepare carefully

Overall Thoughts

Ssam wrap is so far the best option there but the wait time isn't justifiable
author: Eddie W.

description:
I walked in to Spice Kit for a little snack before watching a movie at Metreon.  I saw pics of their Pork Belly Buns on yelp and knew I had to try it.  And that's pretty much all I ordered.  They're not as big as ones made at Chairman, but they are cheaper at $2.50 each and actually tasted really good.

Pork Belly Buns
(http://bit.ly/13CKoar)

I started off with two, but then after finishing them off, I went back up to counter and ordered two more.  The Pork Belly really melted in your mouth and had a nice smokey flavor.  They were really addicting!  And at their price and size, I probably would've eaten 8 or 10!

It's a nice lunch spot if you're in the SOMA area and I'd probably go back for try their sandwiches and bowl specials.  But that's if they can't get me to order more Pork Belly Buns!!
author: Rodney H.

description:
I tried Spice Kit for the first time a week ago because it was catered in for a meeting I was attending. Loved it! 

Here are some recommendations for vegetarians:
1. Organic Tofu Sandwich
2. Organic Tofu Wrap
3. Organic Tofu in a Korean Bowl (white or brown rice, sprouts, cucumbers, Tofu)
3. Lotus Chips
4. Ginger Peanut Slaw

I love their tofu. 

If you are a vegetarian, don't get kimchi. It has shrimp. 

Great outdoor area to sit outside. Good for big groups too.
author: Hiral P.

description:
Mix chipotle style building with a Korean/Viet fusion, and what you'll get is an amazing lunch spot that hits you with flavor without the lack of nutrition. This place, tbh, is a godsend. I almost always go here when I'm working from the office/clients downtown because there simply is no other place that I can think of to go to!! This place is ALWAYS on my mind once it hits right around 11:15AM. 

I mean, sure, there's always Ayola, Oasis, Foccacia, Truck Stop, etc. but there really is no other place that delivers high quality "fast food" that tastes unique and amazing. 8 times out of 10, I will make this my go-to spot (the other 2 being the aforementioned places + Muracci's).

I usually get the Five spice chicken wrap (which contains a decent amount of meat) with, and this is key here, a 64 degree egg within. The sous vide'd egg is key here. The wrap, itself, is done into a burrito shape. If you've had kbbq, take the rice wrap you get and supersize it. The meal comes with a bunch of ingredients, but the main pieces are bean sprouts, kimchi fried rice, and lettuce. I might consider getting the bowl next time and asking for a wrap on the side - can't confirm if this is allowed yet though! All this for roughly $9-$10. 

Overall, this is my go-to in the FiDi/SoMa area, hands down.
author: William C.

description: Pretty good stuff, very convenient! I like the range of options and flavors.
author: Medina C.

description: I got the Korean bowl. The rice was a little bland, but the meat was seasoned well. The distribution of meat and sides was unequal (a lot of meat was given).
author: Emily A.

description:
After reading reviews from my trusted fellow Yelpers I had to give Spice Kit a try.  For those of us that do not work in FiDi, I was happy to see that they were open on Saturdays.  

The restaurant appears to be more for take out than dining in, although there is some seating available both inside and outside the restaurant.  I have tried the ssam, the Korean wrap with five spice chicken and the banh mi with the roasted pork.  Both items should be eaten fresh, especially the ssam.

Both items were fresh and filled with a generous portion of meat and vegetables.  The ssam can get a bit messy to eat towards the end as it doesn't hold together well once the juices soak into the wrapper.  However, both dishes were flavorful and satisfying.  Although the items here were a touch on the pricey side, the quality of the ingredients is quite apparent and justifies those prices.

Ordering is fairly easy, with a choice of "style", protein/filling and then any sides or drinks.  The menu isn't extensive, but there are still quite a few combinations to try.  This is a great option for lunch from the usual sandwiches, burgers and salads in the area.

I look forward to returning to try other items on the menu.
author: Melissa L.

description: Nothing special. Ginger slaw was refreshing. The buns were tiny. You can never go wrong with lotus chips though. Nice and crisp.
author: Annie H.

description: We came here because we wanted food in the his area on our walk over the weekend and it is one of the few places open. It was very fast and very good for the price. We got the five spice chicken salad and the five spice chicken Korean bowl and they were both great. They also comfortable seating and a patio area.
author: Justin S.

description: Fan of this spot. The bowls are delicious and affordable for the area.  I usually get the Korean bowl with kalbi beef. .
author: Rod M.

description:
I'm a huge fan of banh mi and buns so my buddy suggested that I try the offerings at Spice Kit when we went out for lunch near his office.  It sort of reminds me of Chipotle for Vietnamese food, so I was excited to give it a try.  The line was long but went quickly, and there's a good number of seats inside and out.  Soon, it was my turn to order.

I decided to go sick and get their five-spice chicken sandwich with a pork bun.  They make it dangerously easy to order so it's pretty easy to overspend.  The sandwich wasn't anything special despite costing over twice as much as some great places in Oakland.  The bun was pretty good, but again, was a little unsatisfying.  I was ultimately left hungry despite spending over $10 for my meal.  It's an interesting concept and the ingredients are certainly higher quality, but I don't think it's for me.  I'll stick with the good stuff in Oakland instead.

Service was fast and friendly, and they've got lots of the rooster sauce on the counter.  It's a popular place for local tech and finance workers and has a price tag to boot.  I couldn't help but feel a little bit taken, but I can also understand why they sandwiches would be as expensive as they are.  Overall, it was ok, but I'll skip it next time.  It just wasn't that special.

Food: 7/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
I am giving this location a one star for the following:  

Last night I went in and asked, "what of your meats are gluten free?":  Girl answered immediately:  "all but the chicken"  She seemed confident, responded immediately, and I felt re assured.  

Today, i am ill, doubled over in pain as I have had zero gluten in years.  

So I call back to this location:  "Which of your meats are gluten free"  A woman on the phone answers. " All but the chicken sir"  .  My response;  " So the beef is not marinated in soy sauce , which of course contains gluten?"  She leaves and comes back one minute later, " Only the pork is gluten free sir."  

Thanks for that, now I have a week of pain and misery to look forward to.
author: Miles C.

description:
I had the ssam with beef shortribs. I was a bit disappointed as the beef was very burned. Also, the ssam was huge and very hard to eat! All the rice kept on coming out and it was a mess to eat. 
The ratio of vegetables to rice to meat was not good and was mostly filled with rice. 
I would go with a bowl or salad next time.
author: Kristy K.

description:
Visited this little shop for lunch since I was craving something Asian that was also near my work place. 

As is the trend nowadays in the "fast casual" restaurant world, this place lets you customize your meal one category at a time a la Chipotle. You start off by choosing how you want your meal prepared either as a sandwich (think banh mi), wrap (think giant spring roll), salad, or rice bowl (Korean or Vietnamese style).

You then move on to choose your filling and toppings, then sides, and finally drinks.

I ordered their Korean bowl with fried chicken as my meat. The chicken was flavorful, crispy on the outside, and tender on the inside. The seasoned kimchi rice and sauce had a nice kick which was balanced out with sides of bean sprouts, cucumbers, and greens. I kinda wished there was more chicken (there were 3) and sauce but the meal was otherwise well-portioned. Then again, I always want more meat... always.

I also ordered the pork belly bun, which was also delish! 

All together my meal came out to be about $10-11, which is great for downtown SF considering the quality and quantity of food you're getting. Definitely gonna come back and try out their other styles and meats!
author: Derick N.

description:
Fast food sandwich outlet with Asian tinge.  Tried vegetarian sandwich here.  It is different from a sandwich that one gets at most places.  The difference is in the fillings (shredded carrots and other veggies) and the sauce (felt like Thai curry).  Being an Asian, the sauce in the sandwich was really a pleasant change for me.  However, the positive taste of the sauce was offset by loaded shredded carrot.

Fast service.  Not much room inside the outlet.  But, there is a nice outdoor sit out area.
author: Srinath S.

description: i love fusion food! i love how there are so many asian fusion shops in the FiDi/SoMa for me to eat during lunch time! don't be fooled by the long lines. the wait time isn't bad. you'll get your meal pretty quick. i ordered the korean bowl with five spice chicken and the pork belly bun. my bowl wasn't really spicy since it includes kimchi rice, but it definitely tasted good! and i'm a huge fan of porky belly buns! they're pretty good but not as good as the ones from Chairman Bao, yum. definitely worth checking out this place for lunch! there's a little bit of indoor seat, but there's also outdoor seating!
author: Sylvia H.

description:
My experience this morning was hardly up to par. 

The young man who helped me at the cash register had glazed over eyes, was unprofessional, and extremely unhelpful. 

I ordered a steamed bun and asked how big the portion was. The cashier responded with a condescending, "I'm not sure if that'll fill you up, two may be better." I then proceeded to request details about the daikon hashbrown, the cashier stumbled upon his words and was unsure what was included in the daikon hashbrown. He was unprofessional, and honestly, seemed high as a kite. He went to the back, picked up a daikon hashbrown and returned to me and shoved it into my face, showing me what it was made of. (gross)

I also ordered a hot soy milk beverage with spices, shown on their website here: http://www.spicekit.com/

The cashier seemed confused and charged me for a soda. He began to pour cold soy milk over a cup of ice, while asking, "This is what you want, right?" I responded, "No, I'd like the hot soy with spices found on your website." His response, "Oh, they got us! Something on our online menu that we don't have!" Are you kidding me? Unprofessional and uncalled for. 

He had the "soda" taken off my card and refunded. 

The manager came over, explained why they no longer had hot soy on the menu. She was kind and helpful. 

We received our steamed buns and daikon hashbrowns, both are dry, running and raw egg, and bland hashbrown, below average food. 

Horrible customer service. Food was boring.
author: Suzy G.

description: Reasonably-priced and healthy lunch option.  It is pretty quick to receive your order, and there's a nice courtyard out the front of the building with seating.
author: Herb G.

description:
Like it for lunch - always looking for another way to eat a salad :) And the tofu was really tasty so I would come back and order that again.

However, my friend had the beef wrap and she would give it 7/10 and unlikely to come back b/c there are other good fusion options for lunch in the city.
author: Karen C.

description:
Definitely one of the places I wish I'd checked yelp and avoided.

I came in for lunch, $13 but that's nbd in FiDi. My entree was their salad w/ marinated tofu. The cashier told me they just 'redid their tofu and it's great'. In reality it's cubes of tofu cut smaller than dice and fried until they're the texture and taste of shoe leather. All you can taste is oil. The salad itself wasn't terrible, jicama was a nice crunch and the dressing was good. 

Onto the pork belly bun. If you've ever had one of these from the Chairman Bao truck you know what a delight it can be.. but that's another review. Spice Kit's buns are ghetto wrapped in aluminum foil like something forgotten in the back of my fridge. When I order pork belly I don't expect it to be light but got a hunk of 65% flavorless fat and 35% flavorless meat. Pork belly should be braised, instead this just had a smear of hoisin sauce on a stale bun. I tossed it after one bite.
author: Emily H.

description: I ordered a burrito yesterday via eat24. I was working from home all day and this burrito was the only contact I had with the outside world. Approximately one hour later I started to feel a scratch in the back of my throat and now, today, I have a full blown cold. I question how well this restaurant practices safe handling procedures of food. This is not something I expect from a restaurant with a 90 health score. Will not be trying my luck at this place ever again.
author: Thomas W.

description: Love this place. I always get the Korean wrap with tofu. A good place for vegetarians!
author: Emily X.

description:
My friend and I came here for dinner.

Casual ambiance: reminiscent of an Asian Fusion Chipotle. 
We had a Korean Bowl and Vietnamese Bowl.

The Korean bowl I had had really flavorful beef (although my friend didn't really like it). The rest of the bowl was rather nondescript.  But I would definitely order again.

I also tried a bit of the VIetnamese bowl but didn't really like it as much.
author: Christine Q.

description: Spice Kit is one of my fav lunch spots. Their vegetarian buns r amazing. Seasoned very well. Wraps are delicious. Today I tried the Korean beef rice bowl. ALSO amazing!!! I usually don't even life beef, but theirs was super tender and seasoned well! Reminded me steakums
author: Elaine S.

description:
I'd say closer to a 3.5 star, 4 stars felt a little high. Tried the korean bowl with beef and a Vietnamese iced coffee.

The kimchi flavored rice was tasty and no complaints about the beef, but the bowl altogether was good, but not great/amazing.  Good enough to try again (korean saam) or if you're in the area and craving korean for $10.

Vietnamese iced coffee, would not repeat. Lots of other better options nearby.
author: Melody T.

description:
I was a bit iffy about trying a Vietnamese place that cater towards more a non-Asian customer-base, though the main reason why I wanted to try this is because a friend highly recommended this place, and I have to say, it's pretty good. I would probably say that this place may be the Asian version of Chipotle, but probably takes a different route than what Starry Kitchen does down in Los Angeles.

Instead of the usual vessels that was listed, I went with the Vietnamese bowl, and to be honest, I didn't read what the description said about the bowl, besides that a lot of vegetables was in this dish that wasn't a salad. For my protein, the default beef choice, which was Korean Beef BBQ. And after seeing so many people rave about the lotus chips, I decided to get an order, except they ran out that day and offered taro chips, which I said, why not?

To coin the term, "Yelp Elite cult" item, I would have to say the taro chips is probably a good definition of it; the taro chips reminded me of a potato chip, with an extra punch of earthiness, and not overall greasy that you would feel sick to your stomach eating more than one serving.

The Vietnamese bowl was a rice bowl, with a choice of pickled veggies, along with a thick fish sauce, kind of reminded me of a vermicelli style dish, except with rice. I give Spice Kit props for making the fish sauce correctly, and not skimping on the flavor. I do get that fish sauce is a bit intimating because of the salty fishy taste, Spice Kit carried that flavor by combing some sweet and spicy flavors to it, like the usual fish sauce you would get from Vietnamese places, except it's a bit more on the thicker side, which complements the rice bowl perfectly.

Probably a go-to place for a quick bit to eat, and the entire meal costing me under $11 is always a plus.
author: Tom T.

description:
they seem to do the same bowl thing inside the cardboard box with some sliced veggies.
ive gotten some cucumber scraps. i mean i guess they dont let anything go to waste but still cmon. the meat was decently flavored. i did taste sugar which is disappointing . i got it through meal-pal otherwise i wouldnt do this place as its way too packed on any given day. 
for their new-ness to the block, they are better than most but could up the ante on the veggies in the box or maybe make a tick box- put more veggies- no more scraps please.
author: A N.

description: My little pillows of pork bun heaven....followed by a refreshing rainfall of Thai iced tea has made this place my new favorite place to go for a quick fix. I love Asian inspired dishes and when I need just a little something something, I can count on Spice kit to bring it !
author: Lauren S.

description:
Vietnamese version of Chipotle, except there are many cheaper and better options nearby. The unique offering here are their giant Vietnamese burritos wrapped in a spring roll; however, all components of their ingredients were subpar.

- Seasoned rice: Made with kimchi. Very bland, couldn't save it with soy suace.
- Braised Beef Short Ribs: Their most popular protein, was pretty good but fatty and not salty enough.
- Pork: Extremely fatty but in a bad way. Not marbled. 
- vietnamese iced coffee: Premade/mixed. So decided not to order

Service was friendly, but there was a disgusting amount of flying gnats hovering over the lunch tables. I like that they are fast, somewhat cheap, and offer cool promos like free coffee druing breakfast. 

I would recommend the following alternatives:
- For Steamed Asian Bun Sandwiches: Chairman Bao
- For kimchi burritos: John's Snack Deli
- For Banh Mi: Soup Junkie, Cafe Dolci
- For Asian Bowls: Bamboo Asia
- For Chipotle Style Viet spring rolls/bowls: Fresh Rolls
author: Jess C.

description: Great sandwiches and protein bowls. Very fast service even when they are busy. Located in a nice plaza with plenty of outdoor seating. Definitely a lunchtime favorite.
author: Stanley R.

description: Everything about this place lets me down. The food is a fixed set box or wrap with different meats but there is no definitive taste to it. It's a very mediocre taste, served in a way that's ok. I wouldn't be going back given the options around the area.
author: Khash S.

description:
Oddly satisfying lunch when I came here last week.  I was going to order my lunch at the JapaCurry truck across the street but the line was huge and  I was going to have a heavy dose of carb heavy rice plus pork tonkatsu plus curry poured on top.   Yeah very healthy...so Spice Kit across the street beckoned to me.   So I jaywalked across Howard St and went in.

The concept is very Chipotle-ish except that this place isn't fake Mexican food.  I decided to go healthy getting a salad with pork and then I splurged on getting a poached egg with my salad.  Yes salad...egg yolk on top of salad.    I'm usually the type of guy who orders his eggs scrambled for breakfast or gets an omelette.  Egg yolk is still something I'm getting used to.  But oddly enough, it worked.  It was like a supplemental dressing to go with the salad dressing.

The total damage came out to just over $9 which is about standard for any decent place in this area.  The salad was filling and the pork was tasty.  Another healthy eating temptation has been hurdled!

I'll probably be seeing Spice Kit more often as my company will likely be moving closer to this intersection soon.  Hoping to try their egg on top breakfast stuff that they serve in the mornings.  If that blows my mind away, then I'll update this  fo sho.
author: Ben H L.

description:
5 stars for buns and rice bowls!  I've been to Spice Kit a handful of times now, and I really enjoy the food here.  Price point is reasonable considering ingredient quality and the service has always been really friendly and helpful, even when there's a crowd.

My all-time favorite dish to order is the pork bun: fatty, melt-in-your-mouth pork belly with a pat of hoisin on a fluffy bun with a slice of pickled cucumber for the perfect acidic contrast.  This paired with the short rib rice bowl, lotus chips, and limeade is my favorite lunch combination. The kimchi rice has just the right amount of spice so it doesn't compete with the flavor of the meat, and the short ribs balance garlic and sweetness perfectly.

They also have a solid breakfast menu.  My favorite is the breakfast bun (bacon, spiced eggs, gingery hoisin), paired with turnip cake and poached eggs.

Overall, Spice Kit is a great casual restaurant offering fast food that is actually well-balanced in flavor and uses high quality ingredients.  Definitely check out if you are going to be in the area (or Palo Alto, as they are starting to expand around the bay).
author: Amanda N.

description: I like the bacon and egg which is daikon cakes. Today is not so good and I can't believe they served this burnt piece of daikon cake. Look at the picture.
author: Vivi C.

description:
The tenderness of the short ribs was nothing short of spectacular. I also liked the kimchi rice. Overall though, I wanted more from my Spice Kit bowl. Chief among my desires - spice! Also, texture and crunch.

I hate bean sprouts and the rice bowl was rife with them. And since they constituted so much of the bulk of the bowl, without them it was lacking.

I'd probably try Spice Kit again, but I wouldn't get a bowl.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Banh Mi - eh (wrong bread, and horribly strange spices in the meat).

Breakfast - great!!
author: Amy O.

description: So glad to see these guys continue to do well. Delicious food that is healthy, and FAST! What could be better?
author: Mimi T.

description: This place has a good Bahn-mi sandwich and the salad with short rib is quite tasty. Go on Wednesday and Friday at lunch for the fried chicken and get it on the salad. This chickens like crack and they usually run out by 1:30
author: James H.

description:
This is one of my go-to-places for lunch. We've had catering from Spice Kit before -- banh mi is absolutely delicious here.

I've had the ssam korean wrap a few times -- don't be fooled - it's actually QUITE filling with all the rice and all. I definitely recommend the five spiced chicken or the beef shortribs.

I had the vegetarian tofu salad one time, and I wasn't a big fan. However, everything else seems pretty good.

Not a big fan of their thai iced tea - there was something about it that was a little off about it.
author: Joanne W.

description:
Culturally confusing. Too much fusion going on. I had the Vietnamese rice wrap with Korean beef BBQ. The choices for the sides were chips. Pretty sure they were like tortilla chips or something. The rice wrap was thicker than I would have liked it to be and there was too much rice and not a lot of veggies. 

The pork buns looked really good though. I wish I had those.
author: Juliana P.

description: Overall, pretty good and clean food. However they messed up on our order more than once so I think this place needs to get their act together.
author: Bill H.

description:
Spice Kit has a great concept, picking your type of bowl/salad and then what kind of protein you would like with it. You are also welcome to add sides such as peanut slaw and pork buns. So in a way, it's almost like an Asian Fusion Chipotle. However to me, the taste is just not exactly on point. Here is what I ordered:

1. Style: Korean Bowl
2. Protein: Kalbi Beef
3. Sides: N/A

The rice was too soggy and it definitely needed some type of sauce to bring it to the next level, except, the shop didn't have red pepper sauce (gochujang) to offer. It can also use a little more sesame oil. 

Overall, it wasn't a bad meal, but that was after I squeeze the *bleep* out of that siracha bottle. I have also ordered a porridge for breakfast the other day, but I personally think for $5.00 with tax, you can offer to give a little more than a tiny CUP of lierally boiled down rice. I definitely wasn't full after that, and I don't even eat that much. The taste of the porridge wasn't bad either, but it just was not awesome. 

Overall, love the concept and modern vibe of the restaurant, I just think taste and quality can be improved. 

Not sure if I will be back around, but since I work around the area, I might give it another shot someday.
author: Luby H.

description: came here for lunch today for the first time. fortunately I came with someone else who ordered so got to see two dishes. I had the pork banh mi and my friend had the five spice chicken bowl. both were great and the price was right ($8.25 for the sandwich or bowl). the sandwich was plenty spicy, I'm not sure if it was the sauce or the jalapanos but I liked it. there were good reviews about the pork belly bun, but I didn't like it. I expect plenty of fat with pork belly, but it should be cooked thoroughly and a bit crispy. this was not. I had to eat around the fatty parts. I might try it again to be sure, but the other buns and lotus chips look good too. there are only a few tables inside, but outside is an office plaza with plenty of seating. I'll definitely be back
author: Bob U.

description:
So it just goes to show that you don't have to be fancy to get my attention. Popped into this place to check it out and was not disappointed. Sparce decor, simple menu but delicious and fresh. Kind of an Asian mish mash of Korean, Chinese and Vietnamese. Choose if you want a wrap, sandwich, salad, or rice plate. Pick your choice of meat or tofu and voila a quick and simple meal that stimulates the taste buds. 
Like I said, not fancy by any means but a great place for a healthy complete meal prepared quickly. Definitely coming back to try other options. Each meal under $10.
author: Matt A.

description:
I remember reading about Spice Kit a few years ago but as I don't work anywhere near the location, I have never had a chance to try it. Fast forward to earlier this week, a friend recommended it and there we went.

I ordered the 5 spice chicken bowl and the korean beef burrito wrapped in rice paper. Both of the dishes were extremely bland. I wanted to like this place but with the lack of flavors in either of their dishes, I don't think I will be back.
author: Betty C.

description: Came before the lunch rush - had the five spice chicken banh mi. Amazing sandwich, with chicken right off the grill, and great service. Will be returning often.
author: Ian Y.

description: I ordered the Korean Style chicken bowl. I was thoroughly impressed with the price (only about $8) and I enjoyed the flavor of the chicken. The serving could've been a bit larger as it didn't quite fill me up all the way but perhaps next time I will order one of their sides! I will definitely be back.
author: John L.

description:
Fast, great tasting food with similar concept to Chipotle, Asian-style. You can't really go wrong here. The price is great, and the food is even better.

I highly suggest checking the Five Spice Chicken, and you'll keep coming back. I've tried it once before, and it seems I come back every week just to get it (it's limited to certain time of the week).

The line is pretty fast as well, and the employees are friendly. Just try it out!
author: Jeff B.

description: Hot foods really burn me up but Spice Kit really got me going with their wraps.  I love their elaborate fillings.  Yeah I was sweating like a moon dog.  Kimchi.  I get it.
author: BanBan T.

description: Place was Pretty empty when we went in. We were in San Francisco for a few days and on our last day decided to go top the Farmers market. We should have just stayed at the pier. We tried ordering the pork belly sandwich (bahn mi) but they didn't have that today..... The only thing that we liked was the the 2 pork belly buns. Needed a little more hoisin in my opinion but over was good. We also ordered the Vietnamese bowl with chicks .... Was kinda gross and only forced ourselves to finish because we were hungry and already walked a mile to get there. Only reason we went there was because the truck stop was closed on Saturday and Sundays, I guess too much competition from people going to Farmers market? Not sure, that would have been nice. Overall, I would not recommend going here and felt sorry that our last meal in town was this place.
author: Cheryl T.

description:
Spice Kit is my favorite "fast food" lunch spot in downtown SF. It really is the "Asian Chipotle"

The short rib ssam wrap is amazing, a mix of savory tender meat, Korean kimchi flavor and hearty rice, and the mochi-like fresh wrap. Such a unique taste and so good. 

The sides of Lotus chips and Pork belly bun were excessive and delicious.
author: Aki N.

description:
it's unfortunate but Spice Kit is not as good as it used to be.

I've gotten these hard rice in my wraps a few times now. I believe it's from scrapping the bottom of the pot/rice cooker. but it's very unpleasant to bite into the hard rice pieces while eating my wrap.

The other thing is the fried chicken special. The last 2 times i ordered it, i was biting into pure fried chicken fat...ICK.
author: Terry C.

description:
Their concept is very straight forward, either choose a wrap, salad or rice bowl. I ended up choosing the rice wrap with beef kali which is really tasty, I could've ask for less rice since I thought there was too much rice but other than that, it was really good! Then I had the vegetarian buns, I think this is my favorite since the shiitake mushroom is soo tasty!

Thai iced tea was the bomb too.. :)
author: Catrina L.

description: Good healthy fast food. My salad was solid, but unremarkable. I would go again no problem.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Come here for their breakfast!! I used to not be a fan of Spice Kit until they had a promotion for free breakfast and that changed everything. Their bacon and egg "Korean" (or wannabe Korean, whateva I ain't hatin') hashbrown is soooo good. The egg is cooked over easy so the yolk drips perfectly onto the crispy outer layer of the hashbrown. Add a little sriracha and it's heaven in your mouth! 

If that doesn't fill you up, I'd get the steamed pork bun with egg. Or another order of the bacon and egg...
author: V L.

description:
Asian street food!

I had the chicken banh mi, which was good, but I had to remove some of the jalapenos so that my lips would stop burning. I also ordered a pork belly bun, which was delicious but a little bit small.

The food is probably a 3.5 itself, but the guy who brought my food gave me lotus chips (interesting and pretty good) on the house, so I'm giving them the extra 0.5 for that.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Spice Kit is what most food trucks in San Francisco are trying to do with fusion flavors, except that it's always in the same place, they definitely take credit card, and apparently they've been around for two years.

Food quantity is filling without being too much; meat quality is high; line, though long at lunchtime, moves very quickly.

The five-spice chicken ssam (aka wrap) is like a mix of Korean (kimchi flavor) and Vietnamese (rice paper wrapping) and I recommend approaching it like you would a burrito made with a very thin tortilla. If you're eating with someone you need to impress for any reason, I'd probably favor a different order or advise you knife and fork it.

The $7-8 price point is right inline with the equivalent Chipotle or Freshroll equivalents, and the experience is too.
author: Stephanie T.

description: Been here couple times for lunch. Close to work which is literally across the street which is convenient. It's pretty tasty, a little pricey, but it's SF. I always get the Korean bowl w/chicken, chips and a fountain drink. It leaves a strong after taste of garlic in your mouth after, but thats what I get. Usually comes out to about $13 or so. I say give it try, it is worth it.
author: Michael S.

description: Bland food. Bad service.  And the tables were sticky and dirty. Who in their right minds would give this place 5 stars?
author: Sandy L.

description:
Tried out this place a number of times.  Reasonably priced food. Very fast. Staff are very friendly. Order, pay, and grab your meal!    
Try to come a little bit earlier, say 11:45 to avoid the crowd lol plus, I love Korean food.
author: Alanda B.

description:
Roast Pork Banh Mi ($7.75) + Pate (+$0.75). I also got a Steamed Pork Bun ($2.95) and Vietnamese Iced Coffee ($2.95). I majored in math, but still was shocked by my $15+ take out lunch bill.

The pork bun needed some work. The pork didn't have much (any) of the smokiness from the grill they talk about on their website and the two small slices were a little skimpy (see pic). I wanted more hoisin just to kick the flavor up a bit and the one super thin piece of pickled cucumber was there for visual effect only.

The banh mi was a disappointing case where the whole was not more than the sum of the parts.

Nice baguette: check!
Generours amount of tasty pork: check!
Creamy pate: check!
Generous amount of veggies: check!

See my pics.

My first bite reaction was "Wow, this pork is tender, but super bland" All I could taste was the (too) strongly pickled carrots & radish and the kick of jalepenos. I tasted some pork by itself and it had some nice spices and flavor, but they were completely overpowered by the other ingredients. The pate also didn't seem worth it for the amount I got. 

The overall flavor profile was way off. I've never complained of too many veggies in a banh mi before, but in hindsight I should have just ditched half or more of the veggies which probably would have helped the taste balance.

The iced coffee also disappointed First it was weak coffee and tasted watery. Second, if you're going to serve these things to go please mix in the condensed milk for me. The flexing compost-able straw was a sub-par instrument for milk mixing, especially when dealing with all of the ice at the same time.

This place has potential, but still has a lot of kinks to work out.
author: Andrew C.

description:
NOTICE TO VEGETARIANS: The "seasoned rice" is NOT vegetarian. It contains fish sauce. They will substitute white rice when requested.

Pros:
- Portions are plenty large
- Friendly staff
- Willing to substitute for vegetarians

Cons:
- No parking
- Limited seating
author: Jana C.

description:
My co-worker is obsessed with this place.
It's a half mile from my work, and it's a nice spot to walk and get away from the office, while also having good food.
The pork bun is ridiculously good. Two of those with a thai iced tea won't fill you up, but they are tasty as heck.
author: Sean H.

description: Had the Korean rice bowl with five spice chicken. Rice was positively stale, flies flying all about the kitchen, kinda gross. Chicken was alright, but the flies definitely put me off. Also very empty- apparently it used to be better. Never coming back.
author: Su Lin Y.

description:
I ordered a short rib ssam and I got a tofu ssam. I didn't find out until I got home. I hate when my order is incorrect and place was empty so I don't understand how this happens. I tried to like it but the tofu just wasn't good; it was hard, chewy, and buried under a mountain of five spice.

Update: The restaurant reached out to apologize and to make amends. Still not happy about the tofu but I appreciate the effort to improve their service, it's by far better than the restaurants and eateries that show indifference to their mistakes. Bumping up one star.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
Yo VIP let's kick it

Spice spice baby
Spice spice baby
All right stop collaborate and listen
Spice Kit is here with its SOMA rendition
Banh Mi grabs a hold of me tightly
Hit with a craving daily and nightly
Will it ever stop yo I don't know
Lunchtime's at 12 and I go

To the extreme I wait in line like a vandal
Nine bucks and change for my lunch I can handle 
Now Banh Mi and Lotus Chips consume
Stops hunger pangs like a poisonous mushroom
Deadly when I eat a dope medley
Anything less than the best is a felony
Like it don't love it but bet I'll gain weight
You better spice it up or I won't stay
Maybe after some time Spice Kit will solve it
Check out the hook while my DJ revolves it

Spice spice baby  scintilla
Spice spice baby  scintilla

(Word to your mother.)

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rog8ou-ZepE
author: Amy C.

description:
As a fan of pig parts I jumped when I saw all of the reviews posted for Spice Kit following its first Monday of business.  So excited I wasted little time and had lunch there on Tuesday.

I managed to get in and get my food order in just before the afternoon lunch rush.  I wanted to try a little of everything so I ordered the Roasted Pork banh mi, a Steamed Pork (belly) Bun, Lotus Chips and a Calamansi Lime-ade.  The wait for food was actually surprisingly fast.

There is seating inside for about 20 with additional seating outside.  I grabbed an indoor seat and dug in.  I started with a sip of the Calamansi Lime-ade, and it was very refreshing.  It's taste was not very lime-like though, but it was definitely citrusy with just a tinge of tartness.

The Steamed Pork Bun (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/spice-kit-san-francisco#jOb0-QlFTTW-R7RNKuuxVA) was very good.  I got two rather large pieces of pork belly in mine.  Thinly sliced cucumber, sweetened hoisin sauce and chopped green onion accompany the meat inside a steamed clamshell bun.  The pork belly was soft and tender and had very good flavor.  

I liked the Lotus Chips (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/spice-kit-san-francisco#_mjb6qgySqyI3jUa3BBlcg) a lot.  I've often had lotus root in soups and stir-frys, but this was my first time experiencing it sliced and deep fried.  More accurately the lotus root is shaved super thin, deep-fried then lightly salted.  The result was super crispy chips that seemed very light even after the frying oil soaked into the root.

The portion of meat in the Roasted Pork Banh Mi (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/spice-kit-san-francisco#kAHTEjgTR6W8Imomg2dpAg) was very generous.  I ordered it with pate which costs extra.  This was definitely one of the pricier Vietnamese sandwiches I've ever had, but aside from the cost I thought this was very good too.  I wasn't very fond of the drippy mayo, but the ingredients were very fresh.  The crunchy vegetables include pickled carrots and daikon, thinly sliced cucumber, jalapeno pepper slices and fresh cilantro.  I do wish there were more of the latter two ingredients especially the cilantro which they seemed to skimp on.
