The pate was quite flavorful as was the roast pork which was moist and tender with nice charred spots on the outside.  The sandwich was served on a fresh, chewy roll that was nice and crusty.

I'll definitely be back to try the beef short ribs and the five spice chicken.  Perhaps I'll even try a Korean wrap.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: This place used to be great but it seems like they've been cutting corners lately.  I also found a piece of pork in my vegetarian tofu salad today, so it will likely be my last time dining here.
author: Megan P.

description:
OK, I was hoping to be dazzled. I wasn't. Gee, all the right signals were there. An owner who was a disciple of Thomas Keller's at French Laundry and per se. A chef from the Ritz Carlton Dining Room. An effort to replicate an Asian street food stand that would make Anthony Bourdain proud. And it's really close to my workplace to boot. Damn. It was merely OK. Granted they're only three days into their operation, but damn.

The stepwise menu is short and sweet. You pick one of three forms - the tradtional Vietnamese bahn mi, a semi-transparent Korean-style wrap called a ssam, or a salad for the carb-averse. Then you choose one of five tantalizing fillings. Despite stiff compettion from personal favorites like the five-spice chicken and the grilled pork belly, I went for the braised beef short rib in a bahn mi for $7.95 (see photo). Jamie W. ordered the chicken in a ssam, also $7.95 (see photo).

Both of us received little cubes of marinated meat flecking the filling. Mine was a bit better since the flavor of the beef came though, but Jamie's was more like a burrito wanna-be with barely-there chicken ovewhelmed by the lettuce and rice. A good dousing of the bottled chili sauce helped flavor both up immeasurably. I also had the $1.95 Ginger-Peanut Slaw, which I liked since it had a heavy ginger taste counterbalanced by the crunch of the pulverized peanuts (see photo). Just wish the serving was a bit bigger for the price.

I'm sure I'll be back because proximity is important to me, and the service was friendly. I went around 8:45PM this evening, so there was no line. I can well imagine waiting and meeting colleagues accidentally as I was thinking I was talking behind their backs. I hate when that happens. There isn't much seating in the place, a few tables for two on the side, a couple of counters in front, so expect to take it to go.

FOOD - 3 stars...the right elements but not gelling yet...the bahn mi is too bready, the ssam too ricey...the stars will align of these days
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...honestly looks like a fro-yo shop rather than a street food stand
SERVICE - 4 stars...friendly and helpful
TOTAL - 3 stars...I'm pulling for this one to improve and work over time...I'm getting tired of Cafe Venue!
author: Ed U.

description:
The food: the banh mi sandwich and the drinks get 4 stars, BUT the ssam and pork bun were a disappointment for me. I think ratings will vary depending on what u ordered, and how well the food is prepared. I expected better from former French Laundry and Ritz Carlton cooks.

This Asian (Viet-Korean-Chinese) concept is modeled after the Chipotle chain, but prices are slightly more expensive. They have a list of proteins ("ingredients" - chicken, beef, pork, tofu) that u can order as a ban mi sandwich, a Korean burrito, or a salad. Plus a few side dishes and asian drinks. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/t6ad76DjjInmQAiMn_k0rQ/l

The Thai iced tea was perfect, not overly sweet, well made. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/DMpFLDIqJNzp9bvMPO5vXw/l

The sandwich was good overall. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/wD_zm-2p9aY3tUAUF0WZUA/l Good crunchy baguette bread, the pickled veggies were crunchy but a bit mild for me, and the meat was tender and flavorful. Only one of the basic banh mi ingredients was missing: the liver pate - it costs 75 cents EXTRA (nickel and dime schemes annoy me). I guess people who dislike pate won't mind this. Why short change customers? Most banh mi shops in SF include pate by default, no extra charges to jack up the price. Maybe they think that downtown office workers don't know any better.

This ssam was like a Korean burrito - Korean meat, kimchee, veggies and rice wrapped in Viet rice paper, http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/28nYWTQOqaKFDzQR3hYdfQ/l, though the one I got was very poorly wrapped. It was open on the bottom, almost fell apart as soon as I tried to lift it. You're supposed to eat ssam with your hands (real ssam is like the Chinese lettuce cups dish). Clearly the kitchen staff needs more practice or better training. There was a lot of kimchee, not enough meat, and the rice was a little overcooked. This was just their first week open. Not impressed. I suggest that they offer a rice plate option instead, it'd be easier for the kitchen staff to assemble.

The pork bun (2.95 or 2/$5) was another let down. The meat portion was minimal and that pork belly was soggy and thin. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/-1w_AE5ViUPY5z5He_mqlA/l Hoisin sauce was fine, but the tiny portion looked really sad. It reminded me of that famous "Where's the Beef?" commercial. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ug75diEyiA0 My suggestion to improve that: fry that pork belly (thicker cut, and careful not to overcook it), so u get a slightly crispy texture, saltiness, and better contrast. AND put more meat on that bun!!

This food concept has good potential, so I hope that this review is helpful in pointing out the issues that need to be addressed.

Other side dishes on the menu are Lotus chips ($1.50, called "renkon chips" elsewhere) and a ginger-peanut slaw ($1.95).

I did recognize that all the meats I sampled were very tender and moist. That's because this is the first quick service shop in SF that uses sous-vide techniques to slow-cook their meats in vacuum bags (normally only found at fine dining restaurants).

Napkins, plastic utensils and sriracha hot sauce are available next to the soda machine.

This somewhat hidden shop is located on the open plaza of the Orrick Building. The outdoor tables are a nice dining option on sunny days. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/0X--SN_XOmRAkljM1WZe3w/l

Hours: M-F 10:30am-8pm; Sat 10:30am-3pm
Closed Sundays
author: Luis C.

description: Stopped by in the morning wanting to try a banh mi, but was disappointed to find they didn't serve it until lunch time. The steamed pork buns are kind of small for $5.. you could probably go somewhere else and get something more filling, but the flavorful mango lassi parfait is worth trying!
author: Kim D.

description:
There's Chipotle...there's Tava....and there's Spice Kit!

To put it simply, Spice Kit is the Asian and Korean-version of Chipotle. You can order your meal in the style of Chipotle...expect with Korean meats and other foods. :) Came here for lunch with with a friend, and I got the salad with beef :) You can order a wrap, sandwich, salad, etc. A good nomnom for lunch in the city :) There's plenty of seating outside (both shaded and in the sun), so if the weather permits, definitely swing by Spice Kit for lunch and enjoy Mother Nature while you fill you belly.
author: Rachel C.

description: Never would have found this place without Yelp. Just moved to the area and so glad I found this gem. It's not knock your socks off completely new type of food but it's exactly what I want. Good Banh mi ingredients, fresh food and a reasonable price. I'll be back quite a bit
author: Austin L.

description:
Spice Kit redefines a grab and go lunch downtown.

Let me highlight my favorite items!

Korean Short Rib Wrap: this is more like a giant fresh burrito! It's wrapped in soft rice paper and stuffed with a meat of your choice, kimchi, lettuce, sprouts and rice. I always ask for less rice and more lettuce/sprouts. The wrap is huge but with just a little bit of rice, I have no problem finishing the wrap and not falling into severe food coma. The vegetables are so fresh and the flavors in this are so good.

Lotus Chips: Makes me feel healthier because i'm eating "lotus root" but yeah, I know, it's just like potato chips. Really fresh, cripsy and good!

Five Spice Chicken Salad: Their salads here are HUGE! I am always stuffed after finishing a whole salad. Portions are great, meats are seasoned well and toppings in the salad are plentiful and interesting.

I highly recommend this place! There are only 4 or 5 tables, so I wouldn't recommend coming here for a sit down meal, although you could. This place is perfect for a week day lunch or grab and go dinner after work.
author: Gloria C.

description:
A bit conflicted about this place, probably would give 3.5 stars. I've really only had their breakfast.

The breakfast steamed buns I thought were kind of whatever. A bit small for my liking. To be honest, I'm not a big fan of steamed pork buns anyway, so your mileage may vary.

The bacon and egg I thought was also kind of whatever. The hashbrown it came with was super heavy, and the bacon and egg were alright I guess.

What I'm really a fan of is the rice bowl, or really rice porridge. I think they make it really well here, they add all sorts of garnishes that really bring out a lot of flavor. The egg and Chinese sausages are also a really nice touch. My girlfriend loves this and gets it all the time. It's not a LOT of food for $5, but I think it's decent for breakfast.
author: Wynn C.

description:
Let me start off by saying... I LOVE CONGEE / PORRIDGE / GRITS / OATMEAL. 

So when I stumbled upon this place on my way to work in the morning - still sleepy from my nap on the transbay bus, I was extreeeemely excited to see this place open for breakfast and boasting a rice bowl with "savory rice porridge, chinese sausage, crispy garlic, ginger, peanuts and soft egg" -- all for $4.95. YESSSSS Please!

What a great way to start the morning! I especially LOVED the fact that they included the egg in there as well... 

This place was aptly subtitled as Asian Street Food - it reminded me of porridge the way we eat it in Thailand. YUMMERS.
author: Nicha K.

description:
OMFG!!!!

Rolled in here on a Friday and got their special item the - FRIED CHICKEN!!! (Only available Wednesdays and Fridays).

Holy Bajeezus!  3 gorgeous chucks of boneless skinless thighs in a crispy but light breading - oh, so perfectly spiced.  The kind of spice that gets your nose running, ever so slightly, but not so hot that you you're gunna regret it.  Now,  I'm a 'mild' kind of girl so this was just right. . . You glutons for punishment out there, feel the need to kick it up a notch.  You'll have no issues - just grab hold of one of the many Siracha bottles and go friggin nuts. 

Same concept applies: Salad, Bowl Sandwich and Wrap. .  I got the salad with the mango, jicama and peanuts. . .can we say rockin'!?!  The sweetness of the dressing cuts the spiciness of the chicken nicely.  My personal preference, but whatever floats your boat.  Just seems its the best way to showcase that mama jama FAAA-RAYED chicken!  

Chirpin out!
author: Sofia S.

description:
I got to try Steamed pork bun $2.95/ or 2 for $5.  From Kurobuta pigs.  Thanks Finney Friday FREE Stuff & Spice Kit!

It took about 5 minutes to make, then I got them brought to my table.  Each bun is only about 5 bites.  2 chunks of pork, tiny amount of cucumber & hoisin sauce on steamed fat buns.  I liked it.

Go try it if you're in the SOMA area: 1st St & Howard, next to Peet's Coffee.

Hrs:
Sun Closed
M-F 10:30-8
Sat 10:30-3
author: Ann L.

description:
Ive been here for lunch, the line goes out the door often. It's more of a grab to go place as there is limited seating, but they are delicious. I've also been here a few times around 6pm, and they are dead empty around then, so the food comes very quick. 

I've tried the five spice chicken and the roasted pork on ssam wrap and in a bowl. I recommend getting ssam over any other because the banh mi is quite small and doesnt fit everything very well. The bowl seems like a good choice, but you can't get the rich taste all at once compared to the ssam wrap. 

PS. I love how they have ~30 sriracha sauces lined up at the side counter for customers to use : P
author: Elisa L.

description:
Perhaps because my visit to Spice Kit was so long anticipated that I had higher hopes for this eatery. Spice Kit is just okay, solid 3 stars.

My lunch date and I both read that the pork belly buns were a must try, and I agree they were.  However, it was tiny.  I guess I shouldn't expect all buns to be "Chairman Bao sized".  That said, it pork belly was well seasoned.

I ordered a Rice Bowl with beef.  I was super underwhelmed.  The ingredients were fresh and well balanced (the right amount of each ingredient) - kimchi, rice, marinated bean sprouts, cucumbers, lettuce, and their signature Ssäm sauce. It was lacking heat for my taste.

Will I go again?  Likely though it's small venue with few seats inside. Maybe I'll try a bahn mi as my dining companion quite liked it.
author: Marie B.

description: Get here before 12:30....the line gets long.  Really like this place.  The set up feels like a Vietnamese version of Chipotle (pick a type of meal - wrap, bowl, salad; pick a protein).  Probably not as many choices for how you build your meal -- the items are mostly predefined, but that makes the whole process go much quicker as there's less customization.  And there's less need for picking what goes in your bowl as they are pretty well designed to begin with.
author: Alan R.

description:
Spice Kit is set up simplisticly and efficiently. the open kitchen is behind the register. you order at the register and you get your order within minutes.

protein choices: five spice chicken,  beef shortrib, roasted pork, vegetarian(tofu), grilled pork belly

various eating vehicles:  banh mi, ssam(korean wrap), salad or bowl

eats: beef shortrib bowl(7.95)
-tender beef cubes marinated with some salad and a bunch of  marinated rice. looks like fiesta rice with paprika coloring. ok taste.   3.5 stars
lotus chips(1.5)
-very thin lotus roots fried too crispy, tastes a little burnt
3 stars

foodnotes:
-spice kit is in expansion mode, more locations soon
-tasty gourmet eats with quality ingredients. rates 4 stars.
-quick courteous service, fair price.
-will need to try more options. 
-upgrade possible if food execution is perfecto
author: Victor G.

description:
Amazed to find a food spot like this in downtown Embarcadero area.  They have a similar menu lay-out to Chipotle in that you have STEPS 1-2-3 

Step 1 - Do you want a sandwich (banh mi), wrap, or bowl?
Step 2 - What type of meat do you want? Five spiced chicken, beef shortribs, roasted pork, vegetarian, grilled pork belly?
Step 3 - SIDES!  Do you want pork buns, lotus chips, or ginger-peanut slaw?

DONE!

Finally, you can choose a drink and you're good to go.  Such a great concept, very efficient and you can get an entire Step 1, 2, 3 AND a drink for a total of $15 which is just about right downtown getting food to go.  You can exclude the sides and the drink and it's a very reasonable $9.  Can't beat it.  Plus it's different from your regular joints in the area.

Keep in mind, it's a bit spicy so please let them know ahead of time that you want it MILD or not spicy at all or else you might have a tongue on fire while at work!

OPEN ON WEEKENDS!  I came here on a Saturday and they were open.  If you've got a long Saturday to push through, this place can definitely brighten up your day.
author: Sandy L.

description:
After many years of avoidance, I decided to give banh mi another chance.  

I'm glad I did.  This place serves it in big portions.  With more meat.  It's like they know Americans eat a lot.  

A banh mi with five spice chicken had a fresh roll, and more chicken than I expected.  It was tasty and entertaining, and I felt satisfied when I finished it.  

I had a side dish, which was nice but unnecessary.  Ginger peanut cole slaw, and except for the zingy ginger taste, I'd say it was pretty ordinary cole slaw.  

It was the sandwich that made my day.  

5-spice chicken banh mi $6.95
ginger-peanut slaw          1.95
bag (we're in SF)               .10
tax (see above)                 .77

Grand total for VN lunch
(don't tell me there's no
inflation)                          $9.77

(Notice the city bag charge is also taxed.)
author: David D.

description: When I first heard about this place I was really really excited and eager to try it! I mean come on, giant spring rolls?!! Yes please! I came hear late one afternoon with my sister and we shared the kalbi beef spring roll and it was huge like burrito size.  I thought the meat was good but I think the choice of fillings were a little off. When I think spring roll wrap I think cold or room temp but this was a hot leaky mess.  It was really hard to eat because of the thin wrap and everything kept falling out and juice was oozing out of the bottom.  The idea is there but I think with their choice of ingredients a regular tortilla would've been better.  The wrap came with sliced cucumber, lettuce, bean sprouts, and kimchi fried rice along with your choice of meat.  I just thought it would've been more of a spring roll than a Korean style burrito. Now that I've tried it I don't think I have a need to come back
author: Linz C.

description:
Came here after my boyfriend raved about it. 

I ordered the pork bahn mi with pate on a roll and he ordered the chicken bahn mi on a roll, and we shared the pork buns. 

Pork in the buns have a distinct flavor that didn't pair well with the added sauce. Bahn mi was very blah, the pickled carrots were too salty and vinegar-y. Pate didn't have a distinct rich flavor either. 

Overall, was not impressed. Definitely a very commercialized place trying to serve bahn mis. Probably would not come back for a bahn mi or recommend to friends :( however I would come back to try the ssam and a few of the breakfast options
author: Siv L.

description:
So I headed to Spice Kit out on Howard and 1st Street with some of my coworkers for lunch.  I've never been here before, so it was new to me.  But from what I've heard from most people, this place is just A-OK.

The place, overall, is small.  Not too much room in there or maybe all the people at lunch time made it seem more crowded than what it really was.  Either way, I was pretty crammed in there.  I decided to have the Vietnamese bowl with lemongrass pork ($8.25 before tax).  This place is definitely Asian Fusion, since the bowl I had was not the most authentic.  It's good, but nothing compared to a traditional rice plate at your local Vietnamese restaurant.  The amount of rice is very little too, wish I had more.  The pork is not char-grilled BBQ pork, but was pretty good still - very tender.  The plate comes with rice, meat, and shredded carrots, cucumber, and I believe some shredded radish.  There were no jalapenos in my bowl.  Not sure what to call the sauce in English, it's fish sauce, but fish sauce + other ingredients like garlic, water, some red peppers, etc...  It's not spicy for those of you who never had this type of sauce or dish before.

They have other stuff too, like korean bowls, banh mi sandwiches, wraps (in rice paper), salad bowl, steamed white pork buns. etc...  It's pretty unique asian fusion menu,  But overall I would say this place is just A-OK!
author: Kevin N.

description:
really really good fast Vietnamese food.  Hard to believe I can get such a good Vietnamese pork salad for only $7.  Great deal on lunch.

The quality of ingredients is top-notch.
author: Madison W.

description:
Casual Carpool's SF drop off location is conveniently right in front of Spice Kit.

... and Spice Kit conveniently has a simple, but good breakfast menu. http://www.spicekit.com/media/uploads/breakfast_menu.pdf 

They open at 7am and have Vietnamese coffee & iced tea (which are personal hangover cravings of mine). The steamed buns I had this morning said they contained applewood smoked bacon, but what I got were fatty pieces of pork belly. UPGRADE! Two of those things were $5.43 after tax and while they were tasty, they weren't very filling. 

My $4 breakfast bagel by my work gets the job done much better, but Spice Kit was still a fun try.

*There was no line, the staff were really nice (especially for 8:30am), and they take cards- no problem, no sass.
author: K M.

description:
I'm always a bit skeptical about lunch joints in FiDi, particularly ones recommended to me by one of my coworkers whose taste doesn't seem to align with mine. Perhaps my expectations were low or just right, but I was pleasantly surprised by Spice Kit.

I ordered the Five Spice Chicken salad. Everything tasted fresh. The chicken was well spiced and juicy. The taste combination of the radish and the mango and sesame vinaigrette all meshed together. I'm on the fence about the peanuts: they didn't ruin the salad, but they detracted from the lightness that could have been...
author: J J.

description:
Came to Spice Kit after seeing the place on "Unique Eats" on the Cooking Channel.  There was no line when I went on Monday at around 1:30pm.  Guess I beat the lunch rush?

You can find Vietnamese sandwiches everywhere, so although the sandwiches here do look tasty, I wanted something unique and stumbled upon the "Ssam" wrap--basically a kim chi burrito with rice paper instead of a tortilla-- with 5-spice chicken.  All the flavors packed a great kick: the chicken was moist and grilled to perfection, the seasoned rice soaked up all the the wonderful juices, and the lettuce, thinly-sliced cucumbers, and marinated bean sprouts provided the crunch.

My only criticism is the rice paper.  I ordered the item to-go and walked about 10 minutes to my office.  The outside wrap was either blanched too much initially or the heat from the meat steamed the to-go container to the point where the wrap was really soft and starting ripping apart.  The idiot in me tried to initiate emergency procedures by wrapping the bottom with a napkin, but then the napkin just stuck to the wrapper.  The moral of this story is I ended up taking it apart anyways and eating it with a fork.  Still gooodd.

Will come again to try the lotus chips and other meats.
author: Ronald T.

description:
FRIED CHICKEN FRIDAYYYY!!

I love love love their chicken Bahn Mi! I love it more on Fridays when we can get it fried! Yea its more expensive, so?!

pork buns are yummy. thai tea is yummy. limeade is great!
author: Olivia B.

description:
Korean Vietnamese fusion. I brought my Vietnamese friend here for the lols. I'm Korean.

It's hard to get a balanced meal for lunch, and Spice Kit does a pretty decent job at it.

The Korean bowl with beef works for me. Although I have a hard time believing it is short ribs, but the meat is at least tender. The flavor combo works for me, I'd prefer more spice. And having some vegetables to eat is always a plus for me.

The Vietnamese bowl... not so much. This is a classic example of "just because you can... doesn't mean you should." There is something fundamentally missing, and the over abundance of carrots, cucumbers with the lack of daikon and cilantro just doesn't work with balance of things.

The Ssam (wraps) is interesting. It's the basically the bowl wrapped in rice paper.

I see the lotus chips... I need to come back and try them.
author: Brian Y.

description:
Definitely not so impressed with Spice Kit.  It's kinda like Chipotle, in that you can choose a bowl or wrap, your type of meat, and any sides (pork buns).  The only problem is that their wraps are really... not great.

The last time I came here, I ordered the beef wrap.  Think of a Vietnamese spring roll, but huge.  That's exactly what their wrap is.  It's a burrito with that see-through coating, which is quite a strange texture.

The wrap is quite easy to break.  The contents inside of my wrap started flying around everywhere as I was biting into it.  The meat inside was not really tender, or special.  Most of the times when I'm eating a wrap, I look forward to biting into the meat.  With this wrap, I kinda wanted to avoid it.

Overall, come to this restaurant if you want something fast, but don't expect much.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Pork belly buns are pretty decent. Pork belly isn't as tender as it should be but when you're starving and craving for some, it'll definitely do. 

The boys loved the big burrito spring roll. They said it was like an Asian chipotle burrito
author: Victoria P.

description:
I'm a very matter-of-fact person and will get straight to the point.

1. Order the saam with either beef short ribs or pork belly. It is incredible. I don't even like wraps and this was heavely to me.

2. Do NOT get the pork buns. After experiencing Momofuku's pork buns (in NY) I have been wishfully hoping I would find a place like that here. Nope. Not here. They are NOT worth your money.

3. Lotus chips are cool just for the experience...for just $1.50 I think it's worth it just to enjoy the cool shapes they are in, flavor is not anything special.

People have compared this to Chipotle. Nothing like it. Chipotle has that mass manufactured / sloppy feel to it. This is much better.
author: Chrissy H.

description:
Is it just me or does their daikon hashbrown in the "Bacon and Egg" breakfast item not actually have any daikon in it? I hate being lied to...

The rice bowl/porridge, however, is legit, and the steamed buns are decent also.

The chicken, beef and pork are usually a little too salty, the portions are generous, but I'm still not over the daikon hash brown not having [much, if any] daikon in it.
author: Judy K.

description: This spot rocks!! Everything on the menu is tasty.  I usually go for the fried chicken on Wednesdays and Fridays but you really can't go wrong here.  The people that work here are top notch!  They always seem happy even when I request special accommodations.  I've been going here for over two years. If you want high quality food, fast and friendly service then this is the place for you!
author: Pat D.

description:
I ordered a Banh-mi and it was really just ok.  

This is a quick, get in and get out kinda a joint, with very little sitting room. 

I had it with the five-spice chicken and the chicken was very flavorful and at times the jalapenos were a little over powering.  But what dropped stars for me was the bread.  The essense of a good banh-mi has to be crunch soft bread.  And the bread was tough and rubbery. 

I might give the wrap or a salad a try, but I won't be getting the banh-mi again.
author: Maggie F.

description: I recently got a new job in the city and I love the Spice Kit! The veggie bowl is my absolute favorite! They are very kind when they wait on you and the prices are pretty good for the city! I highly recommend Spice Kit!
author: Sandra P.

description: I tried spice kit for the first time using mealpal and have been so satisfied with every lunch here. Great portion size, really wonderful healthy options with a ton of flavor. Perfect place for a filling, delicious and guilt free lunch. Recommend the tofu box!!
author: Alexa C.

description:
I don't mind paying more for a banh mi that's made with better ingredients, and value wise, I think Spice Kit delivers. You can taste the quality of their ingredients. However, there were sandwich construction issues.

The set up is reminiscent of Chipotle (probably not what they want you to think of) where you choose your protein and then the style (bowl, wrap/ssam or banh mi). They're very efficient, even faster than Chipotle. It took me 4 minutes to get my banh mi and that included toasting the baguette.

* Roasted pork banh mi ($7.75): the toasted baguette is light, crispy, soft on the inside - very nice. The sandwich was stuffed with an ample amount of meat and veggies (so much so that it's hard to eat/things fall out). Big tender pork cubes were delicious and warm, with grilled flavor and some very enjoyable fatty bits. The pickled carrots and daikon were very tangy (I'd prefer them a bit sweeter) and the cucumbers were not crunchy (sliced too thin). The bread gets slightly soggy quickly. I added housemade pate which was good but bland. Mayo, jalapenos and cilantro were included.

The abundance of roasted pork and quality ingredients make this a better than average banh mi.
author: Lolia S.

description: I ALWAYS get the pork sandwich with pate and no jalapenos. So so delicious! Service is fairly quick and the line goes by pretty fast. Oh and for breakfast I'm aways satisfied with the porridge. If you're not a meat eater, tofu sandwiches are available.
author: Grace L.

description:
Pork belly bun. YUM! I get this only on Fridays because the fat on the pork belly is only acceptable at the end of the week. It's so worth it though! Reminds me of the Chairman food truck bao - a must try! 

My coworkers always get rice bowls and really enjoy them. I'll definitely be back to try it!
author: Mimi V.

description:
Wednesday is apparently the day to go, because it means boneless fried chicken over kimchi fried rice. Otherwise, I know nothing about the menu. I went during lunchtime, so of course it was super packed. I think it's pretty awesome that they have a bunch of different kinds of Asian food and drink. I can't think of another time when I can get calamansi juice with kimchi fried rice and boneless fried chicken.

The service was quick and efficient, and the portions were all right. It was tasty, and if I worked where my boyfriend worked, I'd see the point of visiting every Wednesday. Since I'm a bit more of a walk away, I don't see myself heading over just for the chicken unless I'm going to meet up with him, but I'll probably give them a try on another day.
author: Robbin A.

description: Wtf ? Came here for lunch from class on Saturday - OMG I am so disappointed ... Just crappy ! I use to frequent this place on the weekdays and was great! Service on the weekend not engaged ordered lotus chips and they gave me taro chips without informing me - worst part is I bought a banh mi sandwich and the cucumbers carrots and cilantro was freaking soggy not fresh as it usually is - so pissed I spent 12 bucks and will end up giving it to the homeless! I want my money back !
author: michelle r.

description:
Don't get the wrap. There's barely any meat, and they seem to think that rice paper is thick enough to hold together a burrito-sized spring roll. It's not. Your wrap will crumble and fall apart like any hope you had of having a satisfying meal. Don't get me wrong; the contents are pretty good, it's just really annoying when the wrap falls apart after the first bite. 

My friends got the sandwich and bowl and said that it was good, and the proportions seemed like they were much better than in the wrap. If you must try this place, I would recommend getting the bowl.
author: Raymond Y.

description: Got the pork buns deal ($5 for 2) , and it was a reasonable amount for lunch. They were nice and let me sit in the place and work for a while, and Peet's next door has free WiFi which is a plus!
author: Anna L.

description:
Read reviews on yelp before I came here for lunch so I expected an Asian style chipolte, and it is just like an Asian style chipolte. I had no problem with that at all! 

I ordered the short ribs bowl and it was delicious. The rice is seasoned in a light bibimbap sauce, with a side of bean sprouts, cucumber, and lettuce. Came out to be $8.63. 

I like to know prices before I come to a restaurant so I'm prepared. Couldn't find it online but here it is: 

Chicken $6.90
Short ribs $7.95
Roasted Pork $7.75
Vegetarian $6.75

Steamed pork belly buns $2.95 or 2 for $5
Lotus chips $1.95

You can get your lunch/dinner in the form of a viet sandwich, a korean ssam, a salad, or a bowl. If you think about it, it's really the same price at Chipolte more or less. So it's really not too bad price wise. It is a little weird that the price of a viet sandwich would be so pricey compared to the ones you get at Saigon or Lees, but I avoid it by not ordering it -- hence the bowl. 

Sriracha on the side is a great second thought to add some spice in your food!
author: Jeannie L.

description:
Ehhh...spent 15 bucks and was disappointed and still hungry. The beef short rib needed more beef for an 8 dollar sandwich and the meat needed to be hot. Flavor was okay, but nothing fantastic.

The pork bun was barely warm and disappointing. I am used to momofuku buns and I wasnt at all expecting this to be on that level. But lets be honest, the buns should be freshly steamed, otherwise they arent any good. The charm of the buns should be that they are fluffy when fresh, when they are pre-prepared and just sit there they become a little sad and stiff.

And the meat itself was disappointing because its "grilled". For pork belly to really have that juiciness and tenderness it needs to be roasted. 

I realize its a lot of work (i make my own at home) but honestly you could roast them in advance in huge slabs and cut and reheat on a flat top and would be much better than what they are serving at spice kit.

Not sure if i got them on a bad day, but it appeared that they sort of have an assembly line making the food so it got cold before it got to me.

I'll update my review after i try them again.
author: Ken W.

description: First time here!  Had the Korean Bowl with Kalbi and Lotus chips (but they ran out and had taro chips instead).  All were delicious; the Kalbi was tender and delicious! The Kimchi rice wasn't too spicy and went very well with the cucumbers and bean sprouts (and I usually don't like bean sprouts).  Definitely will come back here!
author: Ian T.

description:
I took my old boss here for lunch, both of us had a chicken saam, lotus chips and the steamed bun.

My boss like this saam better than the last place he tried one (He did not provide a name) and was very surprised about the lotus chips and steamed bun.

Now that I work about 3 blocks away....
author: Brandon W.

description: Nothing is better than a bowl of warm rice porridge on a cold SF day! I love the rice bowl here because it has a poached egg swimming on top. I can eat this all day! Be careful, sometimes, it gets a bit too salty to eat, but usually, it is awesome!
author: Rosie M.

description: Mediocre food.  The location is convenient, the food is not very expensive, but the food trucks which park across the street are always better.  The pork bun I had was tiny, fatty, and lacked flavor.  And the bahn-mi sandwich with the spiced chicken was lacking insides- poorly balanced and very 'bready', and was simply boring.  Unlikely that I will be back.
author: Andy S.

description:
Struggling on what to eat for lunch?  Want something interesting yet simple? Spice kit is your place!  Small menu with great choices for a quick bite!  

Say what?  Korean burrito??  Bimibap wrapped in rice paper? SIgn me up please!!!!  Definitely will be coming back here to try out their other sandwiches... Especially their Banh Mi.
author: Nho C.

description:
My coworkers suggested Spice Kit for lunch. I had leftover pasta, so I opted to go for the non-nuked version of lunch. My coworkers said that there was a huge line out the door when they arrived (around 1pm). I ordered a short rib beef Vietnamese sandwich w/ pate. My sandwich did not come with pate but came with some really intense pickled vegetables and a massive amount of what appeared to be mayo. There were chunks of beef and some peppers which gave it that kick. The beef kept falling out and mid way into my sandwich it got really dry and inedible. I had to toss it and eat an ice cream sandwich to make up for it. 

I'm a huge judge of Vietnamese food and to me, this wasn't authentic but something else. Something totally different. It should not even be graced with the title of Vietnamese sandwich. Best part about it was the bread which was pretty crunchy and light.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
I'm surprised by a lot of the negative reviews for this place.  Every time I have been here the ingredients have been fresh and well prepared and the service has been stellar. It has a great location in the south financial and even at it's busiest times the wait isn't anything crazy. The staff has been friendly and the owners are pretty cool dudes. I usually go for the chicken saam wrap which is uuuhhhhhhmazing! Such a clever and creative way to gimme tasty noms. I could probably eat one everyday. I would absolutely recommend this place for anyone who isn't afraid of eating something they're not used to.

Real talk: How are people complaining about the price of this place? "Uhhhhh I had to pay eleven dollars for a sandwhich and a side." Dude that is a ROUGH LIFE you have going for yourself there. You sound like you've been getting lunch in San Francisco all of NEVER if you think that's an outrageous price... I'm lucky if I can keep lunch under twenty just for myself when I'm out with clients. Seven bucks for a dank ass wrap is nothing but clutch. Plus it's not like it's shitty quality or everything. Food is fresh, service is friendly, AND THEY HAVE ABOUT TWELVE FULL SRIRACHA BOTTLES. I rest my case.
author: Cooper J.

description:
This is the perfect Friday lunch spot and here are the reasons why:

1.  When it's Friday I feel like I deserve to ingest an unlimited number of calories.  Enter the five-spice chicken bowl.

2.  It's Friday so who cares if you have a food coma after lunch?

3.  It's just legitimately awesome.  

4.  Filling your own mini cups of siracha is about as productive as I can get on a Friday.

Screw it.  It doesn't need to be a Friday to go to Spice Kit.  Just go.  And enjoy.
author: Amy N.

description:
I am in search of my Financial District Banh Mi place. This is stop #2 so far. Yesterday was Little Saigon Deli on Steuart. 

So today me and a coworker walked over a couple blocks to this joint. It's set right in a nice spacious plaza by Peet's coffee in what I consider the "techier" side of FIDI.

The menu is sort of a step by step process, Pick sandwich, pick sides, etc. 

I ordered the Pork Banh Mi sandwich, with no Pate. I added on the Pork Belly Pork Bun sandwich and a Thai Iced Tea. The total was around $12. The pork buns are 2 for $5, so I probably got a lesser value by only getting one. I didn't save my receipt though.

We sat at the bar looking out the window at the sunny plaza and Kara's Cupcakes truck across the street. 

I ate the Pork Bun first. The pork belly slide right out and I inhaled it on my first bite. It was delightful. I then ate the rest of the bun filled with sauce. Also a very tasty bun. I wish my pork belly was crispier though. 

Then I went for the Banh Mi. A nice crispy bun, flakey pork meat and very tasty ingredients inside. I loved the flavor all around on it. I would like to have had more jalapenos and will ask for more next time I go there. This was definitely better than Little Saigon Deli. 

The Thai Iced tea was typical and good.

I think overall I would go back here, but think it a bit pricey for the penny pinching luncher like me.
author: Mack L.

description:
I was so looking forward to a vietnamese chipotle, but it wasn't as great as expected. I ordered the tofu wrap, which I have mixed reviews about.

The good: The tofu. It's marinated really well and they pile it on. They also put a good amount of bean sprouts in the wrap. The taro chips are really good too!

The bad: The wrap itself is rice paper, and they also put rice in the wrap, so majority of the wrap was starch that lacked flavor (the rice and wrap). It just seemed a little cheap to fill a vietnamese wrap with rice..

Basically the filling was really good, so if I go again I would order it as a bowl or salad. On a positive note, the staff were really nice and even informed us that the kimchi is not vegetarian.
author: Maleenee B.

description:
When Vietnamese and Korean inspired cuisine have a love child together, the result is the saam short rib spring roll burrito at Spice Kit (do you like my name for it? lol).  For ~$8, I'd say this was a legit meal with a variety of ingredients that satisfied my indecisive palate.  The saam burrito is wrapped like a beer belly in tight emo jeans in the translucent rice paper used for Vietnamese spring rolls.  Busting out with a medley of kimchi fried rice, lettuce, crunchy cucumbers, korean bean sprouts, and generous cubes of chewy, marinated short ribs, I found myself slobbering and spilling all over the place while Cristofer "I GOT 99 PROBLEMS BUT..." P. strategically explained the best way to vanquish the monster.  SRIRACHA SAUCE FTW!!!!!  It would be interesting and, I think, easier to eat if they used the Dduk Bo Sam (that glutinous rice flour cake: http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3037/2967972951_310fb810dd.jpg?v=0)

Cafeteria-esque, small restaurant.  The cashier noticed the table I was trying to claim was dirty so he rushed over to clean it.  What a guy!!!

Believe it.  I'll be back.
author: Kat C.

description:
Epic fail. I really wanted to love this place, but it really just didn't materialize for me. 

Ordered 5 Spice Chicken Bowl and Pork Belly Banh Mi. It was nice of them to be able to give me the Pork Belly in the Banh Mi, instead of the regular grilled pork that goes into sandwiches, but this place did not deliver. 

The ratio of pickled carrots to sandwich was too high, not enough meat nor flavor. The 5 Spice Chicken was good, but again, the ratio to other veggies and rice was not balanced. I hope things get sorted out, so I can enjoy my next meal here!
author: Teresa H.

description:
Little expensive for a Vietnamese sandwich but good nonetheless. Will come back when I'm in the mood for an awesome Vietnamese Sandwich. If only it was a little more affordable

I ordered the sandwich with the short ribs. Probably one of the best Vietnamese sandwiches I've had. I'm used to order my Vietnamese sandwiches from the South Bay, so it was pretty pricey for me but it being in the city and it being a damn good sandwich, I can see myself coming back.
author: Ryan R.

description:
Fusion on fusion on fusion of Asian foods. ie. Spice Kit. 

Where else can you go for vietnamese spring roll wrapped, korean BBQ burrito with a Indian mango lasse? Um, here. At Spice kit, where the way you put together your meal is essentially like a Chipotle.

About $8 your entree and $1.95 for your side (locust chips, ftw!)

Brace yourself as there may be a huge line during the lunchtime rush, but the line goes by pretty quickly
- minimal seating along the window, but a few seats available outside
author: Tiffany N.

description:
I am going to very honest with you here. I really, really like this place. Do I love it? No. Do I really like it? Yargh.

I literally went to Spice Kit every single day during the summer because it was conveniently located near my internship. I have tried everything on the menu. The only thing I really, really like? 3 words: The Pork Buns.

If you just ignore everything else on the menu and order 4 pork buns, you will guarantee treat your taste buns well ( maybe not your arteries though). 

If you don't want to listen to me, then you can order a wrap which is okay at best. IN CONCLUSION, get the pork buns. I think maybe I ate at this place too much hence why I don't love it. But the concept of the place is great; you can pick and choose.
author: Eileen W.

description: First time at SpiceKit and it was great!!!I had the Kalbi beef sandwich with vegetarian buns and Thai ice tea. If you are looking for a quick bite and want to walk away feeling good, SpiceKit is the place.
author: James H.

description: Pretty solid lunch, i don't really understand the lines here.   I've enjoyed the few lunches i've had here, although the portions are small.
author: Michael E.

description:
Needed my banh mi fix in the FIDI
Chicken banh mi- a bit disappointing. Bread was not crunchy. I think it was sour dough too. 
Pickled veggies were not up to par.
Chicken was flavorful. 
They forgot to put my jalapenos in the sandwich! 
Ordered 2 pork belly buns -yummy but beware. It's fatty
Iced coffee-lacked flavor
Total: $17. 
The hunt continues
author: PreciousSwt P.

description:
If I had one of these closer to my office I would eat here more often. Other than the fact that it is a bit overpriced, the food is good, generously sized and FAST. Had the sandwich, salad and pork bun... I would definitely recommend the pork bun - reminds me of the bun at Momofuku in NYC. This place is definitely setup to be a lunch spot but I think it can have the potential to be a dinner spot - just not in that particular location because it is DEAD there at night/weekend 

My advice to them: Open more locations in the city!! We need more (good) Asian "fast food" food options!
author: Daniel K.

description: Eh overall ok...but ordered a vietnamese bowl today and asked for "no peanuts." Came home to find that my bowl had no peanuts AND no crispy garlic. The crispy garlic is what makes the dish! Apparently the two toppings are mixed together (according to the employee), so if you don't want one, you don't get the other. Someone should have told me beforehand. Now I'll get back to eating my bland garlic-less vietnamese bowl rice =(.
author: Grace M.

description:
Asian fusion is not always a good thing. This place is OK, but definitely not great. The first time I went, I had the 5 spice chicken wrap. I did not realize the wrap was a rice paper wrap, which is my fault, but nonetheless I did not like it. The chicken was tasty, as was the rice, but the wrap kind of ruined it for me. 

What brought Spice Kit down to 3 stars for me was my second experience. I tried the pork banh mi. The pork was flavorless and dry. I had to smother it in Siracha in order to eat it. I have had way better banh mi's for half the price. 

The limeade is good. The five spice chicken would probably be better as a sandwich or bowl. The service is alright. 

Overall, this is not the lunch place for me. For a $10 lunch, I'd rather go somewhere with tastier food.
author: Elizabeth V.

description:
just had it for the first time, very craving for some Vietnamese,...
Steam buns: pretty good, little too pricy 
Five Spice Chicken Rice Bowl: chicken was not great, wish it had a little more sauce. 
Ice tea: it was great, not too sweet :) 

will I go back.........will I? I don't know. Maybe I try something different next time?
author: Sisi W.

description:
Proof positive people (you know who you are) will pay 800% more than they should for mediocre asian food.  Enough with this, "Well it's in the FiDi/SOMA" BS argument.  While some of these items are ok, nothing is great and the prices are insanely overpriced.  Reading thru the positive reviews of this place validates my assumption that the majority of Yelpers wouldn't know quality food if they were slapped across the face with it.  

1992 called and wants it's mediocre take on Asian food back!
author: Darin E.

description:
Spice Kit kind of reminds me of the Chipotle of bahn mi. There really aren't a ton of options for what you're going to get, but you'll get the food fast, it won't cost a ton, and it's going to taste pretty good.
 
I tried a wrap instead of a sandwich and it was decent, but next time I'm definitely going to try my meat between two buns. Hey-o! Speaking of buns I also order the pork buns and they were the highlight of my meal. All in all it's a decent lunch spot, but I probably won't be rushing back.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Love their Five Spice Chicken bowls with kimchi rice and extra kimchi. Quick service and super filling!

However, last time I got their Tofu protein option -- all I have to say is: AVOID. 
Unless you would like soggy, flavorless, old-tasting tofu. No, thanks.
author: Helen S.

description: My friend used to work in the same building so this was always a good place for snacks and drinks when meeting  up. I dont know what the lunch crowd looks like but at night the FiDi shuts down and it's pretty easy to get a quick bite. It's all about the pork buns...
author: Kim N.

description:
This place is...interesting. Very inventive menu selections. New, clean, nice outdoor seating area. I'm just not sure if the combination of goodies in my Ssam worked. 

I ordered the five spice chicken ssam. I had never heard of a ssam before but it's like a Korean burrito. I love Korean food & I love burritos, so the choice was a no brainer for me. Everything was very fresh & packed tightly in a rice paper wrap. All of the components were good but things got soggy very quickly. The yummy bean sprouts just got stringy & warm. I love the idea of a Korean wrap but it just didn't seem to work out for me. 

The pork bun was good but TINY for $3. The lotus chips were just OK & most of them were over-fried. 

I commend Spice Kit for using organic & sustainable foods along with compostable utensils & containers. I think next time I will try the salad so everything can stay nice & crisp, just the way I like it! They also have banh mi so I'll be checking those out someday soon too. 

As we were sitting on the patio eating our lunch, a woman parked her car on the street & promptly started changing into a gorilla suit with a pink tutu & feather boa. She didn't seem to be embarrassed at all to be transforming into a gorilla ballerina right there on Howard Street. Only in San Francisco!
author: Erin S.

description:
Small menu, big taste. 

We had the five-spice chicken salad, the Niman Ranch roasted pork salad, a pork banh mi sandwich, and a steamed Kurobuta pork belly bun. The salads were a bit overdressed (next time, I'm getting the dressing on the side), but the flavor combinations were spot-on: I loved the contrast of the tender, savory meat against the sweetness of the mango and the crispness of the jicama. 

The bahn mi didn't disappoint, either: As soon as the sandwich was delivered to the table, our five-year-old wolfed down half of it -- quite a feat, considering the pickiness of the child and the enormity of the sandwich. 

My favorite, though, was the pork bun. Yes, David Chang's version at Momofuki Ssam Bar is still tops in my book, but I'm pleased as punch that I can walk down the street from my office and get a damn good pork belly bun for less than $3. (I love New York and all, but we can all agree that air travel is a butt-pain.)

Also: Is this place insanely pedigreed or what? I mean, I don't get out much, and I'm sure this city's littered with Asian-inspired counter-service salad-and-sandwich places run by veterans of the French Laundry, Per Se and the Dining Room at the Ritz-Carlton, but this is the first I've come across. 

One concern: Does Spice Kit get enough evening foot traffic to justify staying open for dinner? I hope so, because I plan to come back soon for some p.m. eats.
author: Henry F.

description: Innovative, new taste, not necessarily spicy or flavorful though. I got the 5-spice chicken wrap... what a regret, it is exactly the same as the bowl, except much harder and messier to bite. The wrap is ultra chewy, bad if you are in business clothes. Overall, still a nice place for financial district. But give me more Spice!!
author: Dilys S.

description:
No one likes the rain.  Rain tends to keep people from going outside, and that is the perfect time to hit the eateries that normally have longer lines.  I just got back from here and there wasn't much of a line at all, quick in and quick out.  The staff here have a very efficient assembly line which definitely helps.  the menu seems pretty simple, only a few things on the menu, sandwiches, salad, steamed bun and chips.  

I had the 2/$5 porkbelly bun with a side of lotus chips.  The buns were like the size of White Castle sliders, however of much better quality.  The bun was super soft and the combo of the pork and veggies inside was a great mix.  The pork itself is nicely grilled, partially fatty and tender.

The lotus chips were a bit salty for me, but they are so thin that it didnt feel disgusting afterwards like you would normally feel like after a big bag of chips or fries.

All that for $7.  I'll definitely be back to get my spicekit on.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Got the tofu bahn mi, not authentic at all.
Squishy and soggy bread - not a traditional baguette.  There was no crunch!
Tofu was too sweetly spiced.

Peanut cole law was ok - good crunch, nice dressing.

I took the tofu off my soggy bread and ate it with the veggies but was not a fan.

Sorry Spice Kit.
author: Katie S.

description: Someone described this as "Chipotle-style Vietnamese food", which is kinda insulting because Chipotle sucks and this place doesn't at all. The five spice chicken wrap is a great consistent meal and a really good deal to boot (For downtown SF) at under $8. You can also get coffee for $1. Good coffee for $1.  Pretty much my go-to place when I'm in the area.
author: Walter P.

description:
I'm so tired of the broken record Yelp hateration that blabs on and on whenever an Asian joint tries to do something different.  Duh it's not authentic because they are trying to innovate!  And of course the price is higher because of more expensive rent, better culinary trained talent and higher quality ingredients than you'll find an ethnic ghetto!!!  But seriously, what other take away lunch joints are going to sell sous vide cooked then grilled short ribs?  No comparison to some $3 antibiotic-pumped caged chicken Vietnamese sandwich served with a side of crackhead.

Beef Shortribs: This is the top item to try here.  Apparently they sous vide the shortrib for 24 hours to get it tender without losing flavor then they put it on the grill for smoky char.  You'll notice huge slabs being grilled when you walk in.  Tastes amazing, way more tender than typical kalbi.

Roasted Pork: Soft and full of spices.  Way better than those cheap joints that just microwave some tough pork.

Ssam: Shouldn't this be called ssambap since there is rice inside?  A light lettuce wrap with your protein choice (pick shortribs), rice, kimchi and some other veggies all encompassed by a huge rice paper wrap.  I don't believe traditional ssams use rice paper, but this did help make it more manageable to eat at a desk.  Kind of like a super-sized summer roll.

Banh Mi: I like that the baguette is closer to a baguette than most of those fat hoagie rolls around town.  However, I still feel Lee's has the best bread.  Could have been spicier.  The pickled veggies were standard.  The pâté was totally worth the 75 cent add-on since it was of French charcuterie plate quality as opposed to that cheap spread stuff you get in Little Saigon.

Pork Bun: It's great that places in San Francisco are catching on to the bun sandwich finally.  The pork belly was nice and tender with good glaze, but could have been crisped a bit more.  The pickled cucumber slices were a nice crunch contrast.  Kind of small though.

Lotus Chips: Yummy!  Cool to have chips with holes in them.  When deep fried, kind of tastes like any other tuber.  Definitely a more thematic side than curly fries.
author: Adam B.

description:
I work close by so I decided to venture out here before rain season hits. It can be easy to miss as there is a huge tree in front of them but you can see Peet's coffee which is right next door.

There aren't many seats in the location so most people grab and go. It's similar to Asian box as its a 3 step ordering process. You first choose your whether you want a wrap(which is a huge rice paper that looks like a mini burrito), rice bowl, salad bowl or vermicelli noodles.

Then you choose the protein which range from 5 spice chicken, pork, beef or tofu. I asked the nice girl at the counter what was the most popular and she suggested the wrap with 5 spice chicken, so I went with that. I also ordered a side of fried lotus chips.

When the wrap came out, it literally looked like a mission style burrito in rice paper. The wrap in my opinion with the 5 spice chicken was a blend of Vietnamese and Korean. Most ingredients had a Vietnamese flavor and the korean part was the kimchi fried rice. It was a pretty hefty looking burrito and the 5 spice chicken has a good smoky flavor to it.

Their breakfast menu looked more interesting than their lunch menu and I plan to go there next time to try their porridge. 

Food Highlight: 5 spice chicken wrap w/ lotus chips. Breakfast menu served from 7am - 10am.
author: Rich L.

description:
I've been here three times now. First time was fine, the lady cashier was apologetic because they had ran out of half and half for thai tea. Although, eventually she found some and I left happily with a delicious drink. 

The other two times though, I've been helped by a young man who seemed confused. He certainly takes his time. I had to stare at him for a minute, wondering why he was looking into space and not taking my money that was on the counter. I only ordered a chicken wrap and received a pork wrap. My biggest issue with that is I was the only customer in there, along with a family of four who were deciding what to order behind me.
author: Clar S.

description:
I had the pleasure of attending the soft launch of Spice Kit this past weekend.

Tried the bahn mi and ssam - have to say the meats and tofu are some of the most juicy and deliciously flavorful fillings I've had in a sandwich or wrap.  If pressed, I would specifically recommend the short rib and tofu options as stand-outs.  I really liked the fact that you can customize the food (for me, extra jalapenos and pate on everything).

As for sides, you can't go wrong with the lotus chips and pork bun (which tasted fantastic, but could have been a bit hotter).  I'm giving this place five stars for the incredible food flavor - but they could use some improvement on the food delivery/execution.  Bread needs to be more toasted, portions need to be slightly larger, and service needs to be faster.

Can't wait to go back, especially after they work out the kinks!
author: Herman Y.

description:
Stop by if you're close, otherwise there's probably a local banh mi store that'll be on-par or better.

The chips are good, and the pork belly is OK.

3.5 stars, but definitely not a 4.
author: James G.

description:
Let's forget my previous review, shall we?

Do yourself a favor and get the Ssäm with beef short rib. Totally worth it. Try the other stuff on the menu later. 

The pork buns are adequate and the calamansi drink is refreshing. I've taken a coworker here and now she is a fan. But the ssäm with BSR is enough for me to add 2 more stars.
author: LM M.

description:
Great first day impressions.

Went for a sampling:
1 Short Rib Banh Mi
1 Pork Belly Steamed Bun
1 Bag Lotus Chips
1 Kalamansi Lime-ade

Overall the food was quite good.  Based on first impressions the best item was the lotus chips (SO GOOD) followed by the lime-ade (just the right sweet/sour & hilarious story behind the limes...).  The pork belly bun was good but I prefer the pickled daikon of the Chairman Bao buns personally.

The banh mi was quite expensive though it did feature really delicious and large chunks of short rib.  The bread was also excellent - great crust and tender chew.

Will be making Spicekit a regular on my lunchtime rotation.
author: Andrew B.

description: I tried one of their bowls. The meat was very low quality and they didn't have a large menu. I was disappointed since I had heard so much about it.
author: Dallas J.

description:
I had high (very high actually)  hopes actually and we are close to 4 stars. 

Here's my tip: order 2 pork buns and 1 order of slaw. Then mix rooster sauce in w/the slaw to make it spicy - deposit slaw into the buns.  What you end up with is something like a spicy moo shu pork bun.  quite nice.  BUT a little pricier than I want to spend for a small lunch.
author: Amy W.

description:
Personally, I didn't LOVE the food, but I ordered from the catering menu for a staff lunch and it was a big hit. I go the sandwiches, saam and rice bowls. Also got the big salad. Sauces were good, chicken and beef were very good, tofu wasn't....but then again it's tofu. 

I would order their breakfast for a staff event, but I wouldn't take anyone there for a real bahn mi or "legit" Vietnamese food experience.
author: Adele A.

description:
Lotus Chips OMG! I was so craving some potato chips and these filled my massive craving, these baby's are incredible! 
But let's back up a bit here, we (my husband and I) have been watching the food channel a lot lately and keep seeing places in NYC and SF that look mouth watering good. So since we were making a trek to the Ferry Bldg. for some chocolate we thought it was a perfect time to try some new,
So we Bart'd it to SF from the East Bay and got here about noonish, there was a line inside but it was very fast moving.
The place itself is stark and the menu simple. Banh Mi (Vietnamese Sandwich), Ssam (Korean Burrito) or Ssam w/o the wrap in a salad form.
Then you pick which meat you'd like from 5 Spice chicken, Beef Short Rib, Marinated Roasted Pork, Tofu seared in Soy scallion and spices, or Pork Belly.
My husband got the Banh Mi (he opted out of the pate) but used the Marinated pork.
I got the Ssam which is HUGE and filled with cucumbers, bean sprouts, rice, kimchi and I opted for Chicken.....oh it was heavenly.....
but I couldn't quite finish it (picked out the chicken, didn't want to waste those moist chunks of delicately seasoned meat.) Had a slight spiciness from the kimchi but I'd say on the milder side. And top it off with those Lotus Chips and a Limeaid and you are set!
And even though I couldn't quite finish I didn't feel overly full, it tasted healthy and fresh fresh fresh! And as we were leaving the line was out the door. But it was moving swiftly and I really think this is due to the simpleness of the menu....SMART! This place is a winner. I hope he expands soon and opens one of these in the East Bay. I'd love it and I know it would be a winner.
author: Susan D.

description: This place is great for what it is, easy, fast and inexpensive.  I've tried the wrap, but generally the rice bowl is the way to go.  I've had both the chicken and the steak, which were very good, but the fried chicken special on Wednesday and Friday is the way to go.
author: Tim S.

description:
I can only speak from one experience, which played out like this:

The place was swarming with folks, all happily waiting for their orders to finish. The line moved quickly. 

I ordered a 5-spice chicken bowl, which was a very nice portion for under $7.50. The chicken was tasty, as were the sprouts and rice. My coworkers got salads topped with beef ribs and chicken, respectively.

Definitely will be back. It's quick, relatively cheap, and the portions are right on.
author: Sean O.

description:
I'm SO happy to see they serve breakfast there now. I tried their rice porridge with a poached egg, chinese sausage, green onions, ginger and nuts. I could do with out the nuts maybe if they sprinkled yotiao, chinese donut that would be yummy!

I also had their warm spiced soy milk. It smells so divine! I could just imagine making oatmeal out of this yummy concoction would be so tasty!

Can't wait to try the other items you have available for breakfast! Keep up the great work guys!
author: She R. A.

description:
I had a very nice Saturday lunch here. I'm sure this place sees its fair share of lunch rushes during the weekdays, but there was no line and plenty of seating at 1pm on a saturday.

The wraps were more like big burritos.
author: Ameer N.

description:
so after many, many take-out dinners from here, i'm bumping up my rating to 5 stars. the flavors are consistently on point and the meat is just so tender and flavorful. my favorite bowl is the beef bowl. the chicken and pork bowls are both very good too, although some of the pieces of chicken can be kind of dry...but hey, it's chicken. *shrug*

their young coconut juice is fantastic! it tastes just like when i stick a straw into a coconut. they even have large shavings/pieces of soft coconut at the bottom of the drink, although they should make the straw bigger if they expect people to be able to get to those pieces. with all the beautiful weather we've been having lately, the iced coconut juices are just perfect. 

TIP: get more juice by asking for less ice!

UPDATE: they have breakfast!! the hot soymilk brings me back to when my mom would order me the huge bowl of dou jiang at chinese restaurants. just what i need on a cold morning walking to the bus!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I'm not asian so I don't know how authentic the food is, but everything tastes very high quality. The place is immaculately clean and everyone is incredibly friendly. What more could you ask for?

Pork banh mi - I could eat every day.  I almost do.
author: Bryan T.

description: I order a Korean bowl with short rib and 64 degree egg togo. When I got home, I realized they gave me a Vietnamese bowl instead and the egg I paid extra for was not there. Make sure to check if you order your food togo!
author: S H.

description:
It's like an Asian chipotle!

Good tasting food for FiDi - would be 4 stars in quality for food but minus one for the overpriced small(ish) portions. Come before 12pm and you will beat the line.
author: Adele Z.

description:
Dear Yelp Journal,

You know, after having eaten here twice, I would say they're OK.  They're kinda pricey considering there are way more delicious banh mi restaurants that I've been to, but then again they're not located in the heart of SF where I'm sure a lease for a small business is a huge fixed cost.  

After having eaten two sandwiches, I would say they're OK.  Not fantastic, but not horrible.  What I really like are those little pork belly sandwiches they have.  They're $2.50 a pop, but they're really good.  It's like peking style with the white cha siu bao type breading with peking sauce and pork belly.  Yum!  I might just order those from now on.

Overall, not the best, but they're A-OK.
author: Wilson K.

description:
I had heard a lot of good things about Spice Kit from friends, and decided one day to try it and see for myself if it was worth the hype! So for lunch one day at work I finally went and bought myself a Bhan mi (sandwich) and a Pork Bun on the side.  

First complaint I got here is got to be the price. In total, I paid over $11 for a sandwich and a side! Definitely way too much for me to come here for a casual lunch, let alone multiple times. My wallet hurt :( 

Regarding the food, I found the sandwich to be pretty decent, but that was it, decent. The meat was tasty and cooked well, but I only had about 10 cubes of meat total (and they were small) in my whole sandwich.  I personally would rather have spent $3 for a cheap, delicious vietnamese sandwich.  

The pork bun side was quite delicious, with tasty marinated pork and a soft bun. But for $3 dollars for one of them was just way too much to pay.

Overall I found the food to be worthy of a 3 star review, but the prices knocks it down to a 2. Maybe worth it to try once but not again!
author: Austin R.

description:
Lotus chips: DEEEELISH! 
Pork Bun: WOW!
Banh mi (all except the tofu): BOOOOMB!!
Vietnamese Coffee: Gimme MORE!

I simply couldn't resist signing up for a Yelp account just to give this place its well-deserved recognition. I have been here a few times and managed to stuff my face with everything on the menu except for the vegan (tofu) banh mi, ssam, and salad. Ditto to what the magazine wrote: Spice Kit is fine dining meets fast food. A successful deviation (just a tad) from "traditional" to create something new to SPICE up the bay! You really pay for what you get! Farm-fresh meats, especially the beef short ribs braised for 24 hours? Homemade pate? Organic veggies? Who DOES that? Thanks for watching out for my health and making food taste soooo DEEELISH! I'll be back for more, fosho! My boyfriend made my day by bringing some home today! =]
author: nubie s.

description:
The roasted pork Ssam (rice-paper burrito) is one of the best and most unique lunch items I've eaten in the city. The pork is aromatic with exotic spices, rice is seasoned with sriracha, add some finely sliced cukes and a leaf or two of lettuce, wrapped in a unique and tasty rice paper wrap. With a side of their incredible slaw, this has become a top-five lunch spot for me.

Note: the lunch rush at noon can slow things down a bit and create wait times of up to 8-10 minutes.
author: Christian B.

description:
All I can say for Spice Kit is meh when it comes to the Vietnamese Banh Mi's. I am giving them 2 stars for the price because you can definitely do better for the price you're paying here. The five spice chicken sandwich was really small. It didn't really taste that great either and the roll was much smaller than most places. I expected much bigger portions and the taste to compensate for the price but I was let down, unfortunately.

Here's what saved them and bumped them up another star. I ate their lotus chips for the first time and they were good. I couldn't stop eating them. The chips were indeed lightly salted and I liked the home made part about it. It did live up to my expectations. 

Overall I don't think I'll be back for the sandwiches. Maybe it's the price, the taste or a combination of the two. They should think about making their sandwiches bigger for hungry folks like me. I was hungry after a few hours later.
author: Tim G.

description: Vietnamese / Korean fusion? Sign me up! I tried the Korean bowl and the Bahn Mi and I must say I liked the bowl better.
author: Joffrey F.

description: Chipotle concept for Asian street food but made with fine dining techniques of those trained at French Laundry & Ritz Carlton Dining Room. Fresh squeezed Calamansi Line and coconut juices! Amazing pork belly buns. Rice bowls w super fresh ingredients. Five spice pork banh mi. Love it all. Worth every penny. I wish there was a location closer to me. I'd go all the time.
author: Christina C.

description:
After wandering SOMA for a-bit I yelped a place me and my friend could eat and found Spice Kit. 

The ordering process reminds me of Chipotle and other reviewers here attest to that.

I ordered the Banh Mi 5 spice chicken, opting to pay more for pate and grabbed 2 pork buns with a Vietnamese ice coffee to complete my meal. 

The Banh Mi had a nice crunch to it and held together very well. Flavors of the 5 spice chicken were mediocre, but didn't wow me like other 5 spice dishes I have had in the past. 

Pork buns resemble how Peking duck is served, but they used a nice grilled piece of pork belly instead paired with sliced pickled cucumber and scallions with hoisin sauce. This small little morsel is what I liked most about the place. 

Vietnamese ice coffee wasn't spectacular, but it is a nice pick me up when you're eating.

The plaza Spice Kit is located in can be a nice spot to eat your lunch on nice days in San Francisco. Floor to roof glass windows make for good people watching and for natural sunlight on late afternoons.

I give Spice Kit a 3.5 but will round up because of the Pork Belly, and possibly a return to try their lotus chips.
author: Casey L.

description: I just don't get it. I feel the same way about the Palo Alto location- every time I get it, I regret it. The meat just seems like low quality with tough pieces of fat. Yuck. If the food were cheap I'd be OK with that. But it's not. I reserve this place for days when it's pouring as I work in the same building.
author: Karla R.

description:
Ordered the meatball säam today for lunch - SO GOOD.

Spicy (as in flavorful, not spicy as in hot), different, filling, and cheap. Exactly what I needed for lunch. Sort of along the same lines as Sushirrito, but different.

Adding this to my lunch rotation!
author: Jeffrey H.

description: Pure joy for a kimchi-head like myself. My go-to is perfectly marinated Korean tofu in a rice paper wrap filled with bean sprouts, kimchi rice, cucumber salad, cilantro and egg.  Glorious when sided by fried lotus root chips or peanut ginger coleslaw. Eat often at the SF location during work week, and enjoy the San Ramon on weekends. This is my chipotle, I want to see a spice kit in every town by 2020. Love it so.
author: gigi s.

description: I've been here.a few times and always got the wrap.  Tonight I tried the salad and picked tofu to go into it, and it was very good,
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Tastewise, the Banh Mi with Beef Short Ribs (added pate for 75 cents) was delicious and worthy of 4 stars.

But after passing my credit card over to pay the whopping $9.53 for a Vietnamese sandwich, I couldn't give Spice Kit more than 3 stars.  The value for your money just isn't there, or I just cant justify it in my mind because the sandwich was on the smallish side, and it was just as expensive or more expensive than other bigger sandwiches in the FiDi.
author: Christina L.

description:
I have come here twice so far during lunch time as I work right around the corner. I got the five spice chicken salad both times, but today I also tried the steamed pork bun. I would have to say the bun was good but I like the salad better ($2.95 for a small pork bun and $6.95 for a hefty salad). The chicken is flavored nicely and I honestly don't even need any dressing with this salad (same goes for any other salad that I eat).

One complaint that I have is the cashier and other girl in the front are not very cheerful or friendly. They are a tad on the grumpy side and do not smile. I think if they livened up their attitude or had staff who were more warm and inviting, I would actually care to sit down and enjoy my food.
author: C C.

description:
Three or four stars for Spice Kit...hard to say.

Having been there about a dozen times over a year and a half I've regularly seen the staff do a good job of taking my order--although yesterday they mixed up my veggie bowl with a veggie salad. That said, they quickly gave me a cup of kimchee rice which was nice.

I think this place is slightly overpriced--especially for the veggie option. But, with the exception of last time where some of the tofu seemed over-fried or over-fermented or over something, I've always had a very good experience with the food there. Although, I wish they offered more vegetables on their bowl and sandwiches besides cucumbers, sprouts and lettuce.

The taro chips and limeade are both very good.

There's not a ton of seating inside, but even on the busiest day I can usually get a table or snag a nice seat outdoors--that is seriously helpful on a nice day.
author: Paul C.

description: Gross. The food looks promising, it's not. I got a rice paper pork wrap and ginger cabbage salad. The wrap contained fatty flavorless gristle chunks and the salad was made days ago and stuck in the fridge. Sad.
author: Dylan T.

description: I always like to get some good bahn mi when I can. This place has a more modern feel while the best spots are obviously the smaller mom and pop shops. The quality to bread is subpar based on what is consider a good bahn mi. But it's close to my office and not that crowded during lunch so I go back often
author: Ross I.

description:
Standard system for ordering. Pick sandwich, wrap, or salad. Then select which type of meat you would like. Quick to make the food. Very simple ambiance. 

I had the Bahn mi (Vietnamese Sub) with Five Spice Chicken. The ingredients were fresh. Lot's of goodies - carrots, pickles, jalapenos, etc.. The roll was perfect. Soft with a bit of crunch.

I also had the lotus chips. Nice alternate to standard chips

Overall, it was a very enjoyable lunch.
author: Mark D.

description:
I came here at 11:40am to beat the lunch crowd and glad I did, because the line started forming around 11:45-50...

The food however got me wondering why...
1. Five spice chicken bahn mi - usually the bread is what makes the sandwich, and my friend and I both thought that it was very dense and not as crispy as other sandwich places.
2. Steamed bun with pork belly - tasted like asian trash.  The bun was soft and delicious, but the pork belly was super charred and overwhelmed the other tastes...garbage
3. Lotus chips - slightly salty, fried/oily, nothing to rave about...at all.
4. Limeaide - Tasted good, refreshing...no complaints
Total ~$16.  

Not expensive, but for crappy food with a risk to wait in line...not worth it.

There's limited seating inside and out.
author: Janet L.

description:
I love this place.  So reminds me of Chipotle when you walk in because of how the menu items are displayed. 

You basically pick between a Bahn Mi, Wrap, Salad, then what type of meat you want- Five Spice Chicken, Short Ribs, or Pork.  They had fried chicken today for limited amount. 

I've only had the wrap here which is basically a big spring roll with rice, sprouts, meat, etc.  There is just way too much rice in it but the meat is always juicy. 

Tried to be fancy today and asked for Bahn Mi contents in the wrap- not so good. The pickled veggies was too strong for the wrap and I can tell it would have been better in the French Bread. 

Live and learn. TIl next time!

Oh and the pork buns and lotus chips are yummy too!
author: Anya R.

description:
I can't believe I've been sitting on this review for so long. 

 As others have mentioned it's kind of like the Chipotle of southeast asian food. Pick your protein, then decide how you want it presented.

The bf and I ordered banh mi, ssam, lotus chips, pork buns, and thai iced tea.

The food was tasty, but the chunks of meat in the banh mi were too large in my opinion. You end up with some bites with all meat and some with none. I loved the lotus chips though. 

While the food was tasty it was not special enough in my opinion to make this a destination. I would consider coming again if I was in the area.
author: Maria M.

description: I've had the pork belly buns a few more times and they have been really good. just wish they were bigger! I could probably eat 8 myself! The "bowl" dish is my favorite now too with the 5 spice chicken. This place has definitely grown on me!
author: Noah K.

description:
I don't go out very often.  At all.  It's one of those not-fun times in life in which costs outweigh expenses and fun/eating-out is the first place funds stop flowing to.  

HOWEVER, Spice Kit is my guilt-free default dinner spot when I'm working in SF (Rocketspace) and need some refueling.

Why?  It's fast, easy, fresh, delicious, and nicely priced.  And the best part is that it doesn't feel heavy or fast-foodish.  I almost always get the salad with either chicken on tofu, and it's bangin'!  It's got lots of goodies on it: jicama, mango, radish slices, peanuts, and scrumptious sesame dressing, to name a few.

Highly recommended for a quick, healthy bite.
author: Taylor L.

description:
I was able to try Spice Kit during the soft launch over the weekend like a ninja, but this review is for the experience I had today.

I ordered from them with this tactical blueprint:
1. Banh Mi
2. Pate(forgot it on my first order!)
3. Short Ribs
4. Vietnamese Iced Coffee
-----------I DID TRY THESE AS WELL-----------
5. Lotus Chips
6. Pork Bun
7. Thai Iced Tea

Crazy delicious? -YESSIR

The number 18... I stared it down since that was my order number.  #18 just barely legal... I got 8 good minutes of staring it down before I heard her name called. Will the founder called her name and I took my walk up to the counter with her in my hand.

When I traded my slip for my banh mi, I felt the warmth of the bread through the wrapper just like hitting to 2nd base with a warm apple pie!
