Unraveling the wrapper was more than a momentary experience, it was like I had a time-stop effect of opening a golden treasure chest.  The short rib literally smacked my eyes dead on like a sucker punch of meat.  It was packed with meat cubes, one even tried to run away from me, but I caught it and packed it back with the family using the age old 5-second rule.

First bite... ~~~CRUNCH~~~ Wow! You know it is good when you make it out of the first bite with a cut to the gum, like when you throw a Dorito chip sideways and it hits the roof of your mouth!  Tears of joy hit me as I hit the soft moist succulent meat of the short rib pranced around my tongue.  The medium rare beef was perfect... not too red not too brown... medium pink? WoOoHoOo! I loved it just like how I love my burgers!

The Vietnamese Iced Coffee was great! I must first admit to the audience that I am not a coffee drinker... I do not live by the 3 cups per day code so take this part of the review with a grain of salt.  I felt the sweetness / bitterness was a perfect blend.  I am a sucker for condensed milk and I think that was in there, unless there is something else that reminds me of condensed milk.  I killed my drink so fast and so furious that it was gone in 60 seconds.  I made my co-worker that I dragged with me do a double-take.

Anyways to conclude:
-Ordered food at 11:08am, received food at 11:16am +||+AWESOME+||+
-Cushy indoor seating with awesome possum outdoor view
-Friendly cashier and staff
-Awesome food and a very different banh-mi taste from all the other spots I have tried
-Price is right for the FiDi, but I can only do this 2x a week max (baller on a budget), but definitely once a week!

My pro tip: 2 Pork buns are a great substitute for lunch as well! They are "crazy delicious!"

Next time I will definitely try "Ssam" other item on the menu... like that Korean Wrap dealio.  Keep up the good work Spice Kit, you have made it into my FiDi rotation!
author: Benny S.

description: I want to give this place another star, but considering that I hold a few reservations against it, 3 stars it is.  I work right around the corner from Spice Kit, and also visit the chiropractor right across the street, so this is a once-a-month venture for me.  My favorite menu item is the beef short ribs in either the Ssam or salad.  When I'm feeling a cheat day, I'll go with the Ssam.  They load this thing with rice, and I usually resort to using a fork rather than dealing with rice spilling all over the place.  Not that this is a bad thing, it's just a lot for me.  In both the salad and Ssam situation, there is a less than desirable ratio of meat to rice (greens for the salad).  I only say this because I absolutely LOVE the flavors from the beef short ribs.  Absolutely incredible marinade and flavors that would be best magnified if the ratios were a little more reasonable.  In addition, this place gets sort of busy at lunch, so calling ahead of time helps you cut the line.  I've seen the line go out the door for Spice Kit, but as much as I like this, I'd rather go down the street and pick up something else rather than wait around.
author: Lisa I.

description: I've recently gone back to Spice Kit a number of times for lunch and have been happy with the food and the service.  I wish they did the fried chicken a couple more times a week (or put it on the menu all the time) but other than that, no complaints
author: Matthew B.

description: The food is fine. The most expensive bahn mi of my life, though. My biggest beef with this place is that they play LOUD BLASTING MUSIC AT OBSCENELY HIGH VOLUMES. Seriously, WTF!? Do you *not* want people to come in, or stay in?
author: K V.

description:
Short Ribs Vietnamese Sandwich: $7.95
Add house special Pate: $0.75
Tax: $.83
Total: $9.53

I'm so used to paying around $3 for a Vietnamese Sandwich that this lunch hurts the wallet a little. If I'm gonna be paying 10 bucks for a Vietnamese Sandwich, it better be the best sandwich ever.

So was it? FAR FROM IT

Nothing special about the house special Pate. Short Ribs was not well marinated. Shredded carrots were too sour. 

Lesson learned.
author: Emmie N.

description:
I come here pretty much once a week during lunch time, and order the same thing every time. So if you're looking for a general review for their menu, read no further.

Order the wrap with beef short ribs. The meat is flavorful, and the rice is always on point, a lil spicy, I think they mix it with kimchi. The wrap is delicate, so be careful with it cause it tears easily. The sprouts, cucumber, and lettuce always taste fresh.

If you're going around lunch time, call in and place your order 15 mins ahead. When you get there you won't have to wait long.
author: Harold C.

description:
3.4 stars: 

5-spice chicken - over-priced as previous reviewers mentioned but delicious, fresh ingredients incl. very fresh, crusty banh mi bread
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
05.06.11

I have had almost everything on the menu.  I'm surprised I've never written a review before, but here goes.

Their pork is bomb.  Put that on the salad.  Put that in a sandwich.  Put it in the wrap.  However you like it, get the pork.  Or the two pork buns for $5.  Get the pork.

Thanks for saving my butt during long nights at the office.  They're opened until 8, so it's a quick grab and go back to your desk if necessary.

I am a repeat customer for sure.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I got the Short Ribs Bahn Mi with Pate and it just didn't seem to go well together. I wouldn't get that combo again. The rest of the sandwich was ok but not great.

- Minus 1 star for forgetting my co-worker's order and not being apologetic about it.
author: Alex P.

description: The steamed pork buns were small but delicious. I also liked the lotus chips, but thought this food would be better served out of a food truck than in a big empty square of a space. Still it was good fast way to eat lunch in the financial district.
author: Will B.

description:
i tried this place for the first time and i dont usually say this, but this was the most unsatisfying lunch i've ever had!! 

i recently got a job in the city and being that my company pays for my lunch, i ideally would like to try a different restaurant every day. well today i tried spice kit, a hybrid of american-korean-vietnamese cuisine (the most unlikely combination ever...). my manager forwarded me the menu and just with the website itself, it looked trendy and yummy. the menu was simple enough, choose between their bahn mi, Ssam? (korean wrap) or salad with your choice of meat/poultry. i got the Ssam beef short ribs, which sounds delicious, right? WRONG. i dont know if it was my asian palette that couldn't handle this american fusion, but my lunch lacked lots of flavor!! it was seriously so bland and i couldn't even finish half. i had to secretly throw it away as to not offend my manager (yes i know there are children starving in africa but i just couldn't finish it!!). 

my manger then turns to me and asked me how the food was. i politely told him it was fine, but wasn't very asian at all. to my surprise he agreed! but he still managed to finish his food..

there are plenty of good places to eat in this area and i would only advise someone to eat here if they order the salad. my coworkers seemed to enjoy that. but i on the other hand am left with an unsettling feeling in my stomach and a longing for actual asian food..
author: Andy H.

description: I'm a big fan of vietnamese sandwiches and they do it really well. Fresh bread. fresh cilantro, pickled veggies, and good meat. It's not hard to screw up, its a staple sandwich in my diet. The only reason it's not a five star is that you can get the same sandwich down the street for half the price
author: Daniel B.

description:
I like the concept of this place. I got the short ribs bowl... the meat was really good, and the other elements were good as well. I did get a little tired of the kimchi rice after a while... not my favorite. Also, I did add sriracha to make it more flavorful. Service was very friendly and I got my food quickly.  Prices typical for the area. I'll have to come back again to decide if I really like the place.. I'm unsure at the moment. 

After reading the reviews on here, I didn't come here expecting something authentic, and I think that made my experience better. So my advice: don't come here expecting authentic asian or vietnamese food, because that's not what it is.
author: Alison B.

description:
The do it yourself rice bowls fed 9 hungry guys with leftovers.

UMM Spice KIt

The chicken was specially delicious and since it was all separated out with lettuce cucumber and spouts, everybody could choose what they wanted. Ditto with the sauce. I also liked the cute plastic utensils including tongs.

I will return if the budget allows!
author: Sean C.

description: Great place to go for a quick and casual lunch with good service. The steamed pork buns were fantastic at only 2 for $5. Also had the Vietnamese pork bowl, wasn't crazy about it but it was good nonetheless. The rice seamed a little overcooked and it was missing more of the garlic sauce (if you like spice ask for extra jalapenos!). Would love to go back and try the ban-mi as well as some of the breakfast items, which look delicious!
author: Elisa P.

description: It used to be amazing when it opened, but over time the quality of the meat dropped down considerably, and everything started to taste the same. The sandwich option is still pretty good, though.
author: Steve E.

description:
[korean ssam wrap]
Basically a ginormous burrito with Vietnamese rice paper.  It is filled with kalbi and veggies.

My guess is the kalbi is cooked through sous vide, and I feel that the meat didn't have a good enough sear on it.  This may be for the amount of orders they are serving, but I felt it was too soft with a nice browning. 

[lotus chips]
Very delicious.  They slice the lotus chips really thinly.

[overall]
I give them mega props for a simple menu and using rice papers in a way I've never seen before.  If you want a quick lunch, this place is the way to go.
author: Dan Q.

description:
So why did I increase from 3 stars to 5?

1. Food is really good quality, compared to those whole in the wall places
2. Had the korean wrap, and it was delicious
3. Portions are very good
4. Sides of lotus chips are a tasty salty side, ginger salad is refreshing/different (reminds me of KFC coleslaw, but with an asian twist)
5. Friendly service, open till 8pm
6. Very eco-friendly, with recycling separation (counts for a lot in my book)

All those in mind, convinced me I had to jump up to 5 stars!
author: Eddy N.

description: Great place for a quick bite, clean and friendly service...the pork buns are not traditional...but the kids loved them...I'm a fan!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Dee D.

description:
What to get: Ssam wrap with roasted pork. All this good stuff wrapped in rice paper. It's like a giant Korean spring roll, hearty and flavorful.

Sadly, this isn't a viable lunch option for me since I don't work in the city, but they are open late. I suppose that if I ever craved a wrap, I'd swing by before 8pm or have the bf stop in and make a home-delivery.

I'm okay with not being too adventurous [other reviews indicate that the banh mi is a no-go] and sticking to what I like.
author: Tinna H.

description: Yum!  The banh mi was tasty, and the ssam wrap was also very good.  I loved the pork buns, as well.  Portions are huge, and it's a bit pricey, but overall really good lunch option.
author: Michelle C.

description:
I had the 5 chicken spice wrap. It was pretty nice.
Quick service and cheap price.
author: Paulo C.

description: Oh my gosh!!!! I was in town for a conference at Galvanize and looking for nearby place for healthy gluten free lunch.  Boy was I blown away!  Food was fantastic! Fresh, tasty and great value.  The team is even better! Probably the friendliest and more helpful I've been served by in a long time.  Can't say enough about SpiceKit except come to Washington, DC.  You would do amazing here!  Please come...Please.
author: Kimberly M.

description:
I gotta hand it to these folks. They're trying to make something happen. They're in a plaza that seems to be pretty dead at night so I don't know they'll be packing in the dinner crowds but I can see how lunch would be big here.

I discovered Spice Kit in today's edition of Tablehopper. I decided to give it a try. I drove by the place once because it's a bit tucked back in a plaza. I spied it, parked and walked over. It felt part sandwich shop, part fast-food. There are only a few items on the menu. I ordered the Bánh mì (classic Vietnamese sandwich - toasted baguette, pickled carrots and daikon radish, cucumbers, jalapeño peppers, mayo, meat/tofu, and cilantro). I ordered the 5-spice chicken as the meat. i also ordered a Steamed Pork Bun (Grilled Pork Belly, pickled cucumbers, scallion and hoisin sauce).  I washed it all down with a Calamansi "Lime-ade".

The sandwich was excellent. A little Sriracha hot sauce and yum. The veggies were crunchy, the roll fresh and the chicken savory. The pork bun was similarly excellent. A gentleman behind the counter brought me over a free order of Lotus chips. They were good as well. It was all good. Total dinner expense was less than thirteen dollars.

The folks there were friendly. There's no ambience to speak of...the dining area is mostly hard surface and tall ceiling...a bit of echo. I think a couple of things will be challenging for them. Location for dinner will be tough. The small menu means diners will tire of their options quickly. I will keep my fingers crossed for them.

3.5 stars
author: Gary C.

description: Well...it was my lunch time working in the financial district and I felt like eating salad during my lunch break.. so my co worker and I decided to try this place out because it was literally right across the street from our clinic!!  I ordered the five spice chicken salad and i had to wait almost 30 minutes for it.... (I'm not even kidding nor am I over exaggerating) By the time I got my food, I probably only had 10 minutes left to INHALE it all down to my stomach..... so how did I feel about the salad...? mMm... I ate all the chicken because that was the only thing flavorful!  The salad was HECKA DRY!!!...mMmmmmm... maybe they forgot about the dressing...??? oh yes they did. So I felt like I was eating my backyard...LITERALLY ****dry... grass***... ): I would've went back to get the dressing.. but like i said... I only had 10 minutes left... so..that was a bad bad bad experience...
author: Annie Y.

description: The pork belly sandwich is A-OK. Good amount of refreshing-ness, heat, and seasoning. Not the best vietnamese sandwiches I've had before but I really dig the ultra-simple menu. Barely any seating so tough for a group. Plenty of siracha to go around.
author: Grayson K.

description:
Veggie goodness. 

I usually avoid Vietnamese sandwich spots for fear I'll be stuck with pork, pork and more pork as an option. Well, not at spice kit. You can make the sandwich or the wrap vegetarian. Great start!

I had the wrap with veggies and tofu. It was delicious and flavorful. Definitely get some spicy sauce on the side, too! Everyone I was with loved their sandwiches and the pork buns.

Great spot for lunch and the line moves very quickly.
author: Gretchen S.

description:
Got the beef shortrib ssam. It was okay. The short was all-right. 

The porkbelly bun was okay. It was way too expensive, though. $3 for one bun
Chairman Bao is way way better.

So I spent $12 for all that, so not worth it. Breakfast sounds good.
author: Joolie T.

description:
So after seeing Spice Kit on either the cooking channel or travel channel, the bf added it to his food list on places he wanted to check out on SF so on 3/19 (The day it rained all day in SF and almost got blown away at one point with some 50 mph winds)  So we walked over to Spice Kit and already knew what we were going to order Ssam short beef ribs, Ssam roast pork, lotus chips and the slaw...overall the Ssam were good and yummy, we both agreed the short ribs Ssam was so much better than the pork, thou the pork was tasty as well.  The lotus chips were a bit salty and I'm a salt freak, but even that was too much salt for me.  The slaw was lacking something it needed some sort of a kick.  

Shame they don't have one in NYC...it would be a hit!
author: Judy C.

description: Good place for Asian food, especially work meal. It serves fast and good.
author: Jia Z.

description:
In the bun, pork belly is a little tough and lean. Hoisin is light. Pickle plus belly tastes like a burger. Doesn't hold a candle to other trendy buns (David Chang, etc.)

Sandwich is light on carrot cilantro radish. Pate is mild. Pork is very good and tender,  well seasoned. Bread is wrong, soft and gets mushy too fast with no crust, making the inside stodgier and less banh mi-y.
author: Michael F.

description:
If you're not concerned with fatty meat, try the Korean wrap (ssam) with short-ribs ($9) - my favorite. It's a giant spring roll filled with lettuce, bean sprouts, kimchi rice and 24-hour sous vide braised short ribs finished on the grill. These are short ribs, so there's a good chance you're going to get a layer of fat on some pieces, which I think adds nice, juicy flavor.

If that's not your thing, Spice Kit offers five-spice chicken, roasted pork and tofu that can be put into a salad, sandwich (banh mi) or rice roll (ssam). The banh mi's are OK and I love rice noodle too much to ever get a salad, so I always get variations of the ssam.

Lotus chips and the pork belly buns are afterthoughts. The chips are a bit bland - it is lotus root after all - and the buns don't stack up to a good dim sum BBQ pork bun. 

Line can be long, but it moves quickly since the menu is small.
author: rosanna c.

description: EXCELLENT!! this place made me like vietnamese food again. Healthy tasty options available, a plus for me.
author: Edward R.

description:
I like this place.

Would I go back? Yes.

Would I go out of my way to go back? No.

Skip the banh mi. 

Get the ssam wrap w/ short rib (trust...this Korean liked it a lot...very authentic...huge).  

If you're really hungry, add in a pork belly bun (oh mama, that was good...too small for a meal on its own though...you'll need something else)

Definitely DON'T forget to get the lotus chips.  Salty goodness.

Skip the thai tea. Blah.

Nice lunch option for us SoMa-workin' peeps...
author: Susan L.

description:
If you're charging extra for pate you're not really selling banh mi; you're selling what could be banh mi if you're willing to spring for add-ons. A cheesesteak shop that charges extra for cheese is just a steak sandwich shop. And a cheesesteak shop that charges twice as much as every other place once you've paid for enough options to get a proper cheesesteak is, well, I don't know what that is. My analogy has broken down.

To be fair, it's a pretty decent sandwich, the pate has the right consistency, plenty of peppers, the pork could be a little juicier but it's still pretty good. But it is not the kind of sandwich that makes you glad you spent ten dollars.
author: matthew r.

description: Super clean, high quality ingredients, like Chipotle for Vietnamese food.  I've had the Vietnamese sandwich which I thought was a little small.  I've also had the Korean style "burrito" that I liked a bit more, although it's lacking a bit of structural integrity and you may need a fork.
author: Vivek P.

description: This is a great lunch spot. Lines are pretty long during weekday lunch, so get there early. You first choose the dish format then choose the meat. The meat choice determines the cost. I ordered the Bahn Mi sandwich with Five Spice chicken. It was very tasty and flavorful. They now also have vegetarian sliders which made with mushrooms. Those are two for five dollars. I was pleasantly surprised they close fairly late on week day nights compared to other lunch places in the SOMA district.
author: Foo L.

description:
Every visit here is a treat - let me start with the pork buns which is really heaven on a bun.  Is there anything better than pork belly, seasoned perfectly, on a soft yummy bun.

Then there are the wraps, bowls and salads - are are delicious and full of flavor.  Need some rice with your lunch - enjoy the wrap or bowl.  Watching carbs - the salad has a wonderful dressing, and perfect seasoning.  The meats are all well prepared and flavorful.

And of course, the banh mi is pretty close to perfect.  Took some co-workers the other day and they all loved it.

Perfect lunch treat.
author: Sallye M.

description:
I would give this place one star... but I just don't have the heart to do it, considering my experience is probably just bad luck. That and the service was friendly and quick. Spice Kit led me to some mild stomach problems, my friend suffered much worse... If I was feeling her pain, maybe I wouldn't be so kind.

The food here is very 'meh,' nothing special really. The concept seems pretty cool. Pick your filling, choose whether you want it in a sandwich, wrap, or bowl. I had the tofu wrap. It was like a giant fresh spring roll. The rice in my wrap was way too mushy. Other than the bad rice, it was okay, but nothing i would wait or go out of my way to get.
author: Angela T.

description:
I love this place!  This is nothing like a cheap Vietnamese sandwich place, so if you're looking for a cheap $4 banh mi, this is not the place for you.  The food here is absolutely delicious and they use high quality ingredients (like naturally raised chicken and pork, organic tofu, and fresh organic vegetables).  Plus, they seem to be a very environmentally conscious business -  major kudos for that!

I've been to Spice Kit couple times now and have not been disappointed yet.  My favorite is the Beef Shortribs - so tender and nicely marinated - quite tasty!  The pork bun makes a great treat!

Oh, and the service is awesome- very friendly staff!
author: Esther K.

description:
Spice Kit, you are right by my work and even more right by 2+ friends' work. We could totally be eating there all the time.  5 stars for location.

But let's talk food.  You are a restaurant, after all.  You want to be Chipotle, but from another region.  I get it.  You offer one vegetarian option, served 3 ways.  I've had it (1 way). It was interesting, yet meh. Now what?
author: Andi T.

description:
As a few others have said, this is Asian Chipotle. When framed through this lens it's hard not to love Spice Kit. 
Sure, the ssam and banh mis are not the most authentic you'll ever have, but they're delicious, nutritious and made from great ingredients very fast even during the lunch rush.
I almost always get the Beef Banh Mi with Pate and lotus chips. Make sure to add those on, they're a tasty snack.
author: Max G.

description:
I have been ranging further afield recently for lunch and that has generally yielded good results; today was another such case. I tried the Korean wrap, which turned out to be essentially a burrito-sized spring roll; having rice paper instead of torilla was both interesting and ultimately appealing. I was also very impressed by the lemongrass pork that filled my wrap; I want to try the other meat options now, also. Sadly, this tastiness was tainted by the disappointing Thai iced tea. Not only was it thin and lacking in spices, but it came pre-stirred... perhaps to hide the dearth of cream? Still, I was impressed by their environmental ethic - nearly every piece of cutlery, serving dishes, and other products are compostable in the clearly marked receptical. 

The most pleasant surprise to discover, though, was the extremely comfortable, padded bar chairs for counter eating - far more appealing than the hard, bare wood banquette seats. It was more supportive and contoured than my office chair and I wanted to take it with me back to the office!
author: Bill B.

description:
I really wanted to keep Spice Kit a secret, but the 100+ reviews have already let this cat out of its bag. 

Spice Kit's BRAISED SHORT RIB wrap is honestly one the best things I've eaten here in San Francisco. Tender, marinated beef, boldly seasoned rice, crunchy veggies -- it is so fricking satisfying! The actual wrap  that holds all of this awesomeness together is this clear, stretchy rice disc. It looks and sounds a little intimidating at first, but don't be scurred. The pay off is delicious.

I'm really curious about the grilled pork belly "buns" and the lotus chips, but I can't get myself to order anything other than the beef short rib saam when I'm there. Maybe next time ... probably not.
author: Kevin C.

description:
This place is ok, but it ain't great.

Both times, i've tried the five spice chicken (with and without pate). How many spices? 5. But if it weren't for the name -- I would have thought this sandwich was just a chicken sandwich. It's not a memorable sandwich and tastes quite bland.

The sandwich with pate is better but it will run you a little more than $8 which is steep for a mediocre Vietnamese sandwich.

Don't bother getting the Vietnamese coffee either. It's just tastes like Starbucks coffee with condensed milk. 

I came here twice, but I don't think I'll be back. I'd much rather take a bus to the TL to get some real quality Vietnamese sandwiches.
author: Vanessa W.

description: Maybe I need to give this place another try considering all the great reviews, but I found my 5 spice chicken Vietnamese bowl very unflavorful. I might return for the banh mi's and buns.... if I ever get over my trauma from the bowl.
author: Jen W.

description:
When I hate on LeBron James, people assume it's because I'm a Laker fan and it's natural for me to hate on anything that threatens their title chances.

But truth be told, it's because LeBron could be so much better than he is. While he's arguably the best at what he does (playing basketball) he could truly be transcendental if he put his head down and put all of his energy into playing basketball (instead of trying to be Mr. Cool). 

Anyways, that's what I thought of SpiceKit (or as my friend cleverly called Kimchi-potle). Instead of going all the way and using robust Asian flavors, I feel like the flavors were rather subdued (in the same manner that Chipotle turns the volume down on Mexican flavors) in an effort to capture a broader audience. That is the Kimchi wasn't as bold or spicy enough; and the short ribs while tender weren't flavored enough. I tried the wrap which in my opinion lacked an element that should have unified all the ingredients. A fermented bean paste or gojujang would've really done it.

In the same manner that LeBron has fallen short of a championship, SpiceKit misses the mark. But like LeBron that doesn't mean it isn't good in its own way. It still brings a fresh taste and unique interpretation that has some universal appeal.

But for me, what could've (and should've) been great is only good.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
Epic blunder on my part: do not wrap your wrap in a napkin.  Although compostable, napkins should not be an added ingredient to your lunch.  

At Spice Kit, you have your choice of filler (chicken, beef short ribs, pork, or vegetarian) and "vehicle" (Vietnamese style sandwich, wrap, salad/bowl).  I opted for the beef wrap and a side of lotus chips.  The wrap (sans wrap - technically a salad/bowl - since my napkin was stuck to it) was really tasty, especially the huge cubes of grilled beef.  The lotus chips were light and crisp, but also a tad too oily.

Prices are what dropped Spice Kit to three stars.  Nine dollars for a wrap (the $1.50 lotus chips are more reasonable)?  Nah, no thanks, I'll pass.
author: Mel T.

description:
My life is turning into some warped bachelor version; the only things I have my refrigerator are Kraft American singles, thick-sliced bacon, ketchup, and beer.  There are some frozen vegetables in the freezer.  So, after a 3-mile morning run, I was hungry and decided to fry up the bacon and then cook some potatoes in the bacon grease.  YUM.

Then my friend made fun of me and said I had a "lumberjack breakfast."

So I decided to be proactive by eating a healthy lunch.  After reading about Spice Kit and walking past it numerous times (it's less than 3 blocks away from my place), I decided to give it a whirl on my way back from work.  I asked the counter guy what he recommended, which was the banh mi with chicken or pork, and the wrap with beef short ribs.  After much contemplation, I decided to go for a wrap with the vegetarian option (marinated tofu), and a pork belly bun.

The wrap was large, but it was overpowered by the kimchi.  My bites alternated between being too kimchi and too much rice, which dulled every other flavor.  TOO much rice, not enough tofu, which was very tasty.  I would've been pissed if I'd ordered it with the short ribs and then not gotten a decent amount in my wrap.

The pork belly bun was flavorful but at $2.95 for three small bites, definitely not worth it in my mind.  I wouldn't actually mind eating a bunch of those for a meal, but that would add up to be $$$.

Friendly service and convenient location, but it's not a place that I'll likely be returning to, unfortunately.  Fusion restaurants are hit or miss for me, and this one was a miss.  I'd rather spend my lunch money elsewhere in SOMA.
author: Tori S.

description:
Every time i come here, the owner or exec chef is dishing out the orders with a smile and the food has come out hot and tasty. So far I've had almost everything on the menu and the overall consensus is 4 stars for me. Why? Well its for the quality of the food that you get with the 4 or so options for them to be served. You can get 3 meats served 3 ways with a vegetarian option. I have tried all of them and my favorite is the roasted pork in the Banh Mi with an extra slap of their house pate! Next would probably be the beef short ribs in the Ssam wrap. Beef n rice in the SOMA never tasted so good.  They have some of the best, most tender pork, chicken and beef that can be served within the vicinity of this location. 

People complain about the price for this compared to other places in the City but c'mon, does even f*ckin Jack in the Crack in Beverly Hills ever really sell a .99 breakfast jack!? NOPE! (shit was like nearly $2.50!) Parking was $12 before all the construction and now its an average of pinche viente dollares within a 2-3 block radius of Fremont/Howard. its the Soma area, look at who's leasing real estate here. If i was the owner, I'd try and rape all the white collars myself. Obviously they've done their research on the market and priced it comparatively to fit the demographics of the surrounding area. If it really hurts your pocket, there's Saigon on Spear or that Lil Miss Muffett place on 2nd...
author: Nick V.

description:
Imagine a parallel world where burritos were invented by Asians. Rice paper instead of tortillas. Hoisin sauce instead of sour cream. Cucumbers, spouts, lettuce and kimchi instead of salsa. Five-spice grilled chicken instead of, well, just grilled chicken.

This delicious, brilliant, innovative, reasonably priced and impressively quick (twenty orders out in ten minutes!) world exists. Welcome to the world of Spice Kit.
author: Jason B.

description:
I'm giving Spice Kit a solid 5 stars which is not something I treat lightly since 5 stars should only be reserved for the BEST places and I know my bahn mi sandwiches

I've have now tried Spice Kit several times and have loved every meal.  If it's your first time I would recommend ordering

- bahn mi.  get with meat of your choosing but be sure to order the pate.  the pate is homemade and of fine dining quality
- saam.  get with shortribs and ask for jalapenos if you want it more spicy (they're very welcoming to customizing your order)
- sides.  pork bun is a must try.  momofuku quality at a casual restaurant in FiDi?  insane!

Couple other things to note
* Spice Kit is open late (8pm during the week) and on Saturday for lunch.  No more wondering around with a hungry stomach when FiDi is empty like after a zombie apocalypse
* Their drinks are a tasty alternative to the daily trek to Pete's.  Let your coworkers continue with their daily latte injection.  Go next door and get Vietnamese coffee and Thai ice tea FTW! (and you can customize your sweetness unlike hole-in-the-wall places with mean servers)

Also I don't like commenting on other yelpers but I have to say some of the reviews I'm reading are pretty silly.  Trying to compare a Spice Kit bahn mi to a place in the Tenderloin is like trying to compare the Marlowe burger to a fast food joint.  They are simply not comparable.  And most foodies understand there's a place for both in their tummies  =)

With Spice Kit you're getting fine dining techniques like sous vide cooking and organic / high quality ingredients.  Does that sound like a $3 sandwich from the 'loin where pate comes from the mystery can?  Nope.
author: Stephen C.

description:
Like an Asian Chipotle.

Great spot for lunch. Love the 5-spice chicken Ssam. Often order light on the rice. It is a Korean spring roll that puts Chipottle's burrito to shame.
author: Annie G.

description:
credit to previous reviewers. "Asian Chipotle" is a very apt description of this place. 

They try to fuse alot of things together but they don't they do anything impressive amongst any of the cuisines they borrowed from. 

The pork buns are tasty but very small and expensive at 2 for $5 

"you charge extra for pate?" 

Pros: 
good meat
fast service 
Clean environment 
plenty of sriracha on hand 

Cons:
price
long line at lunch (get here early if possible)
dumbed down flavors (to each his/her own I guess)
small portions. As a former XXL if your are hungrier than the average bear this won't fill you up. 

If you know what Vietnamese coffee is supposed to taste like this isn't what you want. 

Final words: Not a bad spot for a snack/light lunch if your close by but not worth any type of special trip.
author: Norris T.

description: Dry vietnamese sandwich that cost too much. Why do I have weird Asian cravings around FiDi? Then I get disappointed when it's not good! Sigh... I need to stop eating this kinda stuff around my work. Had the 5 spices chicken sandwich and the lemonade. The lemonade was good, refreshing. The chicken was dry and not flavorful. Ick. It's food like this that makes me miss the South Bay. $3/viet sandwiches that were actually good. The price I pay for living in SF.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Dear Spice Kit,

I'd like to send you on a fact-finding mission.  

First, please go to Tu Lan and taste their coffee.  This is what Vietnamese coffee tastes like.  It is strong and sweet and full of flavor.  The bland, gray water you are slinging is offensive, and came out so fast that it must have been in a pitcher, not the traditional slow-drip brew that imparts so much richness and character.  Yours tastes like diner coffee.

Second, go to Muffins Muffins.  It's only a couple blocks away.  Their banh mi are better than yours.  They are also half the price.  Please notice how their pate does not cost extra, since it's a standard feature of Vietnamese sandwiches.  What you are doing is akin to charging extra for ketchup on a burger.  

Their pickled veg is also a more manageable size and shape, not the medusa hair you are slapping down, which is  pretty, but not functional. Your pickles are also too sweet.  I don't want dessert in my sandwich.  You might as well be using doughnuts instead of a baguette.  On that note, your baguette is particularly narrow and hard.  I thought your baguettes were supposed to be one of the ways you justified the high cost of your street food.  

Please do something about your peppers too.  I don't know if they are just extra small and spicy, or if it is a placement issue, or simply lack of abundance of all the other ingredient (kind of a skimpy sammie) to balance them out, but I was getting alternating bites of no spice, and too much spice. 

The pork buns are spectacular and save you from a 1 star review!
author: Quinn S.

description:
I've been waiting for Spice Kit to open, and finally got to try it for lunch today.  We tried almost everything - I'm a fat kid at heart.  We had the ribs on the baguette - add some Sriracha and WOWIIEEE! It was an awesome combo. We also had the wrap with pork in it, but we both thought the baguette was better. We each boughtt a pork bun, which was tender and delicious (2 for $5). The cilantro on it was a nice touch too. OH! and the lotus chips were definitely worth getting ($1.50). They are not like your regular potato chips. They are in a cute shape and delicious.  To drink, we each had a iced coffee ($3). 

Total bill came out to $17, which was a bit more than I was expecting to pay, but for the nice ingredients, fast service and quality of food, I'd definitely go back!
author: Taylor L.

description:
I've tried a few "Korean tacos," now I can say I've eating a Korean burrito.  Being a big advocate of rice paper and bean sprouts, I went with the ssam wrap with short rib and was quite pleased.  The short rib was flavorful, the veggies had crunch, and it was a decent amount of food.  The only bummer is that it sprung a leak before I reached my ultimate dining destination and I didn't have utensils so I had to leave a fair amount behind to avoid looking like a cavewoman.  I also tried one of their pork belly buns and it was reaaaaallly good.  I may just order a few of those next time.

P.S. All you Yelpers who dubbed this the "Asian Chipotle" were spot-on.
author: Krystle S.

description:
This is why I am giving this place a 2 star review. 

1. You look pretty. space, logo, people... pretty. 
b. You're near my jobby job. 
iii. 7 bucks for a bah mi (i think that's what be-it-name sandwiches are called) is CRAZY FACE!

ok i'm done with the list gimmick... lets continue. 

The most over powering flavor in the veggie sandwich was the bread... and not in a good way. Get better bread. The flavors we all a bit lack luster. I know this probably isn't the best idea, it's down right wrong... but go to Siagon Sandwhich and steal a bunch of their bread and fillings. Then add some gold leaf flakes on top. I'll gladly pay 7+ dollars for that!!! 

That being said, I'll try a salad next time, because I like looking at pretty things.
author: danny e.

description:
I've got to say, Spice Kit left me very disappointed. I was excited for a new banh mi place to open and, since it was getting so much buzz and good reviews, I expected it to be much better.

We got the lotus chips, steamed pork buns and pork banh mis with pate. The highlight of the meal was the lotus chips (which in my opinion is the equivalent of saying "the highlight of the burger was the french fries" - when are chips not good?), although they were a little on the greasy side. 

The pork bun didn't have enough hoisin so the bun was left feeling dry and overly bready. White bready. I tasted the pork from the bun on its own and, save for the hoisin, it didn't really taste like anything. 

The banh mi was lacking in several departments. The roll wasn't soft enough, for one. There was not enough sauce, and the predominant texture and flavor  of that sauce was mayonnaisey. Which means the pork was too dry and, again, flavorless. There were jalapeños on the sandwich but I suspect the seeds were removed because there wasn't even a hint of heat. The carrots were alright although I would've encouraged further pickling. All in all, though, a bummer.

I would not go back to Spice Kit and I would not recommend wasting a meal here when there are places like Saigon Sandwiches around. Sometimes putting a healthy, accessible-to-white-people spin on ethnic cuisine results in bland disaster and I'm afraid that's the case here.
author: C P.

description:
I've now been going here at least once a week, if not 2-3 times per week, and think it's the best thing going downtown for lunch.  Of all the styles they serve, my favorite is the salad (vs. Korean wrap and Vietnamese style sandwich) and my favorite meat is the beef, although the meatballs they have on Monday are quite tasty, too.  However, the best of the best is the pork bun - simply awesome.

I am soooo happy this place is so close to my current customer location - it's my lunch addiction.
author: Scott L.

description:
Fellow Yelpers, I don't really understand what the big hoo haw is about this joint. 

It was just too plain. Where was the flavor? If you're going to charge me $8 for BAHN MI, I was ready for my socks to be rocked. I left feeling like a kid who got tricked into eating some bland vegetables. 

Adding a star because the gents behind the counter were friendly... but reducing a star because I won't be making a repeat visit.
author: Izzy P.

description:
I was really looking forward to the opening of this place and was slightly disappointed. My friend and I both had the Korean Ssam with 5 spice chicken. The chicken was quite tasty, however, the rice was a bit mushy and there wasn't that much meat. It was overpriced for the amount of food given and you can get more bang for your buck at other neighboring restaurants. My friend and I were both still hungry after our wraps.
 
The iced coffee was very...very weak, almost water like. If you like your coffee strong, do not get it here. 

Overall, it's worth giving a try once since it is new to the hood and something different. However, I'm not sure if this place would be on my rotation for lunch options.
author: Anita L.

description:
Can I dock a star for an inappropriately named business? The name made me think "spicy" (weirdly enough) but the reality was significantly more pedestrian. Unless having bottles of Rooster sauce by the napkins is enough to make a place qualify for the name "Spice Kit". 

Yes, it's a bon mi/asian wraps place. And most of them are like $7-8. They aren't spicy or particularly big (small-ish even). The ingredients in there are quality but I'm missing the unhealthy slather of mayo, the sprigs of mint and/or cilantro, jalapenos etc.. It's all rather spare and minimalist and, I'm saying it, bland. 

The tenderloin is a few blocks away and it's scary. and gross. but there's a lot more than a few blocks decorated with public defecation and drug use separating Spice Kit from any number of hole in the wall bon mi shops over there. That separation is actual flavor (rather than just the local variety). It's not niman ranch blah blah but it's much tastier for less than half the price. I'll give up $$ for convenience but not flava. 

Spice Kit - the Chipotle of Vietnamese sandwich shops. Yes, that is a diss.
author: Milk N.

description: Ordered the chicken bahn mi,  the beef short ribs bowl and the vegetarian tofu wrap.   All items were delicious! Special thanks for being open on Saturdays.  Staff were very friendly.
author: Sameer B.

description:
After reading about Spice Kit in San Francisco Magazine and realizing it's just two blocks from my office I decided to check it out. 

Wow, Yelpers weren't kidding. They've knocked off Chipotle and created a Vietnamese rendition. 

I got a beef rib ssam, pork bun side and Vietnamese coffee. The ssam was like a bastard love child of the Chipotle ancestors of this place mated with a giant spring roll. Very tasty. I'd definitely get it again. The pork bun, however, was not my thing. It just tasted like empty carbs topped with an overwhelming flavor of grease.
author: Shoshana D.

description:
Only because this place is open for dinner did I check it out so soon after its opening. I pretty much avoid any new place with a lot of hype or anywhere with long lines of hungry and irritated people. Conceptually, this isn't new... Out the Door serves up pricey banh mi, spring rolls, and buns from farm fresh ingredients. 

I tried almost everything on the menu since I figured this won't be a regular lunchtime spot for me: chicken ssam, roast pork banh mi with pate, beef short rib banh mi, pork bun, lotus root chips. No real criticism from me other than the usual small portions for the price but that's not a surprise. Most of the food was tasty: meats were moist and seasoned well, love toasted baguettes, and the pate was delicious. The ssam was messy and didn't have enough chicken. It's like a big spring roll, goi cuon, with rice paper as wrapper. Why didn't they call it a Viet burrito or something; people love the Asian/Latin thing like the Korean taco. 

I like that Vietnamese food has become more mainstream and that American chefs are appreciating its complex flavors. They're not pushing this concept in San Jose where there's no way people would choose this over 50 other $2-3 banh mi shops ... they've open in a spot where FiDi workers are accustomed to paying $10 for a sandwich or salad. 

But with the buzz of SK's chefs, I'd like to see more come out of their huge kitchen. They're making food that Vietnamese ladies have been making with 10 square feet of sidewalk space for generations. There's so much more to Viet food than banh mi and pho. Would like to see what comes out of here next...
author: Mimi L.

description: It's like the Momofuku of San Francisco.  The pork belly bun is not cha siu baos but uses the buns that normally comes with the duck at Chinese banquets.  Coupled with green onions, cucumbers, and hoisin sauce, you may end up getting 3 double orders to go.  Warning, it isn't cheap at 2 pieces for $5 but a palmful of salty lotus chips went great with it for $1.50.  If you want something more filling, go for the saams.
author: Joyce Z.

description: Oh man -- I'm glad we went out of our way to find this place the last time we were in SF! I wish Spice Kit was in Dallas, TX! I am totally and absolutely obsessed with the pork belly buns and their lotus chips! I can eat that for breakfast, lunch and dinner EVERY day. No joke! I surprisingly fell in love with the thin, airy, crunchy lotus chips -- I was not expecting it to be so delicious! Can't wait to be back in SF!!
author: Sarath P.

description:
A totally solid lunch spot in the SOMA area near the financial district for anyone looking for clean Asian flavors.  My fiancee and I shared the banh mi-styled sandwich with the kalbi beef, the ssam pork wrap, as well as the super tasty pork buns(highly recommended!) along with the tasty lotus chips. The ssam wrap was an interesting fusion of a Vietnamese spring roll, Korean ssam (lettuce wrap), meets bi bim bap with the rice and Korean flavors.  It also makes it easier and cleaner to eat.

I definitely left feeling very satisfied by both the flavor and amount of food.  I'm sure this place will be a big hit with folks from Orrick and Blackrock (across the street), but I'll definitely make the hike from my office down here for lunch.
author: Josh H.

description:
I love, love, love Vietnamese sandwiches and can eat them almost every day if I could.  Hence why I was over the moon when my coworker told me about this brand-spankin' new restaurant nearby the financial district.

Spice Kit's founder once worked with Thomas Keller, and the chef spent the last few years cooking at The Dining Room (my favorite restaurant in the city).  With these big names, I held big expectations.

***

I was impressed immediately when I walked in and saw their menu.  They make it easy to understand for those unfamiliar with what to eat or how to order by providing 1-2-3 steps and appropriately detailed summaries for all food items.

I ordered Banh Mi with Five Spice Chicken, with additional pate.  Note: If you're not used to "foreign" ingredients or taste, do not request for pate (which is pretty much liver paste).

I must say -- from the moment I laid eyes on my sandwich to my very last bite, the whole experience was pretty exhilarating.  It was surprisingly tasty and authentic for a restaurant so far away from the "Little Saigon" in Tenderloin.

However, as delicious as it was, there was something slightly off from the usual Vietnamese sandwiches I've had.  After curing my curosity and re-tasting my other favorite Vietnamese sandwiches, my conjecture was that they just use a different recipe for their pickled carrots and daikon radish. 

Either way, I'm still a fan.  Though, be prepared to pay about double the price you would typically pay for your Banh Mi elsewhere.
author: Judy C.

description:
It has been awhile since I've had a home made bun, and I had high hopes for Spice Kit.  My friend ordered some of their pork buns and I had one of those, as well as the Thai Iced Tea.

The Thai Tea was good, nothing extremely out of the ordinary - the only mild complaint was that it may be a tad sweeter than I'm used to.  The bun, small and compact, was about $2.00.  It was tasty (the pork belly was delish) but alas went by too quickly.  Luckily I already had half a sandwich before, so I wasn't relying on a small bun as my whole meal.

Overall, I liked it.  The best in the world?  Mmm, not quite.  There are some kinks that they have to work on (the speed of fulfilling orders, for example -- they looked really stressed and there was a line despite the fact that it was after the lunch rush) and it'd be nice if portions were bigger.  

All in all, I'd recommend to at least stop and try the pork buns.
author: Shay F.

description: I had the short ribs banh mi and lotus chips.  It was the most disappointing working lunch I've had.  The short ribs were bland and dry in bread that was soft and stale.  The lotus chips were crisp but hinted of no flavor beyond frying oil.  Yes, "Eek! Methinks not" is appropos here.
author: Liz T.

description: Get the beef short rib bowl. The short ribs are tender and delicious. The kimchee rice is so yummy (bring mints or gums in case you've got to talk to someone after, it makes your breath reek!). Reasonably priced (~$8) for a big bowl of food. Gonna go back to try the roasted pork bahn mi.
author: Analisa S.

description:
So happy this place is just 1.5 blocks from my office!  We tried:  pork banh mi with the pate (the cashier recommended the pork filling to go with the pate); the mini steamed bun with grilled pork belly (like the Peking duck sandwiches you get at a Chinese banquet, but with luscious pork belly); tender beef short rib ssam (like a Korean burrito with rice paper wrapper), and ginger-peanut cabbage slaw.

Wow, it was seriously good.  You can really tell the difference in the quality of ingredients.  And the portions were good-sized.  I felt slightly embarrassed ordering a sandwich with a side of sandwich, especially when 3/4 of the men (financial district types) in line ahead of me were ordering salads.  Perhaps they indulged in these fantastic sandwiches/wraps the day before?
author: Jimmy G.

description:
Good... but not great.  You have to be in the right frame of mind to go here-- and I can't explain why I just said this statement.  

Went for lunch, found it expensive for the little amount of meat you get in the wrap.  Was very popular at lunch and they were fast.

Probably wouldn't return.  Not much more to say on this one.
author: Brian M.

description:
Love the 4-step menu/ordering process that's so reminiscent of Chipotle. Decide what vehicle you want for the meaty star of the show (options include the trappings of Korean burrito, Viet sandwich, salad, etc), choose your meat (chicken, pork, beef), and how clever is it that drinks and side are steps 3 and 4? Easily smoothing the process for you to pick up those extras and thus spend more. Combine the menu with the sleek aesthetic of the spacious, glass-walled interior, and Spice Kit reminds me a lot of another painfully hip and slightly overpriced FiDi lunch spot, Sushirrito. 

But that's not to say that I don't like Spice Kit. In fact, I'm very fond of their fresh and eclectic ingredients. The Korean burrito is wrapped in clear rice paper, and the salad features minced jicama and mango. Their breakfast sandwiches are tiny, but the smoked bacon they use is so rich and juicy that I thought it was duck at first. Due to the wide variety of healthy options on the menu and its surprisingly chic ambiance, Spice Kit is one of my favorite new lunch places in the city. Workers, liberate yourselves from the chains of Specialty's and head over to Spice Kit!
author: Angela X.

description: I go to Spice Kit for lunch occasionally because of its convenient location. The food is decent and consistent, but not as good as other Vietnamese places in SF (not to mention being overpriced for what it is). I usually get the rice bowl with chicken or pork, but find the marinated bean sprouts to be far too garlic-y. I've tried their breakfast items and like the steamed bun. I did not like the texture and flavor of their "Bacon and Egg" and their rice porridge. I've also tried their salad and wrap, but didn't like the texture of the wrap. I find the combination of ingredients in the salad and the dressing a little weird when it's all put together. I have not tried their sandwich out of principle because I feel it is too overpriced. I appreciate their effort with using organic and sustainable products, but their seasoning and flavor needs a little work.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Ordered the five spice chicken sandwich with pate and the pork sandwich.  The meat was good, pork better than chicken.  I LOVED how spicy it was- my mouth was definitely on fire. The coleslaw really makes the meal.  I would not have enjoyed it anywhere near as much without it.  However, I was bored of eating this meal half way through.  

Get the lotus chips.  These were delicious.
author: Jordan F.

description: Given the 3.5 stars, I didn't expect too much from this place, but I was pleasantly surprised.  We tried a pork wrap and a chicken banh mi and both were pretty good and the ingredients were fresh.  My only complain is that $7 for a banh mi is pricey.  It's probably cuz I'm used to banh mis for $4.  I guess I'm paying for location.  I am, however, more willng to pay $7 for the wrap since it's more unique.  I'd come back again if I was in the area and needed to grab a quick lunch.  It's nice that it's opened on a Saturday since most eateries in downtown area don't open on weekends.
author: Irene C.

description:
Spice Kit is the baby of french trained Asian chefs with backgrounds at Michelin Star establishments, like TFL and the Ritz, plus they serve up quality food fast, thus they get my full support as a restaurant and hopefully in the future as a chain(??) -- no one likes processed unhealthy fast food; quality food fast trumps over processed fast food any day! So come out and support Spice Kit; with growing support, Spice Kit can become the next (Asian-form of) Chipotle!?

As for their food, Spice Kit serves banh mi (Vietnamese sandwiches), ssam (Korean/Vietnamese wraps/spring rolls), and salads with your choice of Five Spice Chicken, Short Ribs, Roasted Pork, Vegetarian, or Roasted Pork Belly with their own respective prices $6-$8 (similar to Chipotle). They also have sides of lotus chips, slaw, and pork buns.

We had the roasted pork banh mi w/ extra pate (+$0.75), the short rib ssam, and the pork buns (2 for $5). They were sold out of the lotus chips :(

The banh mi (DISCLAIMER: I'm Vietnamese and can be a snob when it comes to Vietnamese food) was okay... the bread could have been a bit more toasted, the meat more flavorful, and the pate more complimenting (I would suggest passing on adding the pate, it doesn't add anything to the experience). I could have found yummier and cheaper else where but it was good for an Americanized attempt at authentic banh mi. 

The ssam (traditionally a Korean Wrap of meat&kimchi in lettuce) reminded me of an Asian burrito with Korean and Vietnamese influences.. it was cucumber, red leaf lettuce, rice, choice of meat, bean sprouts, kimchi, and some sauce in rice paper.. it was pretty satisfying and I would definitely get it again.

The pork buns were reminiscent of pecking duck but with grilled pork belly (which was cooked perfectly and tasted great!) and cucumbers, scallions, and hoisin sauce. Definite yum!

OVERALL, Spice Kit serves up great quality foods fast that cater to the 'American' palette, they're a great healthy alternative to your everyday McD's + associates, and you should come try them out/support them!
author: Lana N.

description:
Small menu, small portions, big price-tag. Not a solid combo, mis amigos.

I don't eat a lot, but that mini-bahn mi had me hungry two hours later and I think it cost $10 after tax. 

Go to the muffin place on 2nd for bahn mi! They're huge and $4.75. Now that's the ish I'm talking about!
author: Eli B.

description: These guys are simply wonderful. Affordable, consistently high-quality food - sure - but what's set Spice Kit apart in my mind are the individuals who work here. They're so nice and thoughtful. It makes coming here a real treat. I highly recommend Spice Kit to anyone looking for a quick, tasty meal.
author: Braden S.

description: Yum!   Its a great deal.  Delicious  food for a good price.  The veggies were fresh and the meat was tasty.
author: Myoung K.

description:
Nice concepts and easy menu but on the pricy side.  

I got the Five Spice Chicken Sandwich and it was ok.  Decent amount of chicken but the chicken was little bit dry and lack of flavors.  

The line was pretty long but moved very fast.  The services was efficient and friendly.
author: Liza T.

description: I just moved offices to this neighborhood and Spice Kit has quickly become my go-to lunch spot.  I've only had the five spice chicken (in both the wrap and the bowl), and they were both fantastic.  I don't feel the need to try anything else on the menu!  I've definitely got an addiction to the wrap and probably go there 2 times a week for lunch.  Definitely more of a grab-and-go spot, but for a quick lunch with great flavor, it doesn't get much better.
author: N L.

description: Nice ..well done place ...good Vietnamese S/wches and wraps ...with some fun combos built in. Pretty reasonable on the wallet as well.
author: ani n.

description:
we came here on a friday afternoon for lunch and the wait was at the door.  i hate waiting for food.  good thing is that once you order, the food comes out pretty quickly.  there are a lot of people working behind that counter!

i had a five spice chicken wrap.  i thought the rice paper tasted a little bit funny.  like chemically. or something.  cant really describe it.  the kimchi rice was spicy.  lettuce, cucumbers.  pretty decent.  its hard to eat it like a real spring roll though.  since its so big and thick, everything kept falling out.

bf got the pork sandwich, no pate.  it was decent but not exceptional.

i had a limeade but it was way too sweet and sour so i asked if i could put some tea into it.  the guy laughed at me.  i did it anyways at the fountain.

the pork buns are 2 for $5 and are pretty tasty.  probably the highlight of the meal.
author: claudia y.

description:
I had the Monday Meatball bahn mi special.  The meatball is flavorful, but it's kinda mushy?  I don't really like mushy meat.  

I also had the viet/korean rice paper wrap, which is pretty good.  I wish they would use more gouchi jiang (the korean think pepper paste) in the rice to make it spicier.  The pork is pretty good.  

I'm going to try a pork bahn mi next time.
author: Wendy S.

description:
Got the Roasted Pork Banh Mi for lunch the other day and the 2 star caption says it best, "Meh. I've experienced better." 

I'm not from the city so I don't know what else is around...so if you are craving a Banh Mi and there isn't much to choose from, then yes, Spice Kit was totally edible. There was nothing *bad* about the banh mi, but there was nothing electrifyingly delicious about it either.

But, I do have to say, the peeps who worked there were pretty nice and my friend who I met for lunch works nearby and a bunch of her coworkers were there...so, pretty popular??
author: Jeanette L.

description:
Great lunch!  It's a little pricy for lunch, but it's worth paying a little more for great ingredients ($10 total).

I tried the short rib Ssam (rice paper wrap).  It was a prefect portion of rice, kimchi, cucumbers, and very tender beef cubes.  It was so nicely flavored.  This is a great alternative to a burrito, when you're looking for something lighter.  I also tried the lotus chips, which were incredible.  Yum!!!

Can't wait to try the other meats!  The staff was very efficient and friendly, especially for their second day of business.  There was one woman walking down the line just to see if clients had questions.  She even checked in with me afterwards to see what I ordered.  So nice and welcoming.  This is a great addition to the area!
author: Stephanie R.

description:
Can i reiterate the fact that the food here is great! Try the Bahn Mi and of course add the home made pate.  I love food and high quality ingredients and the fact that they were able to package organic Niman Ranch products into street style food really shows a dedication to high quality ingredients.

No mystery meat in these sandwiches!

My personal favorite is the 5 Spice Chicken Bahn Mi with Lotus Chips.  The lotus chips are very very addicting.  I also like the taste of their freshly made Lime-Aid.  I have tried the Ssam and the kimchee within the Ssam is perfectly marinated to perfection.  

Good job on the sustainability as well!  Recycled Corn Products!  LOVE IT!
author: Patrick T.

description:
Co-worker aptly dubbed this Chipotle for Vietnamese food...so accurate, down to the menu style and decor.

1. Pick what form your food should come in - sandwich, rice paper wrap, salad
2. Pick a meat/filling - chicken, short ribs, pork, tofu

I got the sandwich with roasted pork, which was good but not amazing. The meat was juicy but a little bland and the picked veggies were a bit overpowering. Bread nice and flaky though.

So yeah, it's a Vietnamese Chipotle - cute concept, minimalist decor, appeals to the masses. And just like Chipotle, this place feels like a quick fix that will probably leave you craving something a little more authentic, creative, and flavorful.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Man, I wanted to give you five stars, I really do BUT 3 stars will do, hear me out.

I called in to order my lunch, got hung up. So i had to call back. I had ordered several things for the office and i, and when my coworker went to pick it up, I was so excited for my FIVE SPICE CHICKEN SALAD, but was disappointed because i ended up getting...........a Organic Tofu Salad, which is okay, i mean, it's fine, tasty...... but i wanted THE FIVE SPICE CHICKEN SO BADLY. :'''''[


ugh, maybe next time i will be able to try the tasty five spice chicken everyone talks about. 

Until then, sorry, 3 stars.

****I WENT BACK FOR THE 5 SPICE CHICKEN!
AND IT WAS AMAZING +1 STAR ;]
author: Liberty C.

description:
Spike Kit was a dream come through for our wedding!
Long story short, I was so obsessed with their Banh Mi (running out of my way during lunch to get one 2-3 times a week) that I begged them to do the catering at our casual wedding reception. They were very reasonably priced, super easy to work with and very professional. Best of all people RAVED about the food at my wedding, and I served sandwiches ;) Best idea ever. Thanks guys.
author: Lindsey W.

description:
Really good. TRY THE PORK BUNS!!! 

I haven't tried other pork buns places but its really good. I also had the pork banh mi which wasn't bad with the fresk liver pate. Its fresh its healthy and its delicious. I would love to come back and try more.  I can do without so many pickled veggies though.
author: KK M.

description: Delicious! Best Vietnamese iced coffee in all of SF, I have had the banh mi, the bowl, and the wrap, all amazing - fresh ingredients and filling meals. I love the short rib, and sometimes I get the pork (also amazing, but short rib is one of my all time faves). Try the appetizer pork buns, they are also just mouthwatering good.
author: Alex B.

description:
Can't help but crave going to Spice Kit when I'm in the financial district area for meetings.  I typically don't like eating by myself, but I'll come here because the food is just that delicious!  My husband loves the marinated short rib bahn mi with pate, but I always get the marinated short rub ssam with extra peppers.  YUM!  I get a pork bun side when I go for weekday dinners.  

I rarely give 5 stars, but I gave them to Spice Kit because I can't find another good substitute (no, not even Saigon Sandwich).  The combination of high quality ingredients (Nieman Ranch beef, locally sourced stuff), mouth-watering gourmet Vietnamese and Korean flavors, and friendly service is unparalleled.  While some folks complain about paying $7 for a Vietnamese sandwich at Spice Kit and only $3.50 at hole-in-the-walls, I have to say that a hole-in-the wall Vietnamese sandwich place gave me food poisoning a few weeks ago and ruined my Saturday social plans.  I'd pay a couple of extra dollars any day to enjoy the sandwich, and not regret it later.  

For those who don't like to wait or live in Soma/financial district, I definitely suggest coming for a weekday dinner or Saturday lunch.
author: Grace K.

description:
Stopped by the other night for a quick bite.

A short rib banh mi (with pate, of course), a pork bun, and a vietnamese coffee for $15.  Can you get cheaper?  Definitely.  Can you get tastier?  Probably.  Can you get anything cheaper, tastier, AND made with fresh, organic ingredients?  Probably not.

Will definitely be stopping by again!
author: Maneesh B.

description:
I'd give Spice Kit 3.5 stars.  

For the price, the quality of the ingredients is high. I had the beef short rib in a bowl and the beef cubes were very good.  Tender and nicely seasoned.  Today it's Niman Ranch supplying beef, but not always.  It depends on the market, I was told.

The staff was really friendly and helpful.  We like them.

One quibble - why serve the bowl in a (compostable) plastic container and fork when dining in?  Seems wasteful.  And not too classy.  Why not a real plate and fork?  Cool plates could spice up the overly minimal design.  

I'd come back.  Tasty, healthy, fast, reasonably priced and impeccably clean.
author: ed c.

description: Our group came here to try the Bahn Mi sandwiches, but they ran out of bread!! It was barely 2pm! We all loved to Korean BBQ meat wrap and the cute really tiny pork buns. We enjoyed the Lotus chips too! The Thai iced tea was tasty but too much ice. It was a little pricey but overall we enjoyed our experience.
author: Chris G.

description: Upright 5 spice chicken salad but they only had one register open for the lunch rush. What's the deal? It took so long.
author: Luke M.

description:
OK, second time around the short ribs were still pretty damn tender and tasty, but I really can't get over the massive portions. More doesn't mean better. This time I tried the Banh Mi with Short Ribs and Pate. I was a little hesitant since it was a) fancy and b) way more expensive than Saigon Sandwich, but I thought I'd give it a shot. I mean, where else have I seen short rib banh mi?? 

The bread was kinda blah and reminded me of super toasted bread from Subway. Again, OVERKILL on the beef. I tasted more beef than anything else and the pate was pretty non-existent. 

BF got the Short Rib Ssam per my recommendation and I took a bite and just wasn't as into it this time around. I thought the rice was a little bland and it could have used something spicy or slightly acidic to brighten it up...perhaps some kimchi?

Bottom line - come to Spice Kit for the short rib ssam and savor the tender, flavorful, plentiful chunks of meat.
author: Karena Q.

description:
Pork bun, yum yum! The meat is so soft and tender. Short Ribs banh mi is a good choice as well. If you like meat, you will love it. 

And you have to try the lotus chips! Taste better than the regular potato chips for sure.
author: Eugene K.

description:
This place is like an Asian-inspired Chipotle. 

The set up of the restaurant (more like a fast food restaurant) had big plastic placards above the cash register listing the types of meat you could get, and how it would be served (in a rice paper wrapper like a burrito, over a salad, or in a banh mi). 

I ordered the marinated short rib in a banh mi.
Suggestion to the chefs: Cut the meat into smaller pieces please! I love that the short rib was nice and tender and had lots of delicious fat all over it, but the size that the meat was cut was just too large. It made it a little difficult to eat and after eating half of the banh mi, I gave up and gave the other half of the sandwich to my friend. 

For the sides, we got the pork belly bun and the lotus chips. The lotus chips were just like potato chips - I don't think there was anything that special about them. BUT the pork belly bun - that was pretty good. it was packed full of flavor and very enjoyable to munch on. 

Parking was really easy to find - we parked right in front of the place. Only thing, is that it's metered. Bring quarters! Or you can walk/bike.
author: Julia K.

description:
Ordered a bahn mi with roasted pork and pate on half, taro chips, and a pork bun.

The roasted pork is like a bland pork chop, cooked rare, then cut into 3/4 inch cubes. Not a lot of flavor and occasionally you get big chunks of almost crunchy fat. I'm far from a bahn mi authority but the way the meat was cooked, seasoned (or not), and cut seemed wrong. Also, there was far too much meat for the sandwich. I appreciate generous portions, but this was way too far.

The bread is great, as are the other ingredients. The half with the pate was better than the one without, so there's that.

The taro chips were fine. Not crisp though, like they'd been sitting for a couple hours already (went at 1:30pm).

The pork bun was pretty good, though I wish I had gotten some of the fat other people have mentioned. For what you can find in the area it was damn good, but there are several far better alternatives in The City.

All in all, a solid meh. I'm not kicking myself for eating there but I doubt I'll do it again. There are alternatives in the area which, though far less interesting, are less expensive and just as average.
author: John C.

description:
The wait for a non-mobile pork belly bun solution is over!

With all of the hype this SOMA newbie was getting, I was quite excited to get the chance to try it out in it's first week.  The pork belly bun is decent.  I still prefer Chairman Bao's, but at least if I get a hankering, I don't have to troll John Collins to wait for a truck to come around.  

Solid short rib banh mi.  I can definitely say I was impressed.  Typically, I don't like too much mayo or meat in my Vietnamese sandwiches, but it went well with this one.  I guess that's kind of the nature of it.  Forgo the pate!  Though it's house made, I think it's overkill with the beef - it might be better with the roasted pork.  The cashier and expo guy tried to convince me that the roasted pork was a better sando... let me save you guys the time.  It's not.  I've had better at a proper banh mi shop.  Also got to try the spiced chicken saam wrap - definitely skip this one.  It was kind of bland and very, very generic.

So to summarize, the only thing worth going out of your way for is the short rib banh mi, sans pate.  Not bad for a SOMA lunch that doesn't involve a 15 minute wait in line.
author: Virginia L.

description: So friendly and informative. Gave me a great suggestion. Why isn't this place more packed??? Went with short ribs wrap. Wish portions were a bit bigger, which is the only thing stopping that one star. But can't wait to try breakfast!
author: Thach N.

description: Tried the five spice chicken here and it was just really dry and flavorless. Was really hoping for a tasty Bahn mi but there was no flavor beyond the dry chicken,  pickled carrots and peppers. The Thai iced tea was standard and for $7 bucks it's a really expensive Bahn mi.
author: Kentaro F.

description:
Truthfully, I had low expectations when I entered the restaurant. But when I took the 1st bite I was wrong. The food was delicious! I ordered the banh mi with the pate and pork, and a side of the lotus chips.  The meat was very flavorful and soft.  The pate was smooth and rich. And the lotus chips were OMG. I usually see lotus served in a Chinese soup and never knew it could be made as a chip.

I also got to try the ssam and that was good, but I liked the sandwich a lot more.  The owner gave me a pork bun for free. I thought it would be one of those pork buns you find in dimsum restaurant, but instead it was like those peking duck buns that you get at Chinese banquets. I was very pleased.  

I can't wait to take my wife here the next time I go to the city.
author: Eric T.

description: Awesome! Got the korean rice bowl, sans the kimchi since I don't like spice. I got it with kalbi beef and an egg and it's delicious. They have healthier options like brown rice but I like my white rice! Veggies are great and really freshen up the bowl. Great sized portion!
author: Maje A.

description:
CASING THE JOINT:
Was around the fidi/soma and found this banh mi shop from yelp. I walked in to a board with $7-9 banh mi sandwiches and almost walked right out, given Saigon Sandwiches' $3 sandwiches which taste great and are a bargain to boot.

THE SCORE: 
Deciding I'd never try it if I didn't tidy, I go for the short rib ban mi. Sounds succulent, 24 hour braising, marinated, the works. $8.75 after tax. Sticker shock, but holding judgment. Then I go or the $1.50 lotus chips, I'm a sucker for anything new.

THE GETAWAY: A try at upscale vietnamese banh mi. Unfortunately it's just overpriced banh mi. The extra $3-5 dollars you pay for a sandwich ($7-9, versus $3.50 from a banh mi in the loin) seems to help subsidize the fidi location as well a the clean modern looking interior, rather than truly originally delicious ingredients. 

The lotus chips are worth a $1.50 if you're here already, but they don't have any inherent lotus taste. Just really greasy salted chips (deep-fried, thin). 

Better yet, save your dollars for something else. 

If you're in the area and genuinely nothing else calls out to you, give it a try. But don't say I didn't say there are much better options and banh mi options in the city.
author: Eric C.

description:
Spice Kit is presently located at the top of a long list of lunchables for me, and I just consider myself lucky to have found it.  After spending a year and half working in the culinary wasteland that is San Mateo, I was transferred to an office in the financial district.  My (lunch) future's so bright, I've gotta wear bibs!  

Spice kit is a treasure.  Historically, I've passed on the Vietnamese sandwich.  I'm just not a big sandwich guy.  When you decrease the cleanliness factor and add some carrots and cucumbers as per the norm at most purveyors, my midday gusto becomes something akin to George Costanza after a cold swim.  (I was in the pool!)  Spice kit goes a different route, following a model reminiscent of chipotle.  You choose your meat from either Chicken, Short Rib, Pork or Veggie and then decide if you want a Bahn-mi (sandwich), ssam (wrap), bowl or salad.  There are couple other options, but they keep it pretty straightforward.  Thank you Chipotle model!  

My first encounter with the bahn-mi, was predominately shaped on recommendation.  It was a delicious French roll, topped w/ greens, sliced jalapeno, chicken, cucumber, carrots, cilantro and a little mayo.  I added the optional Pate.  I'm not even sure how to describe it.  Pure delicious.  The chicken is just the right warmth to slightly heat up the veggies so that everything is that perfect temp a sandwich should be and all the different flavors come together well.  I like adding a little sri-racha to kick things up a touch.

The real gem though is the ssam, which is the lovechild of a spring roll and a burrito.  Check it:   rice paper wrap, red leaf lettuce, kimchi, marinated sprouts, rice, cucumber and your choice of meat filling.  At first, I thought it sounded crazy, but it was so DAAAMNED good.  I will be returning for seconds shortly.  

Oh, and if you just want a delectable little taste - go for the pork bun which features a deliciously creamy piece of pork belly on a tasty bun.  Enjoy!!
author: Chad K.

description: Had the Pork Bahn-Mi,  it was good.  The carrots were a tad bit too pickled for me.  But the Bread was perfect, which so many sandwich places fail to get right.  I really enjoyed the sandwich.  Price was only ok, would love to see it for $1 less.
author: Allan H.

description:
"Yay! I'm a fan." True of my feelings about Spice Kit. I'm a fan, though I wasn't blown away. 

Had 5 spice chicken ssam (wrap) and lotus chips for $9.20. Wrap was large, delish, and had plennnty of tasty chicken. Lotus chips claim to be "lightly salted" but were actually over salted . Please fix that, Spice Kit. Otherwise, fresh ingredients, quick service, but slightly pricey. Next time I won't get a side.
author: Loren R.

description:
So, I would've taken a picture of my sandwich for Yelp, but it was too delicious and I ate it!

My knowledgable co-worker mentioned a new Vietnamese lunch place just opened nearby the office, and that we should leave at 11:30am to beat the line.  (He was right, as soon as we ordered the line was out the door and then some.)

I had the Banh Mi (french baguette with radish, cucumber, cilantro and jalapeno) with braised tofu and it was quite tasty.  I especially enjoyed the spicy kick from the jalapeno.

Yes, $7 is a bit pricy, but for my money, totally worth it.
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
I love Vietnamese bahn mi sandwiches, am obsessed with pork belly *oink*, and Korean ssams bring a smile to my face. All this said, I suppose it's no surprise that I totally dig Spice Kit.

After a long drive up from Los Angeles, I swung by for a late lunch with my man. Though they're located in the Soma/Financial District of SF, they're open til 3pm on Saturdays...

The beef short rib bahn mi with pate we ordered was delicious. I loved the mayo, and the meat was good, but watch out for the slices of hot peppers. They're SPICEy :)

Even better? A Korean-Vietnamese pork ssam wrap. The presentation was beautiful and unexpected. But more importantly, the hearty wrap was delicious and satisfying.

Finally, my favorites: Spice Kit's lotus chips (as tasty as they are beautiful) and uber-scrumptious mini pork buns.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. My favorite thing on their menu! The combination of thinly-sliced pickles with tender pieces of pork belly is killer. ORDER THESE!

Nice clean minimalist decor. I wish I worked in the Orrick building. I swear I'd eat a bun a day...
author: Debra C.

description: I love this place!  I go to Spice Kit several times a week; generally, the bowls are great. On Tuesdays and Thursdays they have a special Vietnamese bowl I wish they offered as a regular part of the menu.  The food is affordable and great for lunch.  I did go to the restaurant once as it was preparing to close and on that one occasion the rice was hard, as though it had been stuck to the bottom of the pan.  Fortunately, I've always liked rice this way so it was a plus rather than a detractor.  I'm disappointed Spice Kit only has 3.5 stars on Yelp! because I find my experience there delicious.
author: Marvin P.

description:
Not impressed.

There was the hype and the SF foodie article, but Spice Kit missed its mark.
