Softer baguettes and special meat do not justify spending $5 more than what I'd normally spend at a majority of other Vietnamese sandwiches I can get elsewhere (especially in the south bay).  Mentioning the meat, I got the short rib, which was tender, but not marinated enough to be special.  Also, with all the Vietnamese sandwiches I've eaten in my day, there's a lot more jalapenos (I had 1) and other produce, without the dousing of mayonnaise to compensate.  Now don't get me wrong..I love mayo, but feel it's not as necessary nor does it add a lot of value to a banh mi.  

Oh, and to add insult to injury, I also am compelled to pass along feedback that the wraps fell apart too easily and that it was difficult to eat.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Bland. Overpriced. Boring.

Go down a few streets to Muffins Muffins on 2nd for cheap(er) Vietnamese sandwiches.

This place blows. The chicken sandwich is $7+ and is really dry and bland - absolutely no spice in the "peppers" - the sauce is just mayo. Hardly any cilantro. There really is no reason at all to pay this high price for a Vietnamese sandwich. I was really disappointed. They claim to be fancy chefs...but their food doesn't reflect this at all  in my opinion.

The atmosphere is a total Chipotle knock-off.

I won't be coming back to this place.
author: Chili B.

description:
Stopped by here per recommendation of a friend for a snack break: pork belly bun, lotus chips, and a Vietnamese iced coffee all for just under $8. 

1) Pork Belly Bun ($2.95) -- it's basically like a slightly larger version of a peking duck steamed bun stuffed with two moderately sized pork belly slices, sauced up with a hoison-type sauce, and sprinkled with scallions. The bun is SO soft, just as all steamed chinese-esque buns should be :). The pork belly is super tender and fatty, and the delicate flavors simply complement each other quite nicely. 

It's a bit pricey for what it is...but, it's really tasty,  and I'm pretty impressed with the concept of selling it as a snack! So major props to the owners. 

2) Lotus chips ($1.50) - underwhelmed and disappointed by this one. They're just so thinly sliced, fried, and salted that there's just no flavor profile of the lotus present. It's just greasy shards of salt. Sadly, I did not finish my serving...I'd imagine it would be much more exciting if they tried deep frying thicker cuts to enhance what it is. Maybe like...Lotus fries! 

3) Vietnamese Coffee ($2.95) -- Authentically made, with the condensed milk and all :). TOTALLY a reward after the sweaty trek from work on a hot day! + The caffeine fix!

ALL in ALL: Get 2 pork belly bun (for $5) and a Vietnamese Coffee. Annddddd you'll be set :).

~PS: I think this place would be a great food truck.
author: Gail N.

description:
Went here for Ssam kolbi wrap.  Pretty damn good.  Could use some more spice in there, luckily they have siracha to pick up the slack.  The meat is really really good. 

Tried the ginger peanut slaw, kind of disappointed.  Not bad but just not the big flavor I know this place is capable of.  I'm still a big fan of this place. 

My friend enjoyed the tofu.  Hell, if you can make tofu good you've got my vote.
author: Mike I.

description:
Good first lunch experience today at Spice Kit. 

The place is new (I think...) and right across the road from my office -- that doesnt hurt -- and it seems to be very popular already (or maybe, in part, today,  people were using it as a refuge from the crazy rains we've been having.)

They have a simple menu, where you "build" your lunch from bread/salad/wrap + ingredients + extras, based loosely on Vietnamese sandwich places. I chose the French Roll, with Pork and Pate (interestingly...). The result was a very satisfying, very full, slightly spicy sandwich. I didnt really detect the pate, but the pork was plentiful and succulent.  Good sandwich! Not cheap, at around $9.00, but probably on a par with other nearby downtown lunch places.
author: donal c.

description:
Probably one of the better soma lunch spots.

You only need to know one thing, pork bahn mi with the pate. A side of lotus chips, and a lime-ade and you have an excellent lunch. The pork is deliciously marinaded, the veggies, bright and tasty. Chips, crispy, light and a nice change from potato. (also look cool)

The interior is that of almost chipotle-level stylistic sterility, but it's airy, and pleasant for lunch. The line was short, and moved quickly, so I suspect the decore is what's holding it back, since the food is great. There's places outside to eat on nice days.
author: Boris C.

description: Pretty decent Korean BBQ rice bowl for lunch. Clean inside. Diversifies FiDi's lame options. Not enough seating inside, but we came on MLK day and it was empty since no one was working that day.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Came here for the first time last week and am going back today. Good simple ingredients. I got the ssäm with short ribs and a couple of pork buns. both were delicious and the proce was right. I think I will try the same today, but in a bowl instead.
author: Scott D.

description:
Stopped by this place last weekend after hearing a lot about it in the blogosphere and the SF Mag profile.  Have to say that the food was as good as it's been hyped.  I had the pork buns to start which were very similar to Momofuku as a point of comparison for those who have had the chance to try that NYC must-eat.  Porky deliciousness.  Tender meat with a good sauce to compliment the flavor.

Next I had the pork banh mi with pate.  Can't get enough of that pig, I guess.  Also really really good.  I have to say, I don't normally like the taste of cilantro in my banh mi's but I actually liked it here.  The whole flavor profile was very well-rounded with the perfectly cooked pork and the crunchy accoutrements (pickles, julienned daikon and carrots) to the sandwich.  All in all, a perfect banh mi IMHO.

My wife had the lotus chips and ssam and liked her meal too.  I had a few of the lotus chips and they were quite good.  Nice crispy chips with a good crunch.

The whole experience was great and the food made it definitely worth going back to the next time I stop by SF.
author: Keith C.

description:
TWO WORDS: PORK BUNS

These cute little suckers are like Peking Duck except with Pork Belly. They come in the usual Peking Duck white bun with green onion and plum sauce. Absolutely DELICIOUS. I'm totally bummed that I only got one. The Vietnamese sandwich was just so-so. It was too big, for one thing (oh Americans love their super-sized food). And it really wasn't all that special, considering that the founder used to be at French Laundry. Anyway, PORK BUNS. Get them.

4 stars for the pork buns
3 stars for the vietnamese sandwich
author: Samantha C.

description:
Came here for lunch one day.  Place is super clean, staff is friendly and the wait is not too long.  The menu is like an Asian style Chipotle, 5 different ways to eat it, 4 different kids of meats/vegetables and a few sides if you want to add to your order.  I've only tried the beef short ribs in both wrap (rice paper wrap with kimchi, rice, bean sprouts and lettuce) and salad form.  The wrap I am absolutely hooked on.  The beef short ribs are cooked medium rare so it still retains the juicy meat flavor and has a good bite to it.   I love the texture of the rice paper and the combination of crunchy, spicy and salty flavors of the wrap.

Spice Kit will be part of the routine lunches, I can just keep going back for the wrap.
author: Yun W.

description:
love the steam pork bun. it had lots of flavor and i didn't get the fat that was mentioned in other reviews. 

lotus chips were delicious as well. thickness of the chip was spot on and it was seasoned the right amount. 

if i had another stomach, i would have gotten a beef sammich to go. i tried a bite of my friends sammich; the beef was tender, juicy and the flavor was on point. 

the thai ice tea drink i got wasn't as sweet as i'm accustomed to. whenever i get it at a boba shop, hk cafe or asian supermarket; it's pretty damn sweet. add more sweet please!!!

the wrap was very filling. it's as big as it looks in the pictures. the pork was tender and packed flavor, but i wish i ordered it with beef instead. i'm a beef fan, i should have went with my gut instinct. 

minus one star for the price
11 bucks for a wrap and drink. really?
author: Jerald C.

description: The soy marinated tofu salad was good and came with mango, peanuts, and radishes. The lotus chips were light and crispy. I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here but great if you need to grab a quick bite to go.
author: Debbie C.

description:
I am a huge fan of banh mi - there is something beautiful about the combination of a sandwich filled with Asian goodness. Ever since I saw Spice Kit's menu options, I had obsessed over the thought of trying one of these delicious little creations with Kalbi style BEEF SHORTRIBS! Not that anything ever sounds bad with beef shortribs.

Knowing my husband is a big fan as well, we headed over to Spice Kit this weekend. I tried (what else but) the beef shortrib banh mi with pate and the pork buns. So yummy! The portions are on the smaller side but that motivated me to eat more slowly and really savor each bite. The sandwiches had just the right amount of filling and the bread wasn't too crusty, which I hate at some other places. The pork buns were even better than I had expected and were also adorable to look at...always a plus!

If I'm in the neighborhood, I will definitely be going back. I already have a feeling I'll be ordering exactly the same thing again next time... Why change a good thing?
author: Foodie K.

description:
It was just A-OK for me.  Decided on a whim to come try this place as it came highly recommended by a good friend.  They know that I'm a kimchee lover and had previously tried the Korean Wrap here.  

We ordered via telephone ahead of time and good thing that we did!  When we got here there was an insane line out the door and I got to walk right up to the counter to pick up the food.  We got the Chicken Korean Wrap and Beef Short Rib Bowl to share. I think my favorite thing was the Beef Short Rib.  The kimchee was not quite kimchee enough for the Korean Wrap.  

I would definitely not make a special trip out here for food but may give it another try if I am in the area.
author: Stella C.

description: My office catered a lunch with Spice Kit so I tried a salad, banh mi with the 5 spice chicken and the roasted pork.  It was so good I want to go to the real place to see the whole menu.  Im predicting I'll be obsessed.
author: C W.

description:
My new favorite FiDi lunch spot.  First time (party of 2) we had the lotus chips, 2 pork buns, and the chicken ssam.  Great overall.  Chicken was the weakest link - spice wasn't quite right to my taste buds - but I'm willing to try it again.  Second time through was the beef in salad form and the special of the day - meatball wrap.  The beef is so tender and they really jazz up the salad nicely.  Filling.  The meatballs were fantastic.  I hope they have this special again sometimes soon.  

Washed it down with a cup of (powerful) thai ice tea both times.  Will visit again, soon.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
I'm so so about this place.  In between 2-3 stars, but went with the 2..

I like the idea, I like a lot of the flavors, but what I have a problem with is the meat.  Sometimes the meat is just gross.
I stopped getting the short rib, because it's gross.
The chicken is hit or miss, and the pork was okay the one time I had it.
The fried chicken is always good (Which they have Wednesdays and Fridays).
The sahm bowl is nice, it comes with rice that is seasoned with Korean red pepper paste, the salad is actually pretty flavorful, and the bahn mi is good (albeit expensive, but you're in the fidi, deal with it).
author: YJ P.

description:
Met up with my brother for lunch here one day.  We ordered a beef short rib ssam and a pork banh mi w/ pate.  The short ribs are definitely the way to go here.  The meat is flavorful and tender, though the ssam was a bit hard to eat at times.  

The pork bun is also just ok.  The pork belly was cooked and had a great tender texture, but it came across as bland.  Same goes for the pork banh mi.  

I can see myself coming back here to get the shortribs.  If they can up the flavor on the pork dishes, I'd definitely come back!
author: Naoko M.

description: I LOVE their short rib wrap and lotus chips. My cousin and I call it "the healthy burrito." There's a lot wrapped up in this ginormous asian burrito. Perfectly cooked short rib, rice and various pickled veggies rolled up in a rice wrap. It's a little on the pricey side, but well worth it.
author: Adelina W.

description:
Great sandwiches and side salads. Very tasty, quickly and freshly prepared, and not too insanely priced.  The chicken was better than the pork for me but I'm just being picky. It's all good. 

This will enter into my rotation of work lunch places.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Spice Kit is in my building, so the convenience factor is a HUGE plus for me.  That said, this place is good.  A bit pricey, but hey, it's the financial district.  Here's my grading of what I've tried:

Banh Mi Pork Sandwich: A-.  Solid.  Pork is flavorful and cooked well.  Make sure you add the pate... they give you a lot of it, and it adds so much flavor.

Vietnamese Coffee: B. Could be much stronger... a bit watered down.  And a bit too sweet.  

Lotus chips: B+.  Tad too salty, and they scrimp on the portions, but they are nonetheless delicious.

Thai iced tea: A-.  Rich flavor, but a bit too sweet.
author: suzanne l.

description:
I checked out this place's website and was pretty excited about it but fairly disappointed.
Pork bun- $2 is fine, but the bread was soggy by the time I got the takeout back to my house (20 minutes) and basically disintegrated.  The pork itself was too fattya nd not that flavorful.  
Ssam with korean beef- the beef itself was tender and flavor was ok, but the wrapper was too thick and chewy.  Perhaps I was already ruined by reading another yelper's comment that it tasted like an old condom.  ewwww.
Lotus chips were ok but nothin special- don't know why some people rant and rave about them.  
This place has the potential to be really good, but so far just isn't there yet.
author: Maxine S.

description:
OMG! The pork buns were DELISH!!! when i read the description I was skeptical. I love pork bun you know a bun with some pork in it and steamed. But these had pickled cucumbers um ok... I tried them anyways and they were soo good!!! The bun was cut in half and then they had the pork in them and the cucumbers. so like a tiny sandwich.  Um yea! My new fave! 

Went with 4 male co-workers. They all agreed it was great! We definitely put it on our eat here once a week list. Add did i mention they were full off a wrap and 1 pork bun! Pretty good!!

Warning- it's not cheap- it's going to come out to about $12 a person which is expensive if you are used to a $2.50 Vietnamese sandwich ( Banh mi), but of you are used to over priced food in SOMA- then you won't get sticker shock. 


I gave it 3 stars cause of price ( a lil high) and it was FREEZing outside where we sat. Um can we get some heat lamps? Just saying
author: Mariana M.

description:
If you think of it as a regular sandwich, then it's pretty good.  If you think of it as a banh mi, it's kind of weird and expensive.  Unlike other banh mi, the meat comes in chunks rather than slices.  Pate is extra, but necessary to ward off blandness.

I'll try the ssam next time.

The pork buns, though richly flavored, aren't what Asians would call pork buns, per se.  They are basically a peking duck, hoisin, cucumber and scallion sandwich in a mantou (steamed bread), substituting grilled pork belly for the duck.  Though undeniably tasty, the use of pork belly is an incredibly safe choice these days.

Lastly, the calamansi/line cooler tastes like Ecto Cooler (a.k.a. Shoutin' Orange Tangergreen) by Hi-C, a tangerine-lime flavored drink.  Calamansi are apparently a hybrid of limes and tangerines.  Coincidence?
author: Suo L.

description: I love their salads, the buns, and the sandwiches.  Can't go wrong with any of those choices.  Also love Vietnamese iced coffee, super sweet and super yummy!
author: Dagny C.

description: Nice outdoor seating, presentation is nice but the food doesn't have flavor.  I'd recommend the slider food truck parked across the street.
author: M W.

description:
I could go with 3.5 to 4 stars.

I went here for lunch today and had the pork spare ribs bahn mi with side of lotus chips.  I recently discovered lotus chips while having dinner at B Star and loved them.  The chips at Spice Kit were also good, but I found a few that weren't as crispy as the rest.  They are so pretty and delicate with a flavor that is great.

The sandwich was tasty.  I added the optional housemade pate which was totally worth it.  What can I say?  I'm a sucker for pate.  I guess the only hard thing about this place is that an $11 lunch for sandwich and side seems like a lot when you go to Saigon in the TL and get the same (or similar) for less than $5.  I get that Spice Kit is using local and sustainable ingredients, which I appreciate, even more than your average Bay Area foodie, but the price tag for this would only survivie in the FiDi.  

Don't get me wrong - the food was great.  I'm just not sure I'll be a regular.  I'll go back at least once more to try the pork buns and the Vietnamese iced coffee for sure.
author: Annalea I.

description:
My husband brought me home the roasted pork banh mi, grilled pork belly bun, and beef shortrib ssam and I loved it!

He bought some again today! Can't wait!
author: Jacqui A.

description: Awesome Bahn Mi here. Check out my review, complete with mouth-watering pictures on my blog here! http://joeatsf.wordpress.com/2013/03/12/spice-kit/
author: Joseph F.

description: I really love this place. The flavors are spot on without being overly spicy. My three-year-old daughter usually shares whatever I am eating and gobbles it up. It's great when I can find quality food that is effortless to get her to eat also.
author: Joanna H.

description:
Coming from SJ I know that I can get a pretty damn good banh mi for around $3.50 each. Paying $7+ for a smaller version of basically the same product seems a little crazy to me. I mean the foods good and all but I can go to thanh huong or if I'm really desperate I can go to Lee's but unfortunately I'm lazy to get food and bring it to work so this place will do. I did like the pork bun however...reminds me of some good chinese cooking.

Spice Kit is to viet sandwiches as Panda Express is to Chinese food and Chitpotle to Mexican....white-washed.
author: phil c.

description:
Living next to Little Saigon, I guess I'm just used to paying a few bucks for a Vietnamese sandwich. That said, I think I'll go to Spice Kit for the same reasons I'll go to Chipotle. I can get real ass bahn mi for much less whenever I want (pending my bravery), but this is much more the downtown/SOMA excursion joint for me. 

I had the short rib because, well, when else do I get the short rib? It was actually pretty decent. Did not taste like a tire, like someone warned me. Not sure where that came from. Otherwise, not a ton of seating, but on a nice day, that shouldn't be a problem. Staff was super friendly, the floors, surprisingly immaculate.
author: Roy M.

description: The burritos they have this weird vietnamese spring roll wrap around them on a spring roll it's not that bad but when you're holding this massive thing in your hands it feels incredibly weird...  Like really really weird, I tend to just open the damn thing and devour the insides.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Just plain awesome. 

Got the five spice chicken banh mi with pate (don't forget to add pate! you have to ask for it) - and a steamed pork belly bun on the side. Both were amazing - the ingredients were fresh, flavors bright and everything was perfectly executed including really yummy bread in both the sandwich and bun.

I noticed some other customers ordering the Ssams (Korean wraps) - I thought they would be small like a summer roll but they're huge like burritos! Totally wanna try one of those guys next time.
author: Teo W.

description:
The food is yummy, and the quality of the ingredients is high, but golly, the prices at Spice Kit are enough to scare anyone away.   

I will give them props for their take on the pork bun (think instead pork belly slider).  Tasty piggy tucked between a gooey, steamed pork bun-bun.   At 2 for $5, they are probably the best deal for a lunch time bite.  

I applaud the Kit's effort for trying to take the humble Vietnamese sandwich uptown.  That said, similar if not better Bahn Mi can be had at half the cost throughout the city.
author: Pat W.

description:
Good meat filled banh mi's!  The beef short rib and pork sandwiches are both filled with savory marinated chunks of meat.  The pickled veggies are done right and the french bread is both crisp and soft.  

Aside from those strong points, this is where Spice Kit deviates from the typical Vietnamese banh mi, a sandwich that originally was centered around value.  The pate should be inclusive and not be a 75 cent upgrade.  The price is double of what a banh mi goes for.  They should demand more for the quality meats used, but double?  Maybe if the prices were 2 dollars less, their popularity would be soar.
author: MTBer I.

description:
Insanely tasty street food; I go for lunch at least once a week. Pork belly = breathtaking. Sandwiches = perfection.  Salad with roasted chicken = a healthy, zingy lunch time experience.

I had one bad experience, a few months ago. It was a Saturday, just before closing. I ordered a salad to go, but the greens were soggy. Next time I went I mentioned this to the owner, and he gave me lunch on the house - now THAT is a sign that they take their customers seriously.
author: Gavin Y.

description:
Should've consulted the pictures here before I went.  Would've ordered the Steamed Pork Belly Bun if I knew it looked that delicious.  Next time.

Instead of the Steamed Pork Belly Bun, I had the Roasted Pork Sandwich with Pate, Lotus Chips, and Thai Iced Tea.  The pork was tender, but lacked in flavor.  An extra shot of salt of soy sauce would've done it a lot of good.  Fortunately the Pate helped to enhance the overall flavor of the sandwich.  Wish the jalapenos were hotter too, rather than bell pepper-like.  

The Lotus Chips were excellent.  Good change from your typical potato chips.

The Thai Iced Tea was up my alley - not too sweet.  If you like it sweet, it may not work for you.  

Tastes aside, one pro of this lunch - dining al fresco.  Perfect leisurely TGIF feel.  Me liked.

Again tastes aside, one con of this lunch - the bread cut the roof of my mouth and now my mouth tastes like blood.  That's always a problem with these Vietnamese-type sandwiches.  

Looking forward to the Steam Pork Belly Bun next time!
author: Irene T.

description: Used to come more often when it first opened and thought it was great. Now, their $9 lemongrass pork bahn mi just doesn't seem to cut it anymore. Portion size is too small for the price, so I don't probably won't be coming back for awhile. Loud music with bad acoustics is a bit annoying as well. Place always seems clean with friendly staff though.
author: M D.

description:
I was really excited when i heard this place opened...there aren't many options for food where i work, and its literally right  across the street.
I was REALLY REALLY excited when i heard they have Vietnamese sandwiches....

I tried a sandwich and it was less than stellar...not ideal but i can deal...i mean..i would rather have less than stellar than a frozen burrito from Walgreens...

Anyhoo....They make a Short Rib wrap that is pretty awesome...i have had it a few times...and its always tasty, the meat is very tender and oh just rightly spiced...

The prices are a little steep...I like my Vietnamese sammy cheap and delicious. (Saigon Sandwich, Folks)  

Its busy at lunch, so there is usually a line with very little seating space...boo...

Oh..i also had a pork bun there once...it was GNARLS!

I'm sure i will eat there again someday...usually i go here if the taco truck in the alley across the street has a big ass line.
author: Ripley B.

description:
nice Vietnamese sandwich and Korean wrap, but a bit lose of the authenticity.  The meat is tender though.  The coffee is not good if u really know how to drink Vietnamese coffee.  In general, the food is okay.  Okay quick food to eat when u work in the area.  Comparing to other Vietnamese sandwich like Nom Nom's or Lee's sandwich they are not really a competitor.

Clean and nice service with decent menu in general.
author: tomcat f.

description:
Came here for lunch the first day it opened.  We were all super excited for this place as it sounded amazing.  I don't know if it quite lived up to our expectations though.  

Let me start by saying that the quality of the ingredients are really good.  I had the pork banh mi and the pork was well done, the vegetable fresh.  It has a lot of potential.  But maybe it was because we were here on the first day, but there was something missing from the finished product.   Had it been my first time trying pork banh mi, I might have loved it, but there was something missing in the overall flavoring of the sandwich.  Nevermind that at over $8 (got it with the pate), it is extremely expensive for mediocre sandwich.  Also, the pate kind of got lost in the sandwich.  Couldn't taste it at all.  

I also tried the pork bun.  It was a little more impressed by it.  Though, it really didn't look like a pork bun.  I wasn't sure about cucumbers in it, but they actually tasted pretty good.  

So, overall this place didn't quite live up to its expectations.  I would give it a lower score, but I think there's a lot of potential for this place.  Like I said, the ingredients are fresh and delicious.  Also, everyone there was so nice and friendly.

I'll probably give it another shot.  Everyone seems to be raving about the short ribs and ssam.  I was trying to avoid my general tendency to flock towards Korean food, but I might have to try it out next time around.  

Oh and the lotus chips were pretty delicious.
author: Alea G.

description: I ordered the ssam wrap, spiced chicken, veggies and rice in a rice paper wrap. Delicious, filling and healthy! A perfect satisfying lunch.
author: Shyama G.

description: how you order reminds me of chipotle.  the asian version of the burrito is the best!  it falls apart a little bit since the "wrapper" is so soft, so be careful to not let things fall into your lap.  the food is yummy!
author: B C.

description:
Advantages:
1) Great Chicken sandwich.  Death to chickens.
2) Fresh
3) Great vietnamese coffee
4) Great fast service. The owners are serving you and overseeing the operations; how many Bay area restaurants can say that?
5) I like the eco friendly station with composting/recycling
6) You can eat outside in the sun;  goes a long way for me being stuck in the office all day....lets all lobby for more outdoor eating, less parking/polluting cars.
7) Much better then muffins and Bamboo.   I need to try Saigon Sandwiches on Polk one more time
8) They take credit cards= They pay taxes.  CA schools thank You

Disadvantages:
1) True Banh Mi afficionados know it is all about the freshness of the bread first.   Spice Kit bread gets 4 stars.  I wish the bread was crazy fresh like Westminster CA  where I saw a woman running the bread from the oven to the counter
2) I don't understand the Korean wrap; the wrap was falling apart.  I will not order again
3) Negative yelpers who do not understand basic economics and that rent in a nice building like that has to be expensive.  Of course the sandwiches will cost more in that building!  Who is willing to walk from the financial district to the tenderloin to save $3 and get mugged for $30?
4) Stop the Pate; I know it is traditional...the ducks deserve better...they eat the bugs that the chemical industry is lose/lose.  Long live the ducks.

I go to Spice Kit once per week for lunch and I recommend it.
author: Jordan M.

description:
With names like Thomas Keller and Ron Siegel on their resumes, Will Pacio and Fred Tang present well-cooked and easily understood Asian fast food at Spice Kit. I'm glad we hit this place our first night, as it would become a go-to choice from the rest of the trip. The concept is simple: choose a sandwich, wrap, or salad as the platform and then choose a protein. We had two bánh mì sandwiches, one with roasted pork and one with beef shortribs. This was my first foray into bánh mì territory. It's a Vietnamese sandwich traditionally garnished with liver pate, mayonnaise, a slaw of pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, and cilantro. The shortribs weren't bad, but the roasted pork was perfect. The acid in the slaw cuts through the fat of the pate and pork and adds a nice, bright note. I have had dreams about that pork bánh mì since then, and have already located a recipe for pate that I want to try making soon. If Out the Door didn't have proximity going for it, I suspect Spice Kit would have become our default choice for a quick meal.

We also ordered some steamed pork buns. My experience with the dish in the past has been a soft, pillowy dough which completely surrounded a chopped pork filling similar to what you might find in an egg roll, only a bit sweeter. The Spice Kit take on them is a grilled slab of pork belly basted with hoisin and some veggies. They were delicious, but I'll admit that I was far too enamored with the bánh mì to get terribly excited about them. For those keeping score at home, roasted pork + pate is greater than pork belly alone.

We also got an order of the ginger peanut slaw to share. It was fine, though barely registered compared to pork buns and other porky goodness.
author: Ryan C.

description: I've been here twice now and had the chicken salad and tofu salad.  I really like the salad itself -- the peanuts, cilantro, mango, papaya etc. in it is delicious -- but the chicken lacked flavor and moisture. So I decided to try the tofu next time, even though I don't really like tofu. Not surprisingly, that didn't really help.  Still, these are pretty satisfying salads and quite cheap too. And they're open late enough that I can grab it for dinner, which is a major plus.
author: Richa A.

description: I used to love the place.  I order it today because I had a craving.  I order the tofu banh mi.  They changed the bread.  The new bread is a kind of hard.  I ordered lotus chips.  I got taro chips. I ordered through Postmates, so maybe they forgot to update the menu.  I miss the old Spice Kit.
author: C. N.

description:
I've eaten there once.  The food was okay.  I noted that the rice bowl was heavy on the rice and light on everything else. But this review isn't so much about the food, but about the customer service.  

One day soon after my initial Spice Kit lunch test, I walked by there on the way to work and noticed that they had an open soda fountain with a water lever for water.  And I thought that maybe instead of asking the Peet's people to fill my water bottle could just fill it myself at the fountain.  So I walked up to the counter and asked if I could fill my water bottle.  The person I was directed to was the owner/manager, who said sure, with a smile.  So I stopped by a second time, maybe a few days later, on the way to work and asked the person at the register if I could fill my water bottle. She looked back at the owner, then nodded and said yes.  The third time I just kind of assumed it was okay, and said "Hey, I'm just going to fill my water bottle" and headed over to do that.  The fourth time (so this is maybe over the course of 3 weeks?) I just went straight to the fountain because I was thinking this wasn't an issue for them.  Bear in mind that I am your typical SOMA worker and look presentable, and on a good day fashionable--so I am neither a snob or a homeless person.  Anyway, the register person that day (someone I hadn't seen before) came over to the fountain and pretended to do something to the garbage can while I was filling my water bottle with water from the  fountain.  After she went back to the owner the owner walked over to me as I was leaving and said "Please leave. And don't come back." And I said, "But I thought filling my water bottle wasn't an issue." And he said again "Please leave." And I said  "But I don't understand where this is coming from--I've asked you before and you were okay with it." He basically denied this (so he's either crazy or has early onset Alzheimer's) and said again "Please leave." So I did.  But not without a really gross, disgusting feeling.  

So much for saving the planet.  I hope the place implodes with the next tech bubble implosion.
author: Mare M.

description: This place is creative with the type of food they offer. It's fun to try at least once, but I'm not too excited to come back. i ordered the pork belly bun, the pork is not as tender as Chairman Baos. The grilled beef rolls in rice-wraps are satisfying. I like how they added kim-chee rice inside, but there were too much sprouts.
author: Lynn P.

description:
Dear Spice kit management,

We love you for who you are trying to be but you have a few things to fix before we can completely fall for you:

Be more organized and efficient to reduce the confusion in the waiting area. Write order numbers on bags. Separate lines of those waiting on food vs ordering. Give drinks immediately after ordering so we aren't all standing around starving and hoping our order is next.

Cut down on the dressing on the slaw.  It's tasty but oversaturated.

Drinks are too sweet.  Ease up on the sugar and they taste better and still cut the spice in the food.

Lose the plastic for recyclable paper boxes.  This is San Francisco and the locals are crazy about their recycling.

That all said, you have a fresh concept and delicious food.  Thank you for listening.
author: Kris N.

description: I LOVE the veggie wrap here...something about the marinated tofu is all kinds of delicious!  The little pork shoulder buns are yummy too (fatty in a good way).  The fried lotus chips are a great little side too.  However, I am only giving 3 stars because the size of the wrap seems to be getting smaller and smaller every time I go...what's up with that???  The prices aren't cheap and you really shouldn't cut corners w/ the portions...  :-(
author: Monica P.

description: I visited Spice Kit twice this week to grab some lunch to go. First time, I tried the sandwich with tofu and lotus chips. Sandwich - the flavors were nice but I felt the tofu was a bit too soft, would have liked a firmer texture so the tofu wouldn't mush out of the sandwich when I took a bite, also  to hold up to the crisp vegetables and bread. Another thought, it would have been nice if the bread had been toasted to give the sandwich some crunch to contrast with the other ingredients. The lotus chips are advertised as "crispy" but mine were a bit chewy. Is it that they were not freshly fried? I don't know. Not inspired to try them again since they also lacked flavor. Second trip I tried the wrap with beef. Again, flavors were good, however I found the wrap a bit unwieldy and eventually just had to use a fork because it was turning into a mess. I went with the wrap thinking I'd cut carbs but there was a lot of rice in there. Service was friendly both visits and my order was ready fast enough that I will be back to try the salad.
author: Kenneth C.

description:
open later is good.  the concept is great.  the pedigree is impeccable.  delivery did not meet expectations.
chicken banh mi.  thought he might take it to the next level.  instead too much of the pickled ingredients, parsley, chicken, just didn't mesh well together.  sous vide meat with grilling -- that part works.  the pork bun meat was extra fatty, but tasty.
author: Rob C.

description: horrible and expensive FAKE... they got this limeade they pour from a store bough carton into a glass jar then into your cup to make u think they made it... FAIL FAIL FAIL
author: Marc A.

description: Double the price of banh mi that could be had anywhere else in town and less than half the taste make for a very unsatisfactory experience. Anyone who thinks this is good needs to try banh mi at Dinosaurs in the Mission. You'll never want to eat at Spice Kit again. Guaranteed...
author: Carla B.

description: A colleague suggested going to Spice Kit for lunch. It's refreshing to have a decent Vietnamese Bahn Mi in the SOMA area for a change instead of the typical sandwiches like turkey or roast beef. I had the bahn mi with roast pork and pate (add $0.75), a bag of homemade deep fried lotus root chips and a cup of fresh young baby coconut juice. The bahn mi was good, it was a good size, the French roll has a crunchy crust and moist inside. I thought the pate was a little too thinly spread that I could barely taste it. The roast pork is good though, nice and tender and lots of flavor infused with lemongrass. I also enjoyed the lotus root chips. They were sliced thinly and deep fried to golden brown and lightly salted. I thought the chips were unique. My lunch was good, the bahn mi was tasty, but the price tag of $14.50 for a sandwich lunch was a little spendy.
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description: I know I said it was expensive, but I think I'm really taking a liking to this place. The veggies are super fresh and meat is so good, I've become a regular. This place has become the highlight of my weekly lunch rotation. +1 star!
author: Vince L.

description:
Totally meh. I had the roast pork bahn mi with the pate and the steamed pork bun.

Bahn mi:
For the whopping (comparatively, to other bahn mi) price of $8.50, I was expecting something a bit better or higher quality and with a higher meat/veggie to bread ratio.
The pork was a bit underseasoned and while not "dry" per se, I was expecting a bit more juiciness from the meat. So, borderline dry. The mayo was a bit runny and there was probably too much of it. The amount of meat and veggies was pretty skimpy. So my bites were dominated by bread. I mean, to even skimp on the veggies seems a bit...cheap.

Pork bun
It was pretty good, though I don't know if I'd go back just for the pork bun.

Overall, even if the sandwiches were $2 I'd pay the extra couple bucks and go to Saigon Sandwiches. Bahn mi for $7+ should at least be just as good than the $3-4 ones.
author: fi l.

description: I have had their food here a few times. I have tried their Ssams and Pork Buns. You can tell they use quality ingredients here because the pork is so tender and the ingredients are so fresh! A ssam has your choice of meat, greens, bean sprouts, perfectly cooked rice, and kimchi and pickled cucumbers which tops it all off! The pork buns are yummy too! People are complaining of the price but I'm going to assume they over look the quality of the ingredients.
author: Kathleen H.

description: I'm not too sure how this place received 3.5 stars, but I'm about to bring it down. My coworkers and I went here during lunch, so of course it was pretty packed. This place gave my coworkers and I food poisoning and I wouldn't be surprised if this place gave other people food poisoning as well.  A month or so ago, they gave my other coworkers food poisoning also (which I wish I would have known).  This place needs to be shut down.
author: YUMM E.

description: So delicious.  love this place and the yummy five spiced beef wraps.
author: Miss P.

description: Went back and had the tofu rice wrap...wasn't that great.  Lacked flavor.  THe tofu was too tough and texture wise, the bean sprouts were weird.  Also, the wrap fell apart after one bite so I had to use a fork and knife.
author: C A.

description:
Spice Kit is a great lunch spot for the area when you want something a little different.  Sure it's a little expensive, but so is just about everything else around there and they use pretty high quality ingredients.  So, in response to some yelpers,  you would pay this much for americanized-korean/vietnamese food because you:

1. need a quick , yet satisfying lunch;
2. can't go to those Vietnamese places you actually love (Ba Le in El Cerrito is my favorite!); and,
3. are tired of eating salads and sandwiches. 

I have tried the beef shortribs, pork and tofu ssams (I haven't been able to bring myself to paying $7-$8 for a banh mi just yet), the salad with five-spice chicken, the pork buns and the lotus chips.  Here are my thoughts/opinions:

1.Ssams: If you are trying to look at all dignified, I would recommend that you eat the ssam with a knife and fork rather than like a burrito because it always falls apart by the end (at least for me...perhaps there are more graceful eaters than I out there).  The beef shortribs were juicier and more flavorful than the pork.  The tofu seemed saltier than the meats.  You can also customize the ssam to ask for more/less veggies, rice or sauce.  Warning, the more veggies / sauce you put in and less rice, the more likely it is to fall apart.
2. Salad with five-spice chicken: The salad was lightly dressed and the chicken chunks were very tender.  I wish there was less salt and more flavor on the chicken (salt doesn't equal flavor in my book).
3. Pork buns: The pork buns were terrible.  The bun was dry and the cucumbers didn't taste properly pickled.  I definitely wouldn't get that again.  
4. Lotus chips: The lotus chips were thinly sliced and crispy, but nothing special.  They tasted basically like lightly salted chips.  You should dip them in sriracha sauce if you're looking for a little more flavor.  

There are a few small tables outside and about 5 tables for 2 inside.  The place is pretty loud even when there's no one in it.  I'm not sure why that's the case but it's unfortunate because I really liked the music they were playing (Arcade Fire, Phoenix, Vampire Weekend, Radiohead, etc.).
author: Amy C.

description: If you are vegetarian or vegan, don't even go there.  Its time waste, money waste.  The only veggie dish (TOFU)..they gave 5 pieces dry with lot of rice.  It was tasting horrible.  Its also very expensive..comes to $7 for five small cubes of TOFU.
author: Sowmya R.

description: I went here for lunch 2 days ago with 3 of my friends and we all got food poisoned. I'm in the toilet writing this review. Don't be surprised if a health inspectior shows up. I orders the five spicy chicken wrap.
author: mrhustler h.

description: It's tough to find healthy, fairly priced food in SOMA.  Spice Kit is in an unassuming corner of a large office building so it's easy to miss.  But it's definitely a place to check out.  I grabbed a chicken ssam (Korean wrap) and some lotus chips today.  The ssam was bursting with bean sprouts, lettuce, rice, cucumbers, and chicken; I still have one half of the ssam for dinner later.  And the lotus chips...well, if you can deep fry something and not have it taste like you slurped up a veggie oil spill, hats off to you, Mr. Deep Fryer.  The chips were just salty enough, thin enough, and crispy enough.  Pure lunchtime bliss.
author: Joy H.

description: The tofu Banh Mi was okay, a little too much cinnamon.
author: Jack B.

description: Bahn Mee was ok.  I was expecting bolder flavors but nonetheless it was served quickly & it's a great healthy option.
author: Roger H.

description:
Spice Kit is fast becoming one of my new happy places.  Since I found out about it approximately three weeks ago, I've been there about as many times.  I'm planning on getting lunch out tomorrow, and since I made that decision earlier today the angel on my shoulder has had a very hard time convincing the devil on my shoulder that I should try to eat someplace besides Spice Kit.

I definitely wouldn't call Spice Kit authentic but I would call it fresh, tasty, made with love, and (if you play your cards right) healthy.  I would also call it fast, but only if you don't go during the lunchtime rush.  If you don't like waiting in line and you don't like eating a bit earlier or later than most, you might find a venture to Spice Kit quite hopeless.

But for those with iron wills and iron stomachs, Spice Kit serves up a mean sammich that, in my humble opinion, is  worth the wait.  I've only gotten the tofu banh mi because it's so good that I can't talk myself into getting anything else.  For the health-conscious: their tofu is organic, and BRAISED.  It looks fried, and it's tasty enough that if someone told me it was fried, I'd believe them.  But I checked - braised.  Go forth, ye paranoid of diet, and ingest.  I sure did.  As far as the other fixin's, the pickled veggies are delightfully tart, but balanced with a bit of mayo.  It's really quite artfully done, because you get the mayo's texture and softening qualities without really noticing that there's mayo all up in your sammich.  My one gripe is that I do wish they would distribute their hot peppers a little more evenly.  You can go for a few bites without getting any heat and then get a lot of it all at once.  I've also had a bite of the pork buns, as well as the short ribs, and both are excellent.  I think I could probably just make a meal of the pork belly buns, as the texture and flavor are both right on.

What I really especially like is that both the owner and the head chef are always there cooking, bagging up the orders and (when they can) talking to people.  It strikes me as a business that's really trying in earnest to do well, and to do right by its customers.  While modernized, semi-gentrified Vietnamese food may not be earth-shattering or world-changing, it's still a good way to get some tasty food to the masses.  I heartily approve.  In fact, now that I've thought about my tofu banh mi, I'm going to have a harder time than ever deciding to go somewhere else...rats.
author: Becca S.

description: This place has OK food, but doesn't have that great taste and is overpriced. Basically, if you walk downtown into the financial district at noon and a place isn't lined up it is for a reason.
author: Dan V.

description: Oh the yummy goodness! Thanks again to my co-worker Rafael for making a food run in the rain. Ordered the pork bun, lotus chips and Ssam with beef shortribs (korean wrap). The Ssam looked like a giant spring roll/burrito. I'm glad I ordered it, since you immediately get all the flavors of the tender meat, vegetables, rice and sauce. And to top it all off, the steamed pork buns with grilled pork belly were freakin outrageous. A little pricey for 2 for $5, but I could eat 10 more right now. It's that good! I'll definitely try the other stuff on the menu. Yummo!
author: Ariel P.

description:
Me and the lady were walking down Howard for dinner when we passed Spice Kit.  We stopped to check it out and decided to give it a shot.  Did not regret!

I had the beef short rib sandwich with pate and she had the roasted pork wrap.  Both were damn good.  The beef was savory, tender, and plentiful.  Along with the crisp veggies and bread toasted to perfection, it took the Vietnamese sandwich to a whole new level.  The wrap was also amazing.  It was like a giant awesome spring roll filled with yummy goodness... the lady offered a bite and I almost refused to give it back.  Delicious.  If you live or work in SoMa, Spice Kit is DEFINITELY worth checking out.

I read a couple of other reviews and think it's silly that people are comparing the sandwiches here to the Vietnamese sandwiches that typically sell for about $2.  Yeah those things are decent and cheap as hell, but Spice Kit is still a delicious, filling, healthy meal for under $10.
author: Will H.

description: ok -- YUM. The Saam is like a thai burrito but without the food coma.  I had it with chicken which was very flavorful. I couldn't finish (and i'm a big eater) so it's plenty and good price. The slaw was lackluster in my opinion so i wouldn't get that next time.  Overall i definitely recommend this place!
author: Carol T.

description: I came here the other day following a rave review from a coworker's boyfriend.  I liked it!  The menu was simple and straightforward and the line and service moved very quickly.  I chose the Korean ssam option and the pork... what I received was basically like bi bim bap in a rice wrapper - beansprouts, grilled pork, kimchi, rice all wrapped up in a neat package.  It was definitely filling, I had trouble finishing it all.  I'd like to go back & try their banh mi option though a part of me will have difficulty accepting paying over 3+ for a banh mi but I understand this is the FiDi afterall.  Not all like fusion-y sort of things and I agree not all work well but I think this is one that does.  I would definitely come back... they also have vietnamese iced coffee :)
author: Suzanne V.

description: Delicious, more selection than most vietnamese sandwich places, love the prime rib, had pork as well, but I get cafe dolce's combo meal for $6.50 instead of $10 and comes with drink and chips!
author: Lu G.

description: This is a great place to grab a quick lunch to go. I must warn you to get there before "rush hour" (noon-ish) because it can get really busy.  Get the pork bun, it's delicious. I also tried the beef short rib sandwich. It was really good as well. The owner and staff are very friendly and I will definitely be back to try the other stuff on their menu.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Overall was a pretty good change from my usual lunch spots. I ordered the vegetarian wrap which came with pickled veggies, some kind of spicy fried rice, tofu, lettuce and cucumbers all wrapped up in rice paper. While the vegetable to carb ratio was good, I had a little trouble eating my wrap. The rice paper was kind of sticky and hard to bite off (or cut with a fork and knife) and ended up tearing so it was leaking sauce. The taste was good; it was spicy but not overwhelmingly so, though it does have a very strong aftertaste (bring some quality gum or mints with you). I also don't think given the ingredients, that leftovers would keep well through the next day, so go when you're feeling hungry.
author: Priyam D.

description:
i love the spaciousness of this place, although i do feel that it could use a few more tables in the dining area to complete the whole restaurant feel. the menu reminds me a lot like chipotle, you can mix and match the base of your dish with various meats so it's very customizable. i ordered the salad with five spice chicken with some lotus root(YUM) chips and two pork belly buns...to share with the bf of course. he ordered the sandwich with shortribs. 

i was impressed when our food came, like whoa, i only paid for one order of salad...did you guys accidentally give me two? or maybe i look like an awesome gal so you hooked it up?! anyway, loved the salad because it came with strips of mango in a drizzle of sweet dressing. the meat on the other hand was questionable. sure it was tender, but the spices were a bit off from what i'm used to. my bf's sandwich was bursting with meat, needless to say he was beyond satisfied. the pork belly buns were sooo fatty and tasty, definitely a must! overall it was a good deal for what we paid. 

warning: an order of lotus root chips fit in the palm of your hand =(
author: Melissa Y.

description:
Quick, reliable, delicious food; my favorite is the pork bun (the only way they serve their yummy grilled pork belly), which is meltingly perfect. For a full meal, I like the ssam. I've never tried the banh mi or salad.

Although they have a few tables, I find the ambience too spartan and noisy to enjoy a meal with company there. I just fetch my food and go.
author: HighExpectations A.

description: Quck, clean, and convenient spot to get your banh mi fix at lunchtime.  The lotus chips are nice - like extra thin potato chips.  The sandwiches are tasty and fresh, just watch out for those peppers!
author: Foster K.

description:
Yum. 
Had the wrap with short ribs and a pork belly bun. Super fresh ingredients and great textures. Meat was flavorful and tender. 
Definitely coming back. 
Service was fast as well.
Only four stars because the menu is somewhat limited (but that helps the freshness, I suppose, and I'd rather a place do a few things right) and it's pricey.
author: Vidya R.

description: this place has a very simple menu and you can't go wrong with anything! its all good! whatever you get, get a pork bun too.
author: Chizzy T.

description: The food was tasty but not tasty enough to spend $9 on a bahn mi! Not bad, but just a little overpriced for something you can get for $4-6!
author: G K.

description: Overpriced mediocrity.  You can tell why they charge so much - the $ goes into the decor and the million people behind the counter.  The meat for my pork banh mi was too chewy, bread not toasted enough.  Served on a pizza platter hahaha
author: Dong T.

description: Great lunch option. 5 spice chicken is quite tasty. Does get pretty crowded during the lunch rush, but so do most places in the Financial District.
author: S S.

description: Spice Kit is great. The pork sandwich with the pate is the best bahn mi I ever had. The pork buns are delicious. I would eat here again.
author: Lucas T.

description:
First review!

I was fortunate to be invited to the soft launch of Spice Kit, a new Asian Street food place from ex-French Laundry and Ritz Carlton masterminds.  Much more creative menu than Out the Door.

I had a ssam with short ribs - the meat was so flavorful and the rice paper wrap with lettuce made the sandwich seem light as a salad.

My husband had a bahn mi, with signature pate.  Very delish!  

Vietnamese iced tea was excellent - not too strong as in some hole in the wall places, and the condensed milk was just right, not too sweet.

I'll have to add to my rotatation of FiDi lunch eats.  I hope they can handle the crowds when they launch for real.
author: M K.

description: So I had never heard of Spice Kit before my co-workers asked if they could pick me up something so I said sure. When Sara came back the pork sandwich was so good and the bread was nice and soft but not to wet. The pieces of pork were just the right size and OMG. I cant wait to have one again.
author: Dee Z.

description:
Before you read...  Remember the location of this place, I don't think they will be around much longer if you want a $1.75 sandwich - This is high rent district folks, don't be so damn cheap!!!  If you want that kind of price go to one of the 7,593 Lee's Deli locations...

The food:
- Unique
- Non-traditional, and more on the fusion side
- Good concept of trying to mainstream the genre of food
- Good middle of the road and not to extreme either way of the palette

I like the concept and the variety of the menu, at the same type how simple it is.  The wraps are great.  The pate on the sandwiches are a great touch.

I probably go here 2x per month for variety.  

You get out of there faster if you call in of fax your order and just pick-up...
author: A L.

description: I used to think this place was pretty good especially since it was right in my building but since they recently changed up their bread I am not a fan.  Hopefully they will switch back but until then I'll move on.  My guess is they will do just fine since their aren't that many options around here and the lunch crowd doesn't like to walk.
author: Eric G.

description: Actually about 3+, but I'm sure there is room for improvement. I went the same day The Examiner did a feature article, so it was a bit chaotic and they were out of the lotus chips. I did the Korean wrap version of the beef. It was not quite as spicy as I expected, and I suspect that would have made it a bit tastier. Lots of well-seasoned short rib beef, though. Next time I'll do the Vietnamese sammie version (and go on a sunny day).
author: Robert M.

description: Straight to the point - This place is great! The fresh made pate in the bun mi was delicious and that pork belly bun was one of my favorites. Just thinking aout it - im hungry again.
author: Marc D.

description: I am at this very second eating the chicken wrap and couldn't help but write immediately -- I can feel the spiciness of the chicken on my lips! This is a great solution to the SOMA people that need a quick lunch (ordered and was out the door in less than 10 minutes) and that dread a salad, mostly because it requires a fork, but also because it's just not satisfying once you hit about 3PM cause you're hungry again.
author: Krystha B.

description: I have been eying this place for ages on my way to work. It seemed so intriguing...spices...korean...vietnamese food in an urban setting downstairs from a big law firm. I finally had a chance to stop by to sample their sandwiches. I had the short rib ssam and the five spice chicken. These are very fancy vietnamese styled sandwiches. The bread isn't as hard as most, so I didn't feel like I was scraping the roof of my mouth biting down into it. I definitely will be back to try their salads and pork buns...
author: Natalie S.

description:
I usually come by this place every other week (if I came here every week, I'd be in a bad place healthwise). 

I've had the tofu banh mi, but I prefer the chicken version. The meat is cooked fresh, and the veggies are pretty fresh as well - you can tell when  you can smell the cilantro right when you unwrap it. My only disappointment has been the peanut ginger coleslaw - it didn't have much taste to it.
author: Sweta M.

description:
Love Love LOVE the pork belly buns. Everything else? meh....

Chicken sandwich... not so great. Don't get the pate, it's not the same as your local vietnamese joint. 

Viet Ice Coffee....also not legit. Taste like american ice coffee.
author: George H.

description: The food here is really tasty and the staff are nice. Try the Ssam.
author: Mike G.

description:
I watched the first two weeks as the lines went out the door, but waited to try it after hearing mediocre, at best, reviews from my coworkers. I work in the building so it's very convenient to have something so close besides Peet's and Venue so I finally tried it today.

I ordered the vegetarian (tofu) sandwich (sans mayo), lotus chips, and thai iced tea. I can easily say that the thai iced tea was the worst I have ever tasted (and I drink a lot of thai iced tea). The tea itself was so over-brewed that the cream/milk didn't even add the sweetness thai iced tea is so well-known for.  The lotus chips were okay, greasy and beyond salty which would have been fine but they were overdone so the only flavor to them was the burnt crisp.  But the sandwich was by far the worst part of my lunch.  It started out fine, though the tofu was very bland, until I had a bite of tofu that was sort of peppery and way over-seasoned. It was so full of spices that it over-powed the rest of the sandwich, including the pickled veggies and jalepenos, and sent my tongue into a painful tingling. There was too much spice and no flavor at all in the sandwich.

I would like to go back and give them a second chance, maybe try the wrap instead, but now I'm not sure that's a good idea.
author: Krissi P.

description: Interesting and simple tasting Asian foods in form of bowls, sandwiches, wraps, and salads.  A little pricey for the amount due to the natural food ingredients.
author: Louis H.

description:
Went to Spice Kit today (Day 2) instead of yesterday to avoid Opening Day craziness.  I was still wary of long lines, so I showed up at 11:20 to beat the rush and ended up waiting about 10 minutes for my food.

I ordered the Ssam with beef shortribs, lotus chips, and Vietnamese iced coffee.  Oh my.  Those shortribs... sooo delicious.  Very flavorful and tender.  It will be hard to resist the temptation to order them again next time instead of trying something new.  The kimchi was also very good.  My only complaint is that the rice paper on my Ssam fell apart halfway through eating and I had to switch to a fork and knife.  It didn't bother me that much, though -- the food totally makes up for it.

Lotus chips were awesome!  I didn't think I would love them, since I'm not a big fan of lotus, but I ordered them because of all the reviews here.  They were light, crispy, and perfectly salted.  Will definitely order again.

The iced coffee was brewed to a good strength.  I personally wish that it was a little bit sweeter, but I guess I could always ask next time for them to make it sweeter for me.  Everyone has different preferences...

I will definitely be going back to try other menu items.  I think I will continue to go early (by 11:30) until they get some kinks worked out, but since I have yet to find food (esp Korean food) like this around where I work, it will be worth it.  Regarding value, I left full and it's still cheaper than, say, a sandwich from Sentinel.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I've never been inspired to write a review before now. Convenient location and hours. Fast food that I don't have to pay an arm and a leg for. The ingredients that they use are organic so I'm not sitting in a food coma and or massive guilt trip for getting "fast food." I personally recommend the wrap with the beef short ribs. I'm salivating just wriing about it. I'm excited to try everything else they have to offer, but I'm definitely favoring their wraps.
author: Sumin L.

description: I really shouldn't be reviewing this, because I might be somewhat predisposed to not liking this type of food. The rice wrap was just not really doing it for me, and the flavor combinations made me a bit queasy. The thing that finally did me in was the very bitter thai iced tea :(
author: Roxy G.

description: I have only tried the steamed pork belly bun and it did not do it for me. The pork was good, but I wish there would have been other options than just pork belly as I am not the biggest belly fan. It needed more veggies and sauce. I would not return.
author: Sophia D.

description: Finally got to try this place. I ordered the beef short rib wrap that had spicy rice which I would have preferred  a little more kick, bean sprouts, cucumber,and surprisingly an ample amount of beef. The rice paper that the whole thing was wrapped in was a little chewy but what a great concept. It is so nice to find something different in the financial. I'll be back to try the pork buns for sure! It looks so good!
author: T L.

description:
Four of us came here for lunch yesterday . Our orders: chicken wrap, pork bowl, beef bowl, chicken salad, 2 orders of pork buns, 1 lotus chips, and 2 Vietnamese coffee. Bill came about $53. Expensive for fast food but its location is in San Francisco ...
Now for the food: the chicken roll was too big to eat! It's a giant burrito with no taste . Very bland. The parts all came out after eating half due to the softness of the rice paper. It just didn't cut for roll.
The beef and pork bowls were tasteless ! The rice was Cold..and the meat was very bland ...
The chicken salad was not fresh and not enough dressing. Same problem for the meat - no taste.
The roast pork bun was a little better but still not that special.
The lotus chips were probably the best of all the food here.
The VNmese coffee was way too light and had no flavor.
The service was okay.
Very disappointed with the food! Will not come back!
author: Huyen P.

description:
I'm in love with the pork buns and short rib banh mi with pate!  There may be cheaper places to get a banh mi, but nothing I've ever tried beats Spice Kit's in terms of taste and quality.  I mean, tender juicy Sous Vide SHORT RIBS - need I say more?

I've also noticed they've tweaked their product since launch, and I've really liked some of the changes!  The cole slaw has a stronger ginger flavor, there is even more meat packed into each ssam and sandwich.  You've gotta love a place that takes customer feedback!

I've been back multiple times and it just keeps getting better.  The new Meatball Monday special is great as well.  Soft, juicy meatballs in my mouth.  Tasty!
author: Gilbert T.

description:
After just a fair experience the first time, I decided to try Spice Kit again and order a different sandwich.  I got the "24 hour braised beef shortrib" sandwich this time.  I was expecting to get slow cooked tender meat that the description suggests.  It was OK but given that one of the pieces of beef was still a bit pink, I kinda doubt it had been braised for 24 hours.  

Oh well...
author: Jeff Z.

description:
Just came in for the second day in a row so I could try the ssam :)

I was the only one in there (around 4 PM), and managed to get my food in under 5 mins.  Sweet.

Got the short rib this time-- very very good.

Also got the thai iced tea-- the best I've ever had.

My one complaint:  I only managed to get one bite in before my ssam crumbled into an unmanageable heap.  It was already ripped and falling apart before I even touched it.
author: John D.

description: Good stuff.  its nice to have Bahn Mi that doesnt use F grade meat every once in a while, even if its pricey.
author: Christian M.

description: Spice Kit is probably one of the better FiDi sandwicheries.  Bahn Mi is definitely a good call.
author: Paul K.

description:
i give it 2.5. i had the grilled chicken rice bowl and what i got didn't really resemble a bowl at all. it was just some strips of grilled chicken thrown over rice with some kimchi on the side.

the taste was good but it wasn't anything real exciting. my coworkers love this place but i think i'll pass.

at least i tried it once?
author: laura f.

description: Those pork buns are pretty darn tasty - the sauce was the right sweetness and the pork tender and flavorful.  I wasn't as pleased with the ssam (which I had with five spice chicken) as its flavor seemed pretty muted.  I would definitely come back again for pork buns, though, and to try the beef shortribs banh mi.  Nice to have a salad option.  And love the minimalist / clean aesthetic.
author: Melinda C.

description:
The short: delicious quick lunch, but for what it is, a bit on the pricier side

The long:

3 of us went for lunch last week and the menu is simply...well, simple. You choose from bowl, wrap, salad or sandwich, pick the meat you want in it (chicken and short ribs both amazing), pick a side (pork buns fantastic!) and a drink... It's done in a few minutes and you are on your way.

There is not much room to sit, but this isn't really a sit down place. It's a quick grab your food and go...and it was delish.

I say it's a bit on the pricier side as for 3 of us, it was just under $50 for food and a beverage each...$17 for a grab and go lunch for me is a bit on the pricey side.

Give it a try!
author: Tommy C.

description: I had a beef sandwich from here for lunch and was not impressed.   It was pretty pricy at $8 and there was not much meat in it at all.   And the meat that was in the sandwich was dry.   My coworker got  a salad, which looked much better than the sandwich so maybe I just made a bad menu choice but there are definitely better lunch options in the area.
author: Cheryl B.

description: I saw my coworker eating a monster-sized fresh spring roll and I'm like "what is that!?!" and that was the day I was introduced to Spice Kit. Spice Kit is really small and doesn't have much in the way of ambiance or even a menu really -- their operation could be out of a food truck. Regardless, their wrap is da bomb. Yes I said it. It's like a healthy Korean burrito with delicious customizable meat or tofu. I've only gotten the tofu (as my protein selection) and I really wish it wasn't FRIED. I opt for spice kit when I feel like getting my chow on while also being healthy...which I am successfully able to convince myself of because I'm eating Asian food. The word around the office is that the spare ribs and pork are excellent, as well as the lotus chips!
author: Jessica H.

description: I love that this place is literally right across the street from my building. The menu is simple 1) pick sandwich, wrap or salad 2) pick your meat 3) pick a side (lotus chips are a must to eat with your sandwich). I've pretty much tried everything here and I must say I was satisfied w/ it all (sandwich, wrap, salad, steamed pork buns). I also love how quick/efficient they get customers in and out.
author: Krystel M.

description: This was a solid lunch place.  I ordered the short ribs in a ssam and it was quite filling.  This lunch meal reminded me of bibim bap in a rice skin.  The only thing missing was the fried egg.  I think price wise its on par with most lunch options in the area.  The food was good but the wait was pretty long.  The staff is super friendly and this is a great spot for all those Black Rock employees to grub.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I suppose Spice Kit serves decent quality, fresh food.  It is tasty, but really, nothing special.  Obviously made in large batches and spooned out on an assembly line.

I think any of the Korean or Vietnamese Mom & Pop hole-in-the-wall BBQ/bubble-tea/espresso/ice-cream joints will offer a more flavorful and authentic menu.

And, unbelievably, Spice Kit does not have fish sauce.  You heard that right.  A supposedly Korean / Vietnamese restaurant without fish sauce.  Which means that big, rice-overstuffed wrap will taste mighty dry going down.

Really, no fish sauce?  Would you serve sushi without soy sauce?  Burritos without salsa?
author: Aaron C.

description: Their pork buns were delicious and I could easily eat a half dozen of them. Their beef Ssam was kind of so-so and honestly felt like a giant glob of confusing food. The disparity between the two makes it hard to rate although the beef Ssam was so lackluster I decided to round downwards.
author: Procter F.

description:
bleh! mediocre banh mi. the vegetables in it tasted overly seasoned, bread was decent, chicken was so-so, couldn't really taste the pate either. total rip-off! i felt like i was eating bread dipped in vinegar. eww. and don't both getting the lotus chips either - they taste like regular potato chips. 

completely over-priced for this kind of sandwich. the search in SOMA continues..
author: ally o.

description: Had the veggie wrap. Meh is right -- nothing inspiring about this food.
author: Jack K.

description: I've been meaning to try this place out.  Finally had the Vegetarian Ssam (The Korean wrap - rice paper, red leaf lettuce, cucumbers, seasoned rice, marinated bean sprouts, organic tofu seasoned with soy sauce, scallions, and spices, kimchi, and ssam sause). It was fresh, just right in size, and incredibly tasty.  Will be back for more.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I wanted to check this out after reading about it in the Examiner.. heard it was pretty busy at the usual lunchtimes, but I also found out I could my order in.. I had the korean wrap with beef..wow, that was good! the meat was tender and tasty..plus, the size of the wrap was a burrito.. 

also, I had the vietnamese sandwich with pork..the pork was tender and good, too..the bread was not tough to chew on.. however, I wouldn't go there for the sandwiches.. 

and I had the lotus chips.. just like potato chips.. good, but they don't give you much for $1.50..

conclusion: would definitely go back for the wrap, but not the sandwich or the chips.. prices are a little high for sandwich (be prepared to spend $7-8 on the sandwich or wrap)
author: Linda Y.

description: It was simply dee-lish!  I had the pork wrap and shared a pork bun with my lunch date.  Great taste, presentation and texture.
author: Meredith B.

description: Ordered the shortrib ssam. It was decent, but somehow just not satisfying enough.  Missing something. Will repost once I figure out what that is.
author: Derek C.

description:
I've been here twice and have been thoroughly underwhelmed both times.  

The first time, I had a wrap with the beef short ribs. It was a bland compilation of mush.

Perhaps this was an unintended consequence of making exquisite sous-vide kalbi or perhaps I was just not perceptive enough to pick up subtle flavors.  So I decided to return to try their signature pork buns and a Vietnamese sandwich.
 
The pork belly buns were fine - but not spectacular.  The pork belly itself was tender, but again somewhat lacking in flavor. The bahn mi was a disaster - again, a rather bland compilation of mush on a soggy baguette.  

Given that the average price of banh mi is about $5 ($2.75 if you go to Lee's or Saigon Sandwiches), a $7.95 (or $8.70 with the pate) banh mi had better be exceptional.  This one fell far short.
author: Swissmister M.

description: This is an update to my last post.  I still think this place is a rip off, but some how i find myself walking the 8+ city blocks in order to have lunch/dinner here.
author: Huy T.

description: Simple order at the cashier. High quality ingredients at a reasonable price for lunch.  Sandwiches are tasty.
author: David S.

description: Last week my friend suggested we get together after work and grab dinner at Spice Kit. I had see the place on Unique Eats and had been meaning to try it out. I had the short rib bowl. While the meat was really good I wasn't really impressed with the rice or anything else in the bowl. Yesterday I happened to be in the neighborhood again for work and the beef was so good I decided to try again. I had the Banh Mi this time a huge improvement. I loved the picked veg and jalapenos along with light crispy bread. There was way to much mayo and not enough cilantro but next time I am in the hood I will probably stop by for another one. The short ribs are just too good to miss.
author: Erica T.

description: I loved the wrap - I am always looking for a new food experience/ blend of tastes and textures that I have not had before and this was perfect.
author: Isabel R.

description: The food is pretty good and reasonably priced. I wish the menu was a little more extensive though.
author: Jason C.

description: the chicken bowl and the tofu salad were awesome. we were very impressed.
author: Leira A.

description: New lunch spot that makes the regular rotation.  I prefer the Ssam with chicken or pork.  The pork buns are really good too.
author: Warren H.

description: I love what they are trying to accomplish - high quality organic food to serve downtown. Good service. Clean atmosphere. Only downside is that the food has no flavor. ;-(
author: Eater S.

description: I can't comment on the authenticity of the vietnamese food here but its like the Chipotle of vietnamese food. Great for a quick lunch if you are looking for something different. I had the tofu bahn mi, I was expecting more of a kick but I loved the marninated tofu. I'm weird and I love tofu but maybe next time I'll try their meats.
author: Sara P.

description: Tasty and fresh, but nearly twice the price of Muffins Muffins on 2nd street.  I'd be happy to pay a premium if I were getting more bang for my buck, but I'm having troubling finding the extra bang here.
author: joe b.

description: I needed a quick bit to eat for lunch and didn't want to walk far.  Spice Kit is just downstairs from my building so was the closest.  Haven't been to SK since they opened mid-summer and didn't really care for it.  At first, I found that the food lacked taste and way too expense.  HELLO! If you are going to call the restaurant SPICE KIT... when it better be just that... SPICY!  Well, today I'm singing a different story.  I had the Saam Korean wrap w/Five Spice Chicken!  They really bumped it up a natch in the spice department because it was so spicilicious, just like it should be! Now I have to try everything on the menu!
author: Miriam O.

description:
Met up with friends for lunch here today. All 3 of us went for the shortrib wrap and were happy with it, though mine had completely fallen apart by the 5th bite, so I ended up using a knife and fork. I'd order it again if I could eat it in privacy. Otherwise, I think I'll just get a bowl next time.

Re the lotus chips: they're decorative, but we all agreed that they tasted like salt and pepper potato chips. Not too much of a difference. The peanut slaw was alright, but again, nothing special. My friends also got a pork bun each. They only commented that it was really fatty and that the sauce was something like oyster sauce. Not exactly a ringing endorsement, but I like Chairman Bao's and since they don't come by here, I'll probably give the pork buns a try in the future.
author: Tammy L.

description: sorry to say this, but I'm very disappointed by Spice Kit.  I understand the price is a little expensive because it is in the financial district, but the  food is not justified to the price at all!  my friend and i had five spiced chicken sandwich and roasted pork sandwich with house-made pate: pate is good, marinated veggie is too sour, meat is lack of flavor.  we also had steamed pork bun, neh, not impressed.
author: Sophia L.

description:
solid, should probably improve a bunch in the coming months.

kinda reminded me of a vietnamese chipotle, pick the format (wrap/sandwich/bowl) then pick the meat.  but unlike chipotle, spice kit takes forever to prepare something you'd expect in a couple minutes.

i've gotten the wrap twice and it's tasty and leaves me wanting more.  especially since they really skimp on the meat, which is otherwise delicious.  also unlike chipotle (ok, maybe i should have killed that analogy long ago) the wrap falls apart with one bite and you have to take a knife and fork to it.  had the pork bun last time too and it was the same -- tasty but small.

for all my whining, the place really isn't bad.  and i love that it's open 'til 8pm so i'm not stuffing face from the candy dish on the late nights in the office.
author: Gary D.

description: I'm HOOKED!  My coworker introduced me to this place a week ago and it is SO good.  I usually get the spare rib wrap and the meat is just so tender and juicy its scrumptious!  Feelin' a little hungry just thinking about it.
author: Connie L.

description: So I went to Spice Kit the other day and I had a great experience there. I first notice the decor and and music. I definitely enjoyed the music selection that was being played. I tried the Roasted Pork Banh Mi with pate and it was delicious the pork was delicious and tender. The pickled vegetable added nice contrast in flavor and texture and the pate really brought all the flavors together. A side of lotus chips, pork bun and a drink and it was a excellent lunch. Best part is that they are open til 8 pm during the week perfect for that after work quick meal. Next time I'll try the Ssam and let you all know.
author: Josh M.

description:
best tofu sandwich. yum!! i love the way they make their tofu here...great flavor--kinda like red-cooked stuff (that sounds really weird in english), great texture...takes me back to dad's home-cooking. the sandwich has a nice little kick to it too! i just wish they'd put in a little bit more tofu though. the salad was good too. nice variety of leaves, jicama and mango...but again, i want more tofu!

if they made a tofu rice bowl, you might find me here every day. i'm already there 3 times a week. 

oh yeah, and everyone there is super nice!
author: Adrienne Y.

description: I've been here several times, and each time has been better than the last.  The pork bun is quite good: rich, juicy and delicious.
