The atmosphere is great, and I was able to work with Will to get a large group of people in one evening and have a small, festive event.  Highly recommended.
author: Ken M.

description:
I am a fan of the Ssam Beef Rib Tip!  I tried the Bahn Mi and Lotus Chips, those won't have me coming back. But the Ssam (aka Wrap) will bring me back many times.  

If you ever need a filling lunch and possibly dinner too, then get the Ssam for $8.71.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Had a chance to try Spice Kit a few weeks back, and my only complaint is that I wish it was closer to where I live.

As a Vietnamese person, I've had plenty of Banh Mi in my lifetime, and I feel that Spice Kit has come up with an exciting innovation on the classic sandwich.  I love the fact that Vietnamese sandwiches are no longer confined to "a cheap alternative to a better meal" status. 
The quality of the ingredients is noticeably better than the standard Vietnamese sandwich shop, with the pork and pate combining well.  As an added bonus, the pork buns were an absolute revelation and I'd also recommend trying the lotus chips.

Obviously, if you're looking for the cheapest sandwich around, this isn't the place for you.  But for those that appreciate fresh, quality, organic ingredients excellently prepared, it's a definite must include in your quick dining rotation.
author: Huy N.

description: Soo yummy! I am willing to walk the 4 city blocks on my lunch to go here. The food is delicious and the menu is street food style and simple. I always get the Ssam Wrap but next time I'm getting the Banh Mi. The marinated tofu is deliciously seasoned making this a good choice for vegetarians. There is an endless supply of Sriracha hot sauce and ample seating, including an outdoor patio area. What more could you ask for?
author: Julia C.

description:
So I've been thinking about trying Spice Kit since a few buddies raved about it a few weeks ago.  A French Laundry alum and a Ritz Carlton Dining Room alum doing Asian-inspired street food?  Sounds good to me.  

My favorites:
- Short Rib Banh Mi - I think they sous vide the short rib because its SUPER tender and flavorful.  But its all the little things they get right that makes this sandwich.  The bread is perfectly soft yet crunchy.  The pickled veggies give great crunch and acid.  And that pate - well you've got to try it to understand.
- Pork buns - like others have said, these things are super tasty.  Pork belly is cooked just perfect.  And the bun has that right hint of sweetness and chewiness.  Momofuku's got nothing on these guys.
- Calamansi Lime-ade - Never had this before but I'm hooked now.  Everytime I go in now they have one ready for me.
- Tofu Salad - okok, those that know me will find this surprising since I'm usually not a salad guy or a tofu guy.  But a friend convinced me it was worth trying and I gotta say, I'm a convert.  I probably wouldn't have gained those 20 pounds if salads tasted this good all the time.  And the tofu isn't plain white tofu.  Its the fried kind you get in Chinese claypots and its perfect in the salad.

Also the staff is super super friendly, the space is bright, clean and airy,  and they're pretty quick even during the lunch time rush.  

On a personal note, its a pet peeve of mine when people compare places like this to a $3 banh mi shop a la Saigon Sandwich.  Don't get me wrong, I love Saigon Sandwich and cheap taquerias too.  But they're not sous vide-ing top quality proteins, making homemade pate, or using super fresh organic veggies.  And Spice Kit's downtown, not in the Tenderloin or the Mission. 

Bottom line, if you live or work in the area, try it and you won't be disappointed.
author: Burkon W.

description:
really good banh mi. i got my order togo and it was ready even when i showed up early.
lotus chips were really oily - they had soaked the paper bag they came in by the time i opened them up.

for the increased price and hype, seems just like a regular banh mi to me.
author: Lizzie O.

description: the highlight of Spice Kit is a good--but ultimately yuppified--banh mi.  Fast service and the ingredients always seem fresh, whether during the lunch rush or down time. They lose points for a limited menu and the inedible chicken. Menu allows you to customize in a sandwich, bowl, or "wrap".  Some of these combinations work. Others, not so much. Hot pork falls right through the wrap, which is much more suited to a summer roll.  Overall a fine choice for a little lunchtime variety.  Well-meaning but falls short in the execution.
author: Paul E.

description: "fried chicken", fried chicken, FYI they now do fried chicken as an ingredient on both Wednesdays and Fridays.  (this is ofcourse as oppossed to the five-spice chicken everyday...).  lovers of banh mi with true crackling french bagette: reminder: Saigon Sandwich on Larkin, 'half the price, pretty much always to-go, but I sit nearby to eat my sandwich leaning against the parabolic sun collectors / car-bomb deflectors in front of the (old) Federal Building.
author: Stan M.

description: Tried this for the first time; tried the five spice chicken sandwich - it was so spicy my mouth felt like it was on fire. Being the financial district, if you go towards the end of the day, like i did, there's literally no one in there but the three guys behind the counter who acted like they had better things to do than give me the time of day - i almost walked right outta there, but i was curious how their food would be...It's a very small space, only a few chairs, lots of empty space, probably to make room for long lines during the day maybe, but LOTS & LOTS of FLIES - YUK! Plus, the menu has only like six, very pricey items and you don't get a whole lotta bang for your buck. I've had better.
author: Jag F.

description: I was super excited to try this place, but have to say that you can get better Vietnamese in the tenderloin for a third of the cost.   For the area I guess it's a fair price, but I expect to be full after paying $10 for lunch.  Bahn mi was skimpy and the meat was fatty.
author: Sara S.

description: Started eating here in June 2010.  Fresh interesting food at a reasonable price.  I eat here 3-4 times a week and have never had a problem with getting sick.  I hope they open more stores in the Bay Area.   The team running the place could not be more attentive and helpful.  Keep up the good work.
author: mike s.

description: I had this for lunch and order the chicken bowl. It was a pretty filling lunch, but I did not think the flavors were particularly amazing or special. However, the prepared the order pretty quickly and is a good place to go to lunch if you just want some quick simple asian food.
author: April L.

description: Awful.  A "banh mi" has pate so when I was charged extra...really? I had raw pieces of chicken...and have no idea what seasoning it was marinated in but not good.  And I never had a banh mi dripping sauce while I'm eating it.  Would not recommend this place and will not be going back to it.
author: Thuy V.

description:
i finally got a chance to try out the wrap here. heard about this place and i would sometimes pass by it but never got to try it. 
the food here is ok, i was about to get a sandwich but i figured it wasn't worth it for the price, i can find a really good vietnamies sandwich at TL instead of here for half of the price and would taste muuuuuuuuuch better. so i got the roasted pork wrap with a side of the lentil chips and a thai ice tea. the wrap was ok, not great but ok, i kinda wish they added more kimchi in it cause i did not taste the kimchi at all, but other than that, flavor wise, so-so. i'd come back here again to try a different wrap, and order the lentil chips again, the lentil chips is a must, to order.  
you should definitely stop by if your close tho, personally i like the portion of the food, it's fulfilling but it doesn't make you feel too full. don't forget to order the lentil chips.
author: Toni Rose M.

description: For starters, this is an amazing place! Where else can you get awesome vietnamese sandwiches in the heart of the city?! Well, this is the place! First off, the menu is simple, and the ordering process mimics that of Chipotle - select the type of sandwich, the meat, any sides, and your drink - simple! I love their vietnamese sandwich - have it with the short ribs, the chicken, or pork - you just can't go wrong! For the sides, the lotus fries are incredible - sweet, refreshing, and not too oily at all - served in a perfect portion to complement your sandwich. The pork bun is a definite must too - that is, if you're not full already. For 2.95, it's definitely worth it. Keep in mind that this is a pork belly bun dish, so the oil with the pork is a must (if you don't like the fatty pork, this is not your dish); I however, love this dish and get it every time! All in all, you have to try this place; try and you will fall in love with it. I heard lunch gets busy with an average wait time of 20 min; dinner's a good time to go since it does get a bit slower and you'll get your food hot and freshly prepared by the owner himself! Check it out! You won't regret it.
author: Ken L.

description: Awesome sandwiches and lotus chips.  My favorite was the short Rib Banh Mi with house pate--so tasty and reasonably priced!  Also really enjoyed the pork belly buns.  mmmm...so good.
author: Fleur O.

description: Delicious!  Worth the price.  Great location.  This is the place to go to get away from the office for an hour for a casual, relaxing lunch...
author: Tommy N.

description: Very limited menu, after 4 visits I was done. The food is very average and the atmosphere is rather cold. A lot of hype but much ado about nothing.
author: Celine C.

description: Best sanndwiches ever had. The beef they have is as good as any steak house, pork is melt in your mouth tender, chicken is  tender n moist. Pork bun is another melts in yout mouth stuff. Clean, simple menu. Great guys at the counter. I always ask for khimchi with everything. Don't forget to add pate to ur sandwich.
author: Suren E.

description: the pork buns were great! the sandwiches were very good, but I felt the ingredients could have been better distributed. (one bit all vegetables, one bite all meat.) expensive, but that's expected for this area.
author: Nicholas M.

description: the ssams are delicious! i've had these ssams multiple times before but never had this perfectly wrapped ssam! during the first couple of times i had, half way through eating, the wraps fell apart on me. it was not a pleasant experience because i did not expect in need of utensils to eat this wrap. however, it was different this time! the rice paper was tightly wrapped and i didnt need to use the fork that i had it ready next to me! the flavor is always good and its an orgasm in your mouth! i would definitely come back for more, and everyone should give it a try!
author: hikari h.

description: Stopped here for lunch this past weekend. Everything was so yum. I can 't wait to go back. I had the Bahn Mi with pork, as well as the pork buns and lotus chips (I was starving!). Everything in the sandwich was delicious from the bread, to the meat and I also added the pate which was a great decision. The vibe of the restaurant was great. Very clean, nice open kitchen concept, and great music as well (Postal service and XX was playing while I was there). Will definitely be back soon.
author: Sarah C.

description:
went back for the second day and tried the short rib wrap, lotus chips, slaw, and pork bun (again).

i'm changing my review from 4 stars to 5 because there were no flies/bugs today (so i was able to eat inside), all the new dishes i tried [excluding the slaw] were amazing.

i was afraid that there would only be one or two good/great items on the menu, but it seems like everything is a winner.  i still have to try the salad and chicken....
author: Jay M.

description: ever since spice kit moved in downstairs from my work, i literally go here for lunch at least twice a week.  it's so good!  my favorites are the salad with five spice chicken or the rice bowl with five spice chicken, although i have tried everything on their menu and love it all.  my only critique is that the wrap can be a bit difficult to maneuver, which is why i like the rice bowl more - the ingredients are the same but the bowl has no rice paper.  the steamed pork buns are a nice treat if you have someone to share them with, and the ginger flavored slaw is a tasty side as well.  i also really like the banh mi sandwich and recommend getting it with their house made pate.  to drink, the lime ade goes great with the spices in the food - i literally don't know how i got by before spice kit moved in.  the food is definitely a cut above anything else in the neighborhood within the same price range, and i really appreciate that they are open on saturdays so there is at least one thing to look forward to if i have to work on the weekend.  if you haven't already, you should give spice kit a try - you won't be sorry!
author: Erin C.

description: i was in the area tonight, and dropped by this place. the beef ssam was FABULOUS. the meat was tender and juicy, and completely worth it. i can't disagree more with the chipotle punches from other reviewers. the wrap resemble a burrito but with well-done nods to asian roots - the kimchi, bean sprouts, and rice paper wrap - you don't find that usually in one neatly wrapped package. will definitely come back. in fact, craving the ssam already.
author: Jess L.
